Comments and Signature of Indian Superintendent

I have known this Teacher since she joined the Indian Sup't and Board many years ago. She is a woman of great integrity and has given 18 years of loyal and conscientious service. The Indians among whom she worked are in slightly isolated areas and are not exposed to much irritation by Indian Affairs officials or other interested parties such as Churchmen. APPLICATION FOR APPOINTMENT AS PERMANENT CIVIL SERVANT FOR THE PURPOSES OF THE CIVIL SERVICE SUPERANNUATION ACT, 1924, AS AMENDED.

I, the undersigned, do hereby make application for appointment as a permanent Civil Servant for the purposes of the Civil Service Superannuation Act, 1924, as amended.

I was born at Trenton, N.B., on July 1, 1885. I hold a permanent teaching certificate No. 175, granted by the Province of Nova Scotia and dated August 15, 1924. I have taught Indian children at the schools listed below:

| Name of Indian Day School | Years of Service (10 month year) |
|---------------------------|---------------------------------|
| Indian Cove               | 42                              |
| (Indian Grant Reserve)    |                                 |

(give further details on back of page)

In World War II, I had overseas service in the Armed Forces of Canada.

I understand that it will be necessary for the Indian Affairs Branch to carefully consider the School Inspectors' reports submitted upon my work and that these reports must be judged as satisfactory before my application can be submitted further.

I attach the following documents as required by the Civil Service Superannuation Act:

Proof of Age

Note: Those who are recommended for permanent appointment will later be required to submit a medical examination report.

(Signature of Applicant)
Teacher at Indian Cove Indian Day School.

Comments and Signature of Indian Superintendent:
I have known Miss Gurr in my capacity as Indian Sup't and have always found her an efficient and conscientious worker. She has given many years of loyal and conscientious service to the Indians whom she looked after in a difficult and isolated area, and were never given too much attention by the government, doctors, or other interested parties such as Churchmen. Chiefly due to her guidance, example and instruction that this Band is one of the best in the Maritimes. I request that every consideration be given to this application which will in a small way repay Miss Gurr for 42 years of fine, efficient service.

Retirement Leave and Superannuation Allowance, Indian Day School Teachers

Please find attached a submission to Council recommending that Leslie Claus, Teacher, Grade 3, Tyendinaga Central Indian Day School, Deseronto, Ontario, be retired under the provisions of the Civil Service Superannuation Act, 1949, effective from July 1, 1949 and granted the Withdrawal Allowance indicated in the attached Schedule "B".

Ottawa, December 13, 1949.

PRECIS FOR THE CLERK OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL.

Requesting authority for the retirement of Leslie Claus, Indian Day School Teacher under the provisions of the Civil Service superannuation Act, 1924.

Two extra copies of Order-in-Council are required.
December 13, 1949.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to report:

(1) THAT Leslie Claus, Indian Day School Teacher, Grade 3 in the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources, of the Tyendinaga Agency, Ontario, whose date of birth is October 21, 1909, is a contributor under the provisions of the Civil Service Superannuation Act, 1924.

(2) THAT he is eligible on account of resignation to be retired and that his retirement is in the public interest.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that Leslie Claus be retired under the provisions of the said Act, effective from July 1, 1949, and granted the Withdrawal Allowance indicated in the attached Schedule "B".

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

SUPERANNUATION FOR TEACHERS OF INDIAN DAY SCHOOLS

Please find attached a Submission to Council for six of our Indian day school teachers who, we feel, are eligible as contributors under the Civil Service Superannuation Act.

It is just a year since the last list of such teachers was made and these applicants have all been approved by our field and education officials. We have the necessary proof of age and are attaching the certified birth certificates. These teachers have also had their medical examinations and have been passed by the Department of National Health and Welfare as suitable for permanent appointments under the Civil Service Superannuation Act. The National Health and Welfare forms are also attached.

Director.

We have your letter of February 21, 1951 and you will have received by now our letter of February 27, 1951 informing you of your salary increase effective September 1, 1950.

By authority of Treasury Board Minute 400/540 dated January 9, 1951, your permanent appointment as Teacher, School, Grade 3, has been approved effective January 1, 1951.

As you have complied with the provisions of the Civil Service Superannuation Act, you are eligible to become a contributor thereunder. Therefore, $5 will be deducted from your salary each month for superannuation purposes commencing with the month of January, 1951.

You will find attached three copies of Finance Form No. 61, Election Form, which it will be necessary for you to complete if you wish to obtain credit for all your teaching experience in Indian schools. When you have completed the face of these forms in triplicate, you should forward two copies to the Superannuation Branch of the Department of Finance and retain one copy for future reference. We would like to draw your attention to the fact that these forms must be completed within one year from the date of the instrument of appointment, namely January 1, 1951.
You will note that after allowing for your Retirement Fund credit your arrears will be $587.25. However, these figures are an estimate and are subject to revision by the Treasury Board. It is not necessary to pay this amount in one lump sum, but you can pay it by monthly instalments according to the table shown on Page 2 of Form 64.

It is noted that you have had previous experience in Provincial schools. If you wish to claim credit for this service there are certain facts which you should know and we are enclosing a copy of a memorandum regarding "Pensionable Employment". It is suggested that you study this memorandum thoroughly. If you require any explanations, you may write to us. If you are interested in claiming for previous pensionable employment, we would suggest that you write to your Provincial Department of Education asking for the details mentioned in Section 2 of "Procedure".

We are also forwarding you additional copies of Finance Form 64 which it will be necessary for you to complete if you wish to benefit by this offer.

Yours sincerely,

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

SUPERANNUATION OF TEACHERS IN INDIAN SCHOOLS

School Teachers, Welfare Teachers and Principals employed in Indian Schools are eligible for permanent status under the provisions of the Civil Service Superannuation Act and to contribute to the Superannuation Fund.

Welfare Teachers are employed on a twelve-month basis, but as schools are closed for two months' vacation, School Teachers and Principals are employed for an academic year. Authority is requested that for the purposes of the Civil Service Superannuation Act, present and future contributors to the Superannuation Fund be considered as having twelve months' service for each complete academic year of employment, that the yearly amount of deduction from salary for superannuation purposes be made during the ten months of the academic year and that the nature of tenure of these positions be changed from seasonal to temporary and permanent.

Otherwise an employee would have to teach for twelve academic years to accumulate ten years' service, for twenty-four academic years to accumulate twenty years' service and for thirty-six academic years to accumulate thirty years' service. In superannuation schemes sponsored by Provincial Departments of Education, an academic year is considered as a complete year of service. There is a serious shortage of teachers across Canada and the Education Division must compete with Provincial Departments of Education in recruiting staff for its schools. The necessity of teaching in an Indian School for a longer period of time than would be required in a Provincial School would deter well-qualified applicants and teachers who might otherwise seek continuous employment in Indian Schools.
As the Department is endeavouring to establish and maintain a high standard of education in its schools it is necessary to secure and retain the services of certificated and experienced teachers. Therefore, it is thought to be in the public interest to obtain the authority requested.

Director.
Ottawa, March 5, 1952.

Re: Teachers' Superannuation Fund

A number of experienced qualified teachers have made enquiries recently as to teaching positions in our Indian Day Schools. Many of them are genuinely interested in the work among Indians, and not attracted solely by the improved salary schedule in effect in Indian Schools.

However, when the matter of the superannuation fund comes up for discussion, the general feeling seems to be a disinclination to lose their equity of twenty years or more in the Saskatchewan Teachers Superannuation Fund if a transfer is made to the Indian Day Schools. This is not a problem when young, inexperienced teachers join our teaching service, who have the greater part of their teaching career ahead of them.

Oct. 27, 1887

Hon. Sir,

I have seen the said agreement of the grant of $600 towards the new school house on the Lebret Reserve and think it will be forthcoming shortly.

The contract price was $800, of which I am taking the $200 from the missionary board. When the contract was made we made over estimates on the ground that the builder could be cut on the reserve from which we could make all the lower bricks and rafters. The Indians had also signified their willingness to do the laboring work such as setting stones, digging cellar etc. But when the contractor had taken down his cargo of materials and reached the reserve a distance of about 150 miles he found that the Indians would not allow a white builder to be cut neither would they work even at large wages on any part of the building. Hon. C. P. Alison
Minister of the Interior

Hon. Sir,

I have been informed by Mr. Robert Macdonald of the Grant of $600 towards the new school house on the Athabasca Reserve. The contract price was $800, of which I am deducting the $200 from the missionary board.

When the contract was made, we made our estimate on the ground that the timber would be cut on the reserve from which we could make all the lower joints and rafters. The Indians had also signified their willingness to do the laboring work such as setting stones, digging cellar, etc. But when the contractor had taken down his cargo of materials and reached the reserve a distance of about 150 miles he found that the Indians would not allow a single fir tree to be cut; neither could they work even at half wages on any part of the building. Carpenters at $2.50 a day had to be employed to do laborer's work, and an extra allowance was incurred in getting the additional boards and rafters from Red River. And the contractor puts in a claim for $100 extra.
There is no doubt in my mind that he is entitled to compensation. But the point is who should pay the money—thisness—
involves a consideration as to the cause of the change in the attitude of the Indians—
These Indians are Kickapoos (of the Ojibway nation) and the same people who were recently at war with the United States on the northern limits of Minnesota—

The Secretary:

A letter has been received from the Commissioner forwarding the return from the Assabasca school for December quarter last in which he states that the school material as well as other Indian supplies have been stolen by the Indians and that the same have not been returned although he has written to the Chief and threatened to depose him.

No children attended the school during the quarter although the Commissioner says that it was not the fault of the teacher who should, he thinks, be paid his salary. The school is now closed.

It was only last year that $700 was granted for the erection of a schoolhouse and teacher's residence at this place at the request of the Rev. Mr Andrews of Winnipeg. It appears that the Indians are dissatisfied with the location of the school, which was put up on the reserve. They also seem to have a grudge against the teacher for having refused to procure liquor for them on different occasions. This reserve is near the boundary line and the Indians are very obstinate and inclined to be troublesome.

The school is not directly under the control of the Methodist Missionary Society and up to a short time ago was supposed to be Church of England, as shown by Inspector McColl's reports.
Mr Atkinson has had charge of the school since 1897. He belongs to the Methodist denomination and it would appear to be on that account that the Rev. Mr Andrews applied for a grant for a new schoolhouse and residence.

I think that the Commissioner's recommendation to pay Mr Atkinson for the December quarter should be complied with but that the school should not be re-opened until some assurance can be given the Department that the work can be proceeded with regularly.

It seems a pity that the money has been spent for a new building at this place as the Indians have failed to carry out their promises in every way.

Memorandum:

MR. PAGET,

With reference to your memorandum concerning the request of the Indians at Sabaskong Bay, in the Kenora agency, that a day school be established, I may say that from 1899 to 1905, the Missionary Society of the Methodist Church, assisted by a grant from this Department, conducted a day school at this point. The General Secretary, when announcing their withdrawal from Sabaskong, stated that the Indians were prejudiced against religious services and that the teacher was not likely to succeed with his classroom activities.

In 1907, Inspector Semons reported that was a waste of money trying to keep this school open. Mr. Commissioner Laird writes in 1908 that both Methodists and Presbyterians had declined his invitation to place a teacher there and that the Baptist Church had accepted the responsibility for the activity. School was kept open for 4 years under the auspices of this last mentioned church, and at the end of that time (1912) they, too, threw up their hands. The reasons given for this action were as follows:

1. Migratory habits of the Indians,
2. Impossible to evangelize them,
3. Irregular attendance.

Since 1912 there has been no school activity at Sabaskong, and until the attached petition was received, no requests had been made in the matter.

I believe these Indians should be told that our experience with day schools in this locality is unsatisfactory, because of the irregular attendance and the difficulties of securing qualified teachers who will enter and then stay with the work. There is accommodation for their children at the Kenora (Roman Catholic) and Cecilia Jeffrey (Presbyterian) Indian Residential Schools.

I note that complaint No. 10 states there are three trained nurses at the Kenora Residential School. Only one of the Sisters is detailed for this duty and her work is entirely in the school.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt from your Department of a letter from the Rev. Mr. Andrews, of Rat Portage, in connection with school matters on the Assabasca Reserve.

I have already received a petition from the Indians asking for a better school house, and expressing a desire that the Teacher be married instead of single. Conversations had with Mr. Andrews as well as a report from Mr. Inspector Leveque, enable me to make the following report:

The School population reaches almost forty, and all pagans; the average attendance did not reach it for last year, but this can be improved if efforts are made in that direction. The attendance naturally fluctuates on account of the parents absenting themselves from the Reserves on hunting, berry-picking, and other expeditions. The present building is in poor condition and would require at least $200.00 worth of repairs. The parents are very anxious to have a school, and the average attendance of last year has been an improvement on former years.

Under the circumstances, and considering that the Rev. Mr. Andrews has assured me that the Missionary Board of his Church will provide a part of the sum which will be needed for the new building asked for, and also add $200.00 to the grant of the Department for the Teacher's salary, which will enable the Teacher to marry, and thus add the example of civilized family life to the ordinary school training, I feel justified in recommending that $600.00 be appropriated for a combined residence and school house.

In respect to the cutting of logs, I should be pleased to have your authority at an early date to have the same done by the Indians, as they should be cut in the Winter.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Commissioner.

Memo:-

Re communication from the Rev. Mr Andrews in reference to the proposed erection of a combined school house and teacher's residence on the Assabasca Reserve.

Last December a letter was received from the Indian Commissioner, in which he stated that a petition had been received from the Indians of Assabasca, asking for a better school house and expressing a desire that a married teacher should be employed. The Commissioner stated that the present school building is in such a poor condition that it would require at least $200 worth of repairs, and it would at best only be spent in patching up an old building. Under the circumstances and considering that the Rev. Mr Andrews had assured him that the Missionary Board of his church would provide a part of the sum needed for the new building asked for, and also add $200 to the grant of the Department for the teacher's salary, which would enable the teacher to marry and thus add the example of missionary civilized life to the ordinary training, he said he felt justified in recommending that $600 be appropriated for a combined residence and school house. He also asked for authority for the cutting of logs by the Indians for this building, permission for which was given.
The Superintendent General approved of the Commissioner's recommendation for a grant of $600 for a combined school house and teacher's residence and this amount is included in the Supplementary Estimates which have not yet been passed by Parliament.

The Rev. Mr Andrews states in his letter above referred to that he finds it impossible to secure an offer to erect the proposed building from any reliable contractor for a less sum than $1000 in accordance with the plans and specifications that they have adopted, and he suggests that either the residence part be left unfinished, or that the size of the building be reduced. He states that the building could be completed on a reduced scale for $800, which would be covered by the Departmental grant and $200 to be given by the Church, or the Church will contribute in the same proportion if the original plan is adhered to. This would require $733.33 from the Department and $266.66 from the Church.

I think it would be a pity to reduce the size of the teacher's quarters, as additions would have to be made later on, but I think that the Mission Board should be prepared to furnish the additional amount required to carry out the original plan, as the Commissioner's letter naturally led the Department to suppose that if the $600 asked for were granted, the additional amount required to complete the building would be furnished by the Church.

Mr Andrews asks for an early reply so that the work may be proceeded with at once.

SABASKONG INDIAN RESERVE NO. 35.

LAKE OF THE WOODS.

SPECIFICATIONS FOR THE ERECTION OF A SCHOOL-HOUSE.

And TEACHERS' RESIDENCE COMBINED.

To construct a building as shown on plans Nos. 1, 2, & 3, respectively.

STONEWORK.

To build a stone wall under school room to average two ft. 6 in. in height and 1 1/2 ft. thick; wall to start from the surface of ground without excavation; cellar wall to be built under the house 6 ft. 6 in. high and 1 1/2 ft. thick.

EXCAVATION.

A cellar to be dug under the residence part the full size 18 x 18 ft.

JOISTS.

Bedding pieces to be placed all round the wall 2 by 4, to be perfectly level for studding to rest upon. The joists are to be of timber for the lower floor hewed on one side only; to be 2 ft. apart from centre to centre, and not less than 6 in. thick at the smaller ends. A beam is to be placed under the house and school-room as shown on the plans, to be flatted on one side, and duly supported underneath; upper joist to be 2 by 10 and 18 in. centres. To be well bridged throughout the whole building in two rows 6 ft. apart. Upper collar beams to be 2 by 4 scantling as shown on plan I.

STUDDING.

Studding shall be 2 by 4 14 ft. high for walls of entire building, plates to be doubled, each outside corner to be well braced from sill to plate.

FLOORS.

Lower floor to be double; the first covering to consist of cull lumber, then building paper and upper covering No. 1 Match lumber. Upper floor to be cull lumber, paper and matched
same as lower floor.

**CEILINGS.**

In house part 8 ft. 9 in. in the clear for lower storey, and school room to be 10 ft. in the clear. Upper storey as per plans.

**STUDGING and SIDING.**

The studding on all outside walls and partitions to be 2 by 4 and 16 in. centres. The partition studdings to be well secured to outside walls by headers and firmly nailed. Siding to be cull lumber first, then tar paper, then good matched lumber and all well nailed.

**STAIRS.**

To construct one cellar stair 2 by 10 treads properly secured on sides, which shall be 2 by 10 planks, riser 7 in. high.

**FRONT STAIR.**

To be a nice, plain, neat stair with newell post and hand rail. Treads 10 in. wide 1 1/4 thick. Riser 7 in. Hand rail to return on upper floor as shown on plan 3. by the wavy line.

**DOORS.**

There shall be two outside front doors 1 3/4 ft. 10. by 6 ft. 10. One outer door 2 ft. 8. by 6 ft. 8. One inside door below 2 ft. 8 by 6 ft. 8. Two doors above 2 ft. 8 by 6 ft. 8. All panel doors and well made and sound materials.

**WINDOWS.**

One twin window as shown below on Plan No. 1. and one window 4 lights 12 by 30 glass; one small window in pantry 2 lights one below the other in two sashes 12 by 30 glass. Five school room windows 4 lights each 12 by 32 glass. Two windows in upper storey of school room as marked on Plan No. 3. Four lights each 12 by 26 glass, and one twin window of chairs in dwelling house as shown on Plan No. 1. and one window in back of chair light TRAP DOOR. 12 x 30 glass.

There shall be a trap door hung with hinges, made in top of ceiling over upper hall in house part, 2 ft. by 3 ft. for purpose of ventilation.
BASEBOARDS.

These shall be No. 2 common in lower storey of the house, and 10 in. plain. Upstairs 8 in. wide to be put on after the first coat of plaster and before the second is laid on, and a 1/4 round put on all floors.

CASINGS.

All door casings plain, No. 1, common 4 in. wide, windows the same throughout, to be as shewn on plans.

CORNICE.

Cornices to be 11 in. wide, facie boards 7 in. and 5 in per ends of gables.

ROOF.

Good cull lumber for sheeting, put close and tar paper laid on before shingling. Shingles to be best British Columbia cedar, or, to be split by hand and shaved from the pine, on the reserve, to be laid not more than 5 in. to the weather. The gutters in the angles of the roof to be properly secured by zinc or galvanized iron, not less than 6 in. wide from centre of the gutter on each side, or 12 in. in all.

WAINTSCOTTING.

Schoolroom to be wainscotted 3 ft. high, v. matched lumber, finished with a plain cap 2 1/2 in. wide.

CHIMNEYS.

The chimney for the school room to start 2 ft. and a half below the ceiling and extend up to the ridge of the roof and be built 4 ft. above when finished. House chimney to start where shewn on plan, same height as the other. Flues to be 8 by 12, well and smoothly plastered from top to bottom inside and left smooth and clean when finished.

PLASTERING.

All walls and partitions to be well lathed with sound good dry lath and plastered two coats throughout in a workmanlike manner with mortar made of good fresh unaltered lime and clean coarse sand with plenty of hair mixed in. Ceilings all to be
plastered.

BLACK-BOARD.

A black-board shall be put on all around the school room with black mortar extending 4 ft. above the wainscoting and cut off from the upper plaster with a small moulding.

MATERIALS.

The contractor to provide all materials and furnish everything to complete the building including locks other hardware lime, hair, brick, and everything else required to complete the building to the satisfaction of the person who may be appointed as inspector.

PARTITIONS.

There shall be a partition below to enclose space between the hall and the back wall of the house which shall provide a small pantry and passage down stairs. The room over the school room shall be divided in the centre by a partition having a door way in the centre 2 ft. 8 by 6ft. 8. There shall be no partition up stairs above the dwelling house. There shall be two cellar windows consisting of 2 panes in each 12 by 24 glass. The walls under the school house and dwelling house to be beam filled up to the floor.

There shall be proper thimbles put through the ceiling of house for stove pipes, also one in the partition over the school room and an opening made for stove pipe through the chimney above the school room. And a thimble through the ceiling of school room.

The windows of the building shall all be constructed so that the upper sashes can be lowered for ventilation.

IN THE MATTER OF the erection of a Schoolhouse on the Sabiskong Indian Reserve.

I, Robert Kee of the Town of Rat Portage in the District of Rainy River in the Province of Ontario, Carpenter, DO SOLEMNLY DECLARE:

1. Under the contract made by me for the erection of a school house on the Sabiskong Indian Reserve No. 35, it was agreed that the joints should be all logs for the lower floor, hewed on one side only. That the rafters should be of straight poles, flatted on two sides. That the Indians would get out the logs for the joists and the poles for the said roof, cutting them on their Reserve under permission given by the Indian Commissioner, on the 4th day of January, A.D. 1899, and that I would have to pay for same merely laborer's wages to the Indians engaged in the work.

2. It was also understood and guaranteed to me that the Indians would perform the labor and get out the stone ready for the wall and would also dig the cellar on their being paid by me laborer's wages for their work.

3. Subsequently after conveying all the other materials for the said building to the Reserve by steamer, the Indians absolutely refused to perform any of the above labor and also to permit me to cut any logs, poles or other lumber on the Reserve, and in consequence of this refusal I was compelled to make an extra trip to Rat Portage and bring from there sawn lumber for the joints and rafters to be used in place of those provided for as above and by the contract. This lumber cost me the sum of $35.00. Fifteen dollars more than the amount I would have been compelled to pay the Indians for the joists and rafters. It also cost me the sum of $5.00 dollars in addition for freight from Rat Portage to the Reserve.

4. In consequence of the refusal of the Indians to perform any work, I was compelled to use the skilled labor which I had
with me to get out the stone for the stone work and to make the excavation for the cellar. This skilled labor cost me the sum of $30.50... Dollars more than I would have been compelled to pay had I been able to employ the Indians at laborer's wages.

5. It was also agreed that the Indians would assist in all work which could be performed by ordinary laborers and for which I was to pay laborer's wages, but, in consequence of their refusal I was compelled to use skilled workmen who were the only men available, who did all the laborer's work in connection with the said building, and on this account I was compelled to pay out the sum of $30.50... Dollars more than would have been paid by me had the Indians performed the laborer's work as agreed.

6. Attached hereto is a statement shewing how the above amounts are computed and shewing that the sum of $30.50... Dollars is due to me in consequence of the failure of the Indians to carry out their agreement as per the contract entered into.

AND I make this solemn declaration conscientiously believing it to be true and knowing that it is of the same force and effect as if made under oath under and by virtue of the "Canada Evidence Act, 1893".

Dear Sir,

The Indians of Cape Lake, in the territory under the Metis agency, last summer built and equipped a nice little school house, under the impression that the Department would give them the customary grant of $100.00, as is given to all other reserves. At the payment of 1874, they were led to believe that this grant would be given, and last summer while the payments were being made, they were encouraged to go on and complete the school both by the Indian Agent and myself. So far, I learn, that all measures to get the Department to sanction this grant have been fruitless. I respectfully point out to you the fact that the Indians on this Reserve are very much dissatisfied at the treatment they have received, and naturally ask why the Department takes exception in their case. They have been making great efforts to improve their condition, and the school house they have built, though small, deserves great credit, and I feel that the Department should give them encouragement by approving what they have done. They ask that an appropriation be made for the school house and a teacher. The money to complete the building was advanced by a local trader who lives among them, who can ill afford to lose it. I beg respectfully to ask to know whether you can do in the matter! And remain

Sincerely yours,

Rev: Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th instant applying on behalf of the Indians of Maple Lake for a grant of $100 to complete the schoolhouse on their Reserve and also for a salary for a teacher; and in reply I beg to say that it is regretted that the Department was not first communicated with before any expenditure was incurred in connection with the erection of a school house, as were it disposed to sanction the establishment of a school on the Reserve, provision would have to be made in the Estimates and the money voted by Parliament for the purpose before any authority could be given. Sir,

I have just been informed that it appears Mr. McKenzie (Indian Agent) has written to Ottawa to have me dismissed from the Eagle Lake Day School, as teacher, for unnecessarily interfering in matters here not connected with my duties. And in reply to the charge against me, I am at a loss to recollect anything I did which Mr. McKenzie does not approve of. I have always done what I thought was for the good of the Band; and this, not without Mr. McKenzie's knowledge. And I have letters in my possession to show he approves of what I do.

And I might say, I caused a good deal of disturbance in my efforts to put a stop to drinking and gambling whose habits were indulged in to a disgraceful extent by the Indians. And as a consequence of my efforts the Indians did their utmost to have me dismissed when the Indian Agent was here to pay treaty, on Aug. 6th last. But the charges against me were of such a nature that the Indian Agent told the Indians he saw nothing in what they said, to be able to comply to their wishes.

The man who worked against me the bitterest came to me the following day to apologize for trying to have me dismissed. And the councillor wanted me to write to the Agent for him to tell him to have me kept on.

So when Mr. McKenzie says the Indians wish to have me dismissed, he is stating what is forgotten.

I wish the Indian Department would know the particulars of the way the drinking and gambling were carried on. I told the Agent the particulars. But I do not think the information ever went further than his office.

I have always been careful to do nothing over the Agent's head; but if necessary I shall give you the detail information direct, to show what the state of things were.

At present there is very little drinking and no gambling that I am aware of, for some time. But before I did anything the same used to gamble openly and the drunks walk right into my house whenever they felt like it (and this was pretty often) while they had liquor in them. I reported this and more to the Agent; but it seems he finds it very difficult to do anything.

In conclusion I wish to say, before the Department should do anything to have me dismissed I would like them to know what I might have to say for myself in defense.

Kindly forward this to the Indian Department, Ottawa, soon as possible.

Hope to hear what you think of the above said.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

We, the undersigned settlers of Eagle River District, beg to draw your attention to the fact that the Indian School at Eagle Lake being closed at the end of last term, without any other whatever. If the school be reopened, there is a prospect of good attendance (and we sincerely hope that is so).

The school is the only civilizing influence the Indians have, and the only thing that keeps them together on the Reserve; and if it remain closed, they will wander idly about, and be a great nuisance to the settlers.

There is another matter besides the closing of the school that we wish to bring to your notice, and that is, that there is some person or persons here selling liquor to the Indians, and under the influence of it, they are gambling, quarrelling, and worse.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

On the return from the Eagle Lake day school for the December quarter, last, the Commissioner writes, "this school is giving but poor returns and I am ordering its being closed forthwith". The average attendance for that quarter was 2.5 and for the whole year was only 3.7 and for the year previous, 1906, it was 4.3. The falling off in the attendance was sufficient reason for closing the school.

This school was previously closed from July 1, 1903 to December 30, 1905, for the same reason. The Agent in reporting on this school gives the number of children of school age as 16, but the teacher has never succeeded in having a better attendance than above mentioned.

Mr. Fox, the teacher, from the correspondence on file does not appear to be popular with the majority of the Indians and a petition for his dismissal reached the Department only yesterday, while a counter-petition for his retention was sent in by the white settlers in the district. Mr. Fox has been very active in the suppression of the liquor traffic and gambling, which no doubt accounts for his unpopularity with them. He is well spoken of by the Church of England Bishop of the
the diocese and the white settlers, but the fact remains that for the three years he has had charge of this school he has failed to secure an attendance that would justify the Department in continuing him in charge.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Mr. James Fox has written eleven pages of foolscap to the Minister in reference to the notice he received through the Agent at the instance of the Commissioner to the effect that his engagement as teacher at the Eagle Lake school would close at the end of the March quarter.

The correspondence on file shows that there was no other course open to the Commissioner than to dispense with his services, as the attendance at the school was going from bad to worse ever since he took charge. In January, 1905, when appointed to this school, there was an enrolment of 16, with an average of 8, which dwindled down to 2-3.

Mr. Inspector Simmons in his report on this school, dated Feb. 28, 1908, said that he proceeded to Eagle Lake and found the school closed for about two weeks, because the Indians would not send their children while Mr. Fox was in charge. He endeavored to arrive at the reasons for the falling off in attendance but was satisfied of one thing, which was made clear to him, that Mr. Fox's usefulness at this place was gone for the present. The Indians were decided on their position that
they would not send their children while Mr. Fox was in charge. The Inspector did not like the boycott, which appears like giving in to a dissatisfied and quarrelsome lot of Indians. On the other hand he states that Mr. Fox has manifested a spirit of fight which does not recommend him. He appears to be bad-tempered, suspicious and vindictive and his zeal is not so much in the interests of sobriety as it appears to be at the first glance.

Mr. Fox was not summarily dismissed. He received a month's notice that his services would be no longer required and the Department approved of the Commissioner's action.

Mr. Fox's letter above referred to gives no good reasons why his services should be retained. It is full of excuses, denials and charges against the Agent, which, I understand, have been enquired into.

Eagle River Reserve.

Education.

There are eleven children of school age in this reserve, but no teacher has as yet been appointed to take charge of the school erected last fall by the Rev. Mr. Prover. The building is a small one 16 x 16, covered with shingles and built of logs, good floor and ceiling, four windows of good size, two doors, three long benches, a table, box stove, no open fire place, a stair for the attic which is lighted by one small window. The lot is well enclosed with a good fence, there is a little garden in front of the building planted with different kinds of small seeds. The Indians seem anxious to have their children educated.

Sir,

I beg to address you concerning the school on the Indian Reservation of Eagle Lake. We have been wishing to have a Teacher here for some time and as our former Agent told us whenever we had a school house built, the Government would supply us a teacher, I immediately set to work when I was elected councillor and put up a building as we were anxious to have our children taught. The house has been finished some time now and ready for occupation but no teacher has been supplied so I hope you will remedy this as soon as possible.

Dear Sir,

Will you be kind enough to use your powerful M.P. influence in my behalf in a small matter?

This is how it is: - Indians travelling are allowed travelling expenses "to a point, but not from a point." (Quotation from an official document.) And this travelling allowance is not paid until two years have passed from date of appointment. Now the authorities have ordered this school to be closed to June next; therefore I cannot put in two years. And moreover the appointment has been of so short duration that before I have cleared myself of expenses incurred in journeying here and in the purchase of a little clothing, I am ordered to move on. Add to this that Grassy Narrows is an outrageously expensive place to live in, and you will easily understand why what a hole I have tumbled. Under the circumstances I think I am justly entitled to my travelling expenses, both to and from Grassy Narrows, and as the whole amount for both journeys is under £25 I hope you will see your way to providing my claims.

I have just had a terrible winter. The house is unfinished; rain and wind come in at their own sweet will; the C.R.R. lost half.
my blankets for a while and I did not get them until January 18th! The Indians would do anything without being heavily paid for it. They ought to honestly feed guests, but these creatures refuse to bring in a diet without being given something - I have had to give them several biscuits and the agent tells me I shall have a fine for these - that comes in about once in two months, eight or ten Weekly To in a bundle - many thanks for your kindness in sending them, and the delicate way you sent the gift, I refer to the Govt. in the printed address. I felt half inclined to be a Govt. but I knew my own was not much valued by the Govt. I have reported one Indian for threatening me, trying to persuade my head and using loud (? abominable) language - I hope the authorities will take up the matter. Indians go frequently to Rat Portage, but they don't bother their heads about any mail. Supplies (goods) sent from Wis. were two months at Rat P. - and I the while living on bread and water.

I shall therefore, will carry the $10 - I owe them $2 back $6 - when he has drawn my pay for quarter ending March 31st. The Indians &c could not be this opportunity - I forget to tell Mr. Smith about the $10 - please send him the money immediately - about 3 weeks after you receive this - All good wishes, &c. assure a long letter - Wishing you & the families all prosperity, &c. remains, Yours faithfully,

In reference to the letter addressed to you by Mr Edward V. Lys, teacher of the Indian school at Grassi Narrows near Rat Portage relative to a claim which he makes for travelling allowance, I have the honor to inform you that Mr Lys' quotation from an official document would not apply to his case as a travelling allowance is only to be made to teachers engaged by the Department from Ontario or other Eastern Provinces under written agreement and after two years satisfactory service, so that even if Mr Lys were to remain on for two years and give satisfaction, he would not, under the regulation above referred to be entitled to any allowance for travelling expenses. I may add that notwithstanding the hardships and disadvantages teachers in such unsettled districts have to contend with, such officers are easily obtained.

of Indian Affairs:
Sir,

Referring to your letter, No. 147619, to Mr. Richardson, dated April 28th, 1897 (in my travelling expenses), allow me to say that I made the claim I did because I considered myself perfectly justified to make it. Some seven or eight years ago I was appointed teacher to the Black River Indian School, and my travelling expenses to that Reserve were paid without a protest. But I was not allowed return expenses, so my appointment to this place was annulled at the end of eight months or so by the closing of the school, & I imagined that I was entitled not only to my travelling expenses to Gracey Narrows but also from it. Touching biscuits, the Indians would not supply me with fuel unless I gave them something for the trouble; having nothing else to give, I gave them biscuits.

With regard to your plan aimed at Indian School teachers, I think I am not far wrong in stating that all government offices, from that of Premier down to scavengers and Indian School teachers, could be easily filled, and probably at less cost to the country. The rush for Indian School teachers proves the deplorable condition of Canada.

If you really take an interest in the welfare of the Indians, you will surely pardon me for giving you the results of a four-years' experience of Indian Schools. I shall make my remarks as brief as possible.

I consider the plan of giving biscuits to the children pernicious. The Indians are thankless.
the white man is greatly benefited by the children going to school. Over and over again have parents come to me, begging for pork, flour or tea, and added, to soften my heart, that they would send their children to school regularly, if I would but accede to their request. If biscuits be given at all I think they ought to be bestowed upon those pupils who not only regularly attend, but work while in school.

There ought to be some kind of pressure brought upon the parents to compel them to send their children to school. As it now is it rests largely with the youngsters themselves whether they will attend or not. Some years ago I suggested to the Department that an aged couple should be paid to take charge of the children while their parents were away on hunting trips or other excursions; and the youngsters not allowed to join these expeditions. I received a hint for my zeal; and I expect a repetition of it in reply to this.

The books and lesson cards are utterly unsuited for Indian children; they take no interest whatever in them. Fancy explaining to an unintelligent Indian child, who knows nothing whatever of civilized life, such words as maps, cell, try the ot to get bed, full of the day, &c., &c. The youngsters take no interest whatever in the cards. But when I place before them a picture representing bears, wolves, canoes, and other creatures and things with which they are familiar, they become quite lively and chatter away as if they enjoyed the lesson. Then I can induce them to speak English.

The final question is a burning nuisance to the teacher; the Indians won't supply wood unless they are paid for it. Why could it not be insisted upon that if 40 cords of wood be not piled up near the school by the time the agent comes round to pay the twenty months' rent money would not be paid till next year? If this were made law, and the agent was firm in the matter, next time I came I would see for 40 cords of wood, the Indians would soon be brought to the point where they would be willing to pay.

Honorable Sir:

We the undersigned, Indians of Grassy Narrows, humbly beg to make application again for a Day School, and to have our old school rebuilt, also to provide accommodations for a resident teacher.

Priests and ministers are always welcome in our midst, but as the majority of our band is catholic we think it proper to have the said Day School under the Roman Catholic Denomination, as much as the Roman Catholic authorities have just started with our complete agreement, a mission on our reserve.

This new establishment of a Roman Catholic mission on our reserve will be, we believe so, quite a help to us for an attendance to the school more satisfactory than in the past.

The Indian Department should understand on the other hand, the circumstances in which we are. Some of our people are obliged to leave in winter for a considerable time to provide for their living, the crossing of the English River also under unfavorable weather, is quite an obstacle for our small children, in the summer, to attend regularly to school. But we understand more today the benefit of the education, and promise a more regular attendance and to do our best in the future.

We are determined as in the past to fight against ministers and priests proposals, of sending our children far to any boarding school. Hoping that our request will be granted and we will have a favorable answer.

We beg to remain, Honorable Sir,

Sir:

I beg to report having made an inspection of the Kenora Agency now in charge of Mr. R.S. McKenzie and to offer the following information in connection therewith:

**Key Schools**

I found that the schools were not in a very satisfactory condition and that both interest in them and attendance of pupils were far below the desired standard.

At Islington the school is closed owing to the illness of the teacher Mr. C.N. Chapman who has been for some time in the general hospital at Kenora and who says that the Bishop is likely to discontinue his efforts there.

In my opinion a lot of money and energy was wasted in trying to keep these schools open and I favour the enlargement of the boarding school work but have no definite suggestion to offer without further study of the question.

My dear Sir,

I have to thank you for your letter of the 6th inst.

Mr. Eley went down to Islington on the 19th inst. and would begin his work at once. We have not yet heard from him.

Re travelling expenses. It seems to me rather hard. We cannot get men on the spot, and if they have to come from a distance we can hardly expect them to pay their own expenses. Mr. Eley's expenses from Toronto were nearly $30, and he had to remain here for ten days because there was no chance of getting down to Islington; this cost him at least $15, the same or nearly so will have to be found for his return, thus it will cost nearly $100. We cannot let him pay this, but if we are to get men into the schools the Diocese of Neewatin cannot afford to pay this, and unless the Department is willing to pay it in future we must refuse to engage men.

Mr. Aldous has said nothing about his expenses but it must have cost him fully $50, possibly more to get in to Lac Seul.

Believe me

Ottawa, February 3rd, 1910.

Right Reverend Sir,

The Department regrets very much that Your Lordship's letter of November 22nd, last, in reference to day schools at Lac Seul and Islington was inadvertently overlooked.

The Department is fully cognizant of the existing conditions on these reserves and appreciates the difficulty of conducting permanent day schools. Your Lordship's suggestion that teachers be sent in to these two points to work among the Indians during the summer months meets with approval, and, if it is possible to secure the services of energetic, interested young men or women, there is no doubt that much good can be accomplished.

It is realized that summer schools are not and cannot be as efficient in respect to class-room work as those conducted throughout the whole year, but on these reserves an enthusiastic teacher would find much scope for his or her efforts among the Indians themselves. In fact, the Department would be disposed under present conditions to lay more stress upon this feature than upon the class-room work.

The Department would like to see effected some improvement in the method of living among these people. Something might be done towards improving sanitary conditions and inculcating habits of cleanliness; and if, in

Right Rev. J. Lofthouse, D.D.,
Bishop of Keewatin,
Renfrew, Ont.
addition to this, instruction in plain cooking and the home treatment of common ailments could be given, the benefit to the Indians would be of inestimable value. The Department in suggesting this line of work is speaking in the light of recent experience. On one reserve in Saskatchewan a trained nurse and qualified teacher was placed in charge in September last, of a school conducted under the auspices of the Church of England, and, in the short time that has elapsed, the results achieved have even exceeded the expectations of the Department. This is not an isolated case. On other reserves in the west and in British Columbia splendid success along these lines is being met with. The Department is of opinion that if Your Lordship could obtain the services of nurses who would be willing to undertake this and the school work for a few months during the summer that the interests of the Indians would be better served than by the appointment of male students, whose attention would be given principally to the school work. To such persons the Department would be willing to pay salaries of $50.00 a month.

However, if not found practicable to carry out this suggestion, the Department will be glad to have you nominate two student workers, who will be paid at the rate of $500.00 per year. In this event very much will depend upon the character of those engaged. Perfunctory service will not be productive of the desired results, but Your Lordship's varied experience in Indian work and knowledge of the necessary requirements will enable you to make fitting selections.

The Department will be glad to hear from Your Lordship at an early date in regard to the proposition above stated.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your Lordship's obedient servant

My dear Sir,

I have to thank you for your letter of Feb 3rd Re schools at Lac Seul and Islington.

I am most anxious to see a general improvement amongst our Indians but the conditions in this section of the country are so entirely different to Saskatchewan and British Columbia that we simply cannot follow their plans or expect the same results. We could not, in fact I would not send a nurse to either Lac Seul or Islington, unless we had a man whose wife was a nurse, and unless the Dept was prepared to spend $1000 over a house etc for them as well as pay them $1000 a year Salary.

I am willing to assist the Dept to the full extent of my power, but at the same time I am also sure that nothing but Boarding schools will ever do any real and lasting good on the Reserves in this District.

I have the offer of a man for Lac Seul, a Mr F. Aldous, he was for some fifteen months at the St Paul's Mission, Macleod, is a capable teacher, and strongly recommended by the Rev G.B. Gale. He would I think do good work.

1st. Will the Dept appoint him? at $500 a year.

2nd What can be done about fixing up the school, getting school materials etc. There has been no school at Lac Seul for years, and I do not know in what state the school is or even if it is fit to use.

Dear Sir,

I thank you for yours of the 9th inst re appointment of the Rev L.C. Banks as school teacher at Lac Seul.

I think and trust that Mr. Banks will be able to keep on this school during the Winter, but it is a difficult matter as the school is across the Lake from the Mission, and not at all easy to get to. Am writing to Mr. Banks on this matter.

May I be allowed to say that I am very anxious about this place. The Indian Agent here informs me there are over 100 children on this Reserve of school age, and that the only way of getting them into a school is by building a Boarding school. The Department have promised this for the past three years, but nothing has been done.

There is certainly more need for a Boarding school at this place than any other Indian Mission I know in the whole country. The Roman Catholics have Boarding schools on Reserves with less than half the numbers of Indians, and are seeking to get some of our children.
We are very anxious to see the school at Lac Seul restarted, and there is very great need for it, there being a very large number of Indians on this Reserve. It may be a difficult thing to get the children together for the Indians are going much further away in their hunting than formerly, but think we may be able to get a fair average.

The Rev F. Eley is now Missionary at Lac Seul, and doing very good work, he is quite willing to try the school if the Dept. will reopen it. I have therefore much pleasure in recommending his appointment at the usual Salary of $500. a year.

There would need to be a complete outfit sent into Lac Seul Desks etc., as there is nothing whatever there for the school, except bare walls. It would also be well to ask the Agent to insist upon the Indians providing firewood for the school as otherwise it would be impossible to carry it on in the Winter.

I remain

Sir,

Enclosed please find copy of a letter received from Rev. Canon Lofthouse which speaks for itself.

I consider a School is needed very badly at Lac School as the children from that and other adjoining Reserves do not get any education, and the Indians will not send their children to the Shoal Lake or Kenora School owing to the distance, and the fact that these Indians never come to Kenora.

I know Mr Sanderson, who is the best person that could be got for the position, he has the confidence of both the Indians and the White people.

We would have preferred a Boarding School, but the Canon says funds will not run to it yet, however he says there are enough children who will be able to attend the School to make it a good proposition.

There were two schools on the Reserve, but one was pulled down last winter getting rotten and the other is in very much the same state, but there is a building on the Mission property which no doubt Mr Sanderson intends using.
I do not know the procedure in these cases, and so ask your advice as to what information you require in this connection.

Canon Lefthouse has written me a personal note asking that I use my influence to get as good a grant as possible for the School work at Lac Seul, and he thinks they should get a grant of not less than $600.

As regards the supplies he presumes these would be sent direct.

I have no hesitation in recommending that something be done if possible for these Indians as I have lived amongst them and know their needs so well.

I have the honour to be,

Specifications for Schoolhouse to be erected on Wabigoon Reserve.

Dimensions. Frame Building 20 ft. x 24 ft. with porch attached 6 x 8 ft.

Foundation. Cedar Posts 8 in. at small end, set 6 ft. apart, 4 ft long sunk 3 ft into ground.

Sills. Tamarac or Norway Pine 8x8 halved at corners dovetailed where necessary with one mud sill running through centre.

Joists. 2x10, 2 ft centres thoroughly nailed to sills.

Studs. 2x4, 2 ft centres placed on sills, 10 ft clear from floor to top of plate, double at corners, doors and window jams.

Wall plates. Double 2x4 double stuff.

Rafters. Rafters and diagonal collar beams 2x6. Rafters and collar beams for porch 2x4, collar beams placed 9 in above door.

Roof. 1 in. rough boarding, 1 layer tarred felt paper lapped 3 inches, R.C. Shingles 5 inches to weather, mounted with 4 inch ridge board.

Walls. Outside 1 inch rough boarding, 1 layer tarred felt paper, 3 in lap covered with drop siding inside lined with beaded ceiling (both to be dry lumber)

Flooring. 1 inch rough lumber covered with one inch match flooring. Platform 1 inch Match flooring, supported on 2 x 6 and 2 ft centres.

Doors. Porch 6 ft 8, 2x8 wide by 1 3/8, 4 panel, main door 8 ft 10 in by 1 1/2, hung with 3. 4 in butts, each with strong plain lock, plain casings and facings of dry pine.

Windows. 4 double windows plated 2 in each side of building 14x25 glass 1 3/8 in sash with casings and facings.

Steps. Steps to porch door 2x9 resting on cedar logs.

Chimney. Commenced on a support 7 1/2 ft. from floor rising 4 1/2 feet from top of roof, 9x9 flue, of well burnt brick, support firmly spiked to wall and framed.

Painting. Two coats inside and out of approved colors, except roof.

The whole work to be done in a thorough workmanlike manner, with good material and subject to the inspection and approval of the Indian Agent or other officer who may be deputed for the purpose.

Sir:-

In reply to your letter of the 22nd Instant. No.117760/5.

Reference to the eight desks in the Wabigoon reserve School house.

I beg leave to say that the only thing could be done with the desks would be to have them taken over to the Hudsons Bay Coy at Dinorwic and store them there until they would be required, but as this would cost considerable as I would have to send down a man to have them brought over and stored, and then pay storage on them I am of opinion, it would be more than the desks are worth, I think they will be perfectly safe where they are until next treaty payments when they could be brought over without much cost, However I will be guided by your instructions.

With regards to the stove and pipes, as the stove was well used up and broken, also the pipes, I gave the Chief permission to take them and make use of them for his own benefit.

With regards to the school building, may say it is fairly good only that the foundation has rotted away, and would require to have a new foundation put in to make it safe and good, but if this school is not likely to be made use of in the near future, I would beg leave to recommend that it be given over to the Chief, or otherwise a new foundation put in and kept for a paying house.

Dear Sir,

Because of the war there is a shortage of funds. Our Bishop feels it necessary to close this School. He has asked me to go to Wapusta, taking the three Indian children with me.

Dr. Donald would like to give his consent, but thinks you may object. They come from St. John's. Their father Wolf has several wives, from 26 to 30 children. These children are by different mothers, and two of them with their mother were cast off to starve. St. John's mother died when he was 2 yrs old. How the child lived through the severe winter which followed is a mystery. He was only clothed with an old shirt and one small blanket tucked under his arm. He crawled into camp at night. I just picked up his living. He was found by some surveyors wandering about. I was taken by them to the Hudson Bay Co. who sent him down to the Mission here. I have had him 3½ years. I look upon him as belonging to me. I have clothed him, taught him, done everything I feel towards him as a Mother. The other child who was deserted is a little older. I have had her 1½ years. She was not quite in such a pitiful
state as the boy. There is no one to lay claim to them. Their father said, "I don't want them; I have thrown them away." The third child is an older girl. When her mother died, she was given to an old crippled woman, but was sent by the Police down here, for she was neglected. These children have no mother or relative except a father who has deserted them.

I want you to give consent for me to take them to Wapusk, the two younger ones anyway, for they have no one but me. I am greatly attached to them, & will feel it deeply if they are taken from me. They were given to me. Other children have been taken from one mission & placed in another, passing over two missions, because the one who took them felt the same as I do. They were left in her charge? There have been given to me.

Mr. Laird knows me & he knows the children. Will you consent? I am anxiously awaiting your consent. Will you either telegraph it or send by letter as soon as possible, before the children are sent elsewhere.

The Bishop has asked me to go in December. I would like to get your permission as soon as possible, so that I may be able to pack. Trusting to get a favorable reply.

Yours sincerely,

(Miss) L. Miller

Feb 4th 1896

At a meeting of all the male members of this reserve they all wished the government would keep their children on this reserve and give them proper schooling. They don't want them to be sent away as they love their little ones dearly. They would like to see them get education in the English language & to live with like the English with whom they are surrounded and with whom they have to deal with every day. The Indians brought me the enclosed petition and are very anxious that their children should be educated on the reserve in a boarding school & not be sent away some to Red River some to Regina &c &c. OTTAWA 11th February 1906

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant enclosing a petition from the Oak River Sioux Indians for the establishment of a Boarding School on their Reserve; and in reply I beg to say that the Department has no funds at its disposal for the establishment of a Boarding School in this locality, even if it were thought advisable to do so.

The Day school on this Reserve which has been in operation up to the end of December Quarter last, has had such an unsatisfactory attendance as to quite discourage the Department. If the Indians are as anxious for the education of their children as their petition would lead one to suppose they should not object to letting them go to either Bighorn or Regina, where they would receive far greater advantages than at a Boarding School, supposing one were established on their Reserve.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I have just now finished a long trip through my missions of Lake Athabasca, Fort de la K Fitzgerald, Fort McKay & Fort Mc Murray. I was glad to see the Indians around Lake Athabasca in good health and prosperous, but as you have learned already, the Indians of Fort McKay & Fort Mc Murray have been struck by the terrible Spanish influenza last winter and I was very much grieved to see too many poor children left without father or mother and the others who are not orphans are deprived of all means of learning. Therefore, come to you with earnest prayer that you may help me in the work I feel in duty bound to undertake. You know that all these Indians, Chipewyans and Cree are Catholic, there is a boarding school at Fort Chipewyan but it is so far away more than 200 miles distant from Fort Mc Murray and already full. I believe that something ought to be done and I ask you to be allowed to open a boarding school at Fort Mc Murray for 25 children. If you give me some hope, I would try to put up some building where Sisters of Charity would take care of the most destitute among the children, not this year of course, but before the end of next year.

I have the honour to be, Dear Sir,

Respectfully yours,
E. Edward Scott, Superintendent Indian Affairs

Right Reverend Sir,

I have given careful consideration to your letter with regard to the matter of the establishment of a boarding school at Fort McMurray in view of the large number of Indian children who are left as orphans owing to the epidemic of influenza. As you are doubtless aware, it is the policy of the Government to exercise the greatest economy in incurring expenditures of this character at the present time in view of existing conditions. It is recognized, however, that this case is of an urgent and unusual nature and it is accordingly proposed that it should receive special consideration.

If you were to erect a suitable building, I think that we should be able to arrange provision for a per capita grant on the same basis as that paid at the other boarding schools in the north. It must be definitely understood, however, that the Government is not at any time to be involved in any expenditure other than the per capita grant in connection with this proposed school, that is to say twenty-five pupils at $145 per capita.

Sir:

As it is reported that the Government is being asked for assistance towards establishing an Indian Boarding School at this place, to be under the management of the Grey Nuns, I would respectfully recommend that, should such be the case, the matter should receive favourable consideration.

For the past two years the Willow Lake Band, who have some twenty-three children of school age, has asked for a Day School, but knowing that, owing to the nomadic habits of the Indians and other reasons, it would not meet requirements, I have not favourably reported on the matter. It is regretted however that these children should not grow up in complete ignorance. If an Indian Boarding School was built and maintained here, these and others could be trained for the competitive struggle of life. There are also a number of other children at the Pembina Reserve and also at Fort McKay who are similarly situated. I have no doubt that the proposed school would be full to its utmost capacity from the beginning.

As there is likely to be some development here in the near future it would appear to be expedient that there should be an institution where the Indian children could be fed, trained and clothed, as well as protected from the allurements of a frontier town.

INDIAN DAY SCHOOL REGULATIONS

All Indian schools shall be kept open for not less than 360 days in each year.

School shall be opened after the summer holidays on September 1st, unless this date should fall on a Labour Day, and shall close for Christmas holidays on December 22nd.

The winter term will commence on January 3rd, and end on June 30th in each year.

The following holidays will be allowed during the year—All Saturdays, Labor Day, all King's Birthday, Good Friday, Easter Monday, the remainder of the week following Easter Monday.

In addition to the above, the Roman Catholic Schools will be allowed as holidays a limited number of holy days of obligation, and travelling time in all which will be accounted as teaching days and for which payment of salary will be allowed, but no change is to be made without the consent of the Department.

Wherever the interest of the school, such action may be desirable, the holidays allowed during the summer term may be extended to include the period between the school year, but no change is to be made without the consent of the Department.

The morning session shall be from 9 a.m. to 12 noon, and the afternoon session from 1 p.m. to 6 p.m., with a recess during each session of not less than 15 and not more than 30 minutes.

Salaries of Teachers will be paid at the rate of $100 per month in each School year.

Salaries will be paid at the end of each quarter upon receipt of reports showing the school has been opened during one month in the quarter ending September 30th (unless special permission has been given), and the monthly payment for the quarter will be for one month only. During the months of July and August, the regular salary will be paid at the end of the quarter.

Summer holidays are not taken into account in payment of yearly salaries. Each school will pay for the period taught in the manner above, and the yearly salary allowed, provided the school has been granted for a change in the holiday period.

All teachers will be required to give at least one month's notice of their intention to resign.

All questions relating to the day school should be referred to the local Indian Agent.

These Indians have never received treaty or any assistance from the Government excepting medical treatment. They are further very anxious that their children should receive an education though they have a strong aversion to sending them to the Industrial schools as some of the parents have sent their children to Industrial schools and the death rate has been heavy, some of the families having had several children die and they attribute this heavy mortality to the close confinement.

To overcome this the Indians wish to have a Day School on their reservation and the children will live at home and attend school in the daytime.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the above date and number dealing with the matter of locating the Moose Jaw Sioux on the Reserve that was set aside for them in the Wood Mountain Country.

With regard to the matter of establishing a day school, I do not think that one could be successfully operated under the conditions that will exist at this place. The Indians are likely to settle at distances from one another, and the question of getting a teacher and finding accommodation will be difficult. I do not think there will be sufficient children to keep a school in operation and in view of this I think every effort should be made to place these children in Industrial or Boarding Schools. In speaking to these Indians a few weeks ago on the subject of sending their children to school, I was told that they had written to the Department, through Mr. Grayson, and pending a reply they were not prepared to do anything in the matter.

M. Graham, Inspector of Indian Agencies, and I have to quote his report as follows:—

"With regard to the matter of establishing a day school, I do not think that one could be successfully operated under the conditions that will exist at this place. The Indians are likely to settle at distances from one another, and the question of getting a teacher and finding accommodation will be difficult. I do not think there will be sufficient children to keep a school in operation and in view of this I think every effort should be made to place these children in industrial or boarding schools. My Dear Mr. Scott,

I have a letter from J. H. Thompson of Wood Mountain with reference to the possibility of a Day School being established on the Reservation there. The Indians there are very much averse to sending their children to an Industrial School as their experience of 15 years ago in that regard was a very unfortunate one. Many of the children they sent at that time under compulsion never got home. They are very desirous of having a Day school established on the Reserve with an efficient teacher. There are some 14 to 20 children of school age whose parents promise attendance. To establish a School at that point will tend to keep these people on the Reserve during the summer with the exception of the men who go out to work in the harvest fields. I wrote in my report of June 1912, regarding this matter but have had no communication from you as to whether there is a possibility of acceding to the demands of these Indians. I will be glad if this matter is taken up at an early date and notification sent me.

Yours with regards,

Dear Mr. Campbell -

I have your communication of the 16th instant in reference to the establishment of a day school on the Wood Mountain Reserve. This is a matter which had been previously given consideration by the Department, and in 1913 it was decided that owing to the comparatively small number of children of school age and the location of the families the success of a day school was doubtful.

I would like to know if these Indians are now permanently located, and if so, what distance they could be from a school centrally located. Supposing there are from 14 to 20 children of school age on the Reserve it is doubtful if the attendance that could be secured would justify the Department in making the outlay necessary to provide a suitable building, etc.

I would be quite favourable to giving a day school a trial if there is any building that might be

Glen Campbell, Esq.,
Chief Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.
used temporarily for the purpose and if it could be possible to secure the services of a teacher and a suitable lodging place.

I should be pleased to hear from you further in regard to this matter at your convenience.

Dear Sir:

Re Indian Residential School,
Cranbrook, B.C.

In my report dated August 22nd, 1941, of the Machinery at the above School, I now wish to report that the same arrangement as last year is still in operation, but I was informed that the Petter Engine has been overhauled and is now in good condition. Also that there has been some hanger Bearings and new pulley sent out to the School, but no new shafting.

No doubt when all the materials arrive the plant will be put in proper condition. Undoubtedly the present labour and market conditions have caused a delay in getting the work done, but it should be put in proper and safe condition as soon as possible.

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

I have for acknowledgment your letter of August 31, in which you request that a cheque for $48.00 be sent to Mr. T. J. Arnall, for travelling expenses incurred.

In April 1, 1944, a cheque for $150.00 was sent to Mr. Arnall. This was a standing advance for travelling expenses in connection with the inspection of boilers at Indian residential schools in British Columbia.

This Department has been instructed by the Treasury Board to eliminate all standing advances not required and to reduce the advance where the expenditure does not justify the amount advanced.

During the fiscal year 1943-44 the total travelling expenses incurred by Mr. Arnall amounted to $90.80. It has been decided, therefore, to reduce the amount advanced to $75.00 and to change it from the category of a standing advance to a special advance, to be accounted for when the inspection service is completed.

As Mr. Arnall's expense account enclosed with your letter of June 30, 1944, amounted to $42.00, there is still a balance of $108.00 for which he should account.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Having reference to your letter of the 21st instant
with regard to expense account in favour of T.J. Arnall,
S.P.P. Engineer of this Department, I beg to advise
you that the amount of the advance, namely - $75.00 -
recommended by the Treasury Board is not of any value
to Mr. Arnall as Boiler Inspector.

Granted that last year his expense accounts were small,
but this was because travelling conditions were such
that it was impossible to make reservations, and a
large number of the boilers were not inspected.

Mr. Arnall has already spent practically $150.00 this
year on trips he has made and he still has to go to
LeJac and Alert Bay.

Also, the work at the Coqualeetza School will have to be
inspected at least twice before it is completed.

Unless the travelling advance is given these inspections
cannot be made.

Then, if any of the schools need an inspection during the
winter in cases of emergency, Mr. Arnall is expected to
make a trip and submit a report. Here again unless he
has sufficient travelling advance he cannot make the
inspections.

A great deal of your work is done in conjunction with
that of this Department and the minimum amount is charged
to your Department.

"C. F. Dawson"

The present system of allowing condensate from Laundry
to enter this boiler the year round, and burning rubbish
in firebox, has caused the sterilized water to practically
ruin the tubes and plates of this boiler. The boiler should
be dried and all condensate taken off and air allowed to cir-
culate through during the non-filling season. The condensate
from Laundry boiler; either returned to the laundry boiler, or
wasted to sewer. The present method has been in use for several
years and the new engineer is not to blame for the condition of

While the foregoing does not approve of half-breed children, whose parents do not live upon reserves as Indians, being admitted to the schools, yet it takes into consideration the fact that there are circumstances under which in all justice half-breed children should be admitted to such institutions; and I have quoted therefrom in order that you may have the full facts before you, and also as I consider the ruling in question strengthens my view of the case.

I have been accustomed to deal with cases of this nature upon grounds of humanity and expediency, rather than rules or regulations laid down by law, written or unwritten. It seems to me that this case is one which should be so dealt with. I therefore recommend that these children be taken into Treaty, placed upon the pay-list, and accepted as grant earners at the Kenora School.
