Sir:

In his first report on Indian Schools, dated 1st June, 1910, the Superintendent of Indian Education states:

"Not only do our schools every day removing intelligent Indian children from evil surroundings, but they are very often ministering to a class which would be outcasts without such aid; refer to the illegitimate offspring of white men and Indian women who are thrown upon their mothers for support, and who have no legal status as Indians. This great charitable work, which parallels the efforts put forth by white communities aided by Provincial, Municipal, or private endowment, must be carried on by the Dominion Government, aided by Christian missionaries and missionary societies."

That statement appearing in a report of a high official, in a report publically published and circulated by the Indian Department, I take to indicate a reversal of the policy recent when it was written, of excluding such children as the Superintendent refers to from Indian Industrial and Boarding schools, for I know not of any other agencies through which the Dominion Government can provide for the education and ethical training of those unfortunates.

I was greatly pleased when I read the statement, and
flattered at finding it so much in accord with the views which I hold on the subject and which I have taken frequent occasion to impress upon the Department. But I am equally disappointed at finding that the practice of the Department has not yet come fully up to the Superintendent's view. Perhaps the Principals, who were so emphatically made aware of the Department's determination to keep Indian schools exclusively for Indians of legal status, are waiting for more direct advice of the reversal of policy, while the Department may be waiting for the Principals to move in Half-breed cases before taking particular action in accordance with the Superintendent's view.

It, therefore, occurs to me to suggest that a circular be sent to Principals of Indian schools, embodying the view of the Superintendent as summarized in the statement I have quoted, and requesting the Principals to send a detailed report each as to the Half-breed children in the schools on whose behalf the per capita grant has been refused, or who have been admitted without consulting the Department, so that the sound policy expressed in the Superintendent's statement may be put into full and effective operation without further inevitable delay.

I find the following Half-breed children at this institution:

Lizzie Muskrat and Lillie George, the illegitimate offspring of a Half-breed woman leading the Indian, who some years ago abandoned the children on the Blood Reserve and left the country. They were taken into the Catholic Boarding School on the Blood Reserve and cared for by the Sisters until...
they were transferred some six or seven years ago to this institution and placed under the care of the Sisters here.

Albert and Sylvester Helcourt, born of Half-breed parents following the Indian mode of life in the Lac Ste. Anne country, and unable to so bring up the children as to make them useful members of the community.

Napoleon, Joseph, Agnes and Louise McCullis, children of Halfbreed parents. The mother is dead. The father is old and somewhat infirm; is occasionally able to work, but has a hard enough time to support himself.

Mary and Agnes Hall, from Medicine Hat. The mother was a Half-breed woman named Brasseau. She is dead. The father's whereabouts is unknown.

Albertine McKay, a Half-breed, whose both parents are dead. The mother, Mathilda Bishop, was a regularly authorized pupil of this institution.

I submit these cases for consideration by the Department as to whether they do not form part of the "great charitable work", referred to by the Superintendent of Indian Education, and which, he states, "must be carried on by the Dominion Government, aided by Christian Missionaries."

It might, of course, be argued that the statement's scope is confined to the illegitimate offspring of Indian women of legal status. But such a narrow and technical interpretation would defeat the object of a policy designed to save from becoming outcasts and menaces to society children of mixed blood for whose proper upbringing there are no other agencies than our Indian Schools. The policy as I interpret it
was given a measure of effect to when Inspector Graham, acting under Departmental instructions, gathered at Medicine Hat and placed in this institution a number of non-annuitant children of mixed blood. I can see no difference between these children and those I have mentioned. They are plainly of mixed blood; indeed in one in particular the white blood has allowed of no external evidences of red. There can be no objection to Principals of Schools being allowed to do what the Department had Inspector Graham do, and I shall be glad to hear that the wise policy referred to is not to be confined in its operation to what was done through him.

There is a case in Lethbridge to which it seems to me the policy should apply. Louise Rabaska, an ex-pupil of this School, and, I understand a treaty Indian, married one Godin, a Halfbreed. He is in the Penitentiary. There are three children, I am told, of school age. The mother is unable to provide for their education and proper upbringing. They are in the way of degradation. I would suggest that the Principal be authorized to take these children into the School.

I should be pleased to be advised of the Department's attitude towards the position taken in this communication.

Sir:

On my return from the farther west about a week ago I found awaiting me, among other letters, yours of the 17th ult., in reply to mine of the 30th September, last, in which, in advocating the admission to Indian schools of the children of half-breeds leading the Indian mode of life in accordance with the former policy of the Department - a policy which I regard as having been wisely designed in the public interest -, I drew attention to the inconsistency between the views in that respect expressed in the Report of the Superintendent of Indian Education, published in the Department's last appearing Blue Book, and the present practice of the Department.

I note your statement that what I "quote from the Superintendent of Indian Education's Report, published in the Annual Report of this Department for the year ended 31st March, 1910, was written before a variation of the former policy was decided upon".

If you will refer to the Superintendent's Report, you will find that it is dated "June 1, 1910". On reference to the pamphlet entitled "Correspondence and Agreement relating to the Maintenance and Management of Indian Boarding Schools", you will find that there is printed therein a letter, dated November 25th, 1910, covering "memorandum and draft contract", which are stated to be "the result of a conference held in Ottawa on November 8th". And I was given to understand that at that conference a similar draft contract was submitted for consideration.

Now, allowing a reasonable time for the gestation of the scheme embodied in the contract, its conception comes so
close to the time of the writing of the Superintendent's Report that I thought it was warranted in reading the contract in the light which that Report seemed to me to shed upon the Department's educational policy. I am sorry I was mistaken. And my sorrow is the greater in that I had so rejoiced at an official expression of what I took to be a policy, and a policy so in accord with the view I hold and have frequently pressed upon the Department since it departed, some considerable time before the framing of the said contract, from the practice of admitting to Indian schools as grant earners children of Half-breeds leading the Indian mode of life.

It is all very well to say, as you say in your letter, that "it is the duty of the Provincial Governments to provide education for Half-breeds"; but it is well known that there are no Provincial institutions in which the same can be provided, and that our Indian residential schools are the only existing agencies for the proper up-bringing of the unfortunate class of children referred to in my letter of the 30th September, last, and in other communications.

There are many people of mixed blood in treaty, who have in consequence the legal status of Indians; and there are Indians, as well as Half-breeds, not in treaty. I presume that it would not be thought of excluding from Indian schools the children of Indians not in treaty. But it is not easy to distinguish between natives of wholly Indian blood and those who have an admixture of white. Why, then, draw so hard and fast a line excluding all Half-breed children? It certainly seems arbitrary; and the ordinary observer, at least, cannot understand it.

The Government of the Dominion never took the position that it had no obligations at all as to Half-breeds. It recognized them as possessing, in a degree, an aboriginal title to the land of this country, and took measures to extinguish it. In other ways and at different times it helped these people. And having once given their children the right of entry as regular pupils of Indian residential schools it is hard to now debar them.

It is particularly hard, nay, it is unjust to exclude from these schools the illegitimate offspring of Indian women. There is no more unfortunate class in the country. In various
reports and letters have brought several such cases to the attention of the Department. What is to keep them from becoming outcasts and menaces to society if they be not taken into Indian schools - schools established and maintained, be it remembered, not for the mere purpose of fulfilling the conditions of Indian treaties, but in the interest of the commonwealth. The Indian Act, under which the department itself exists, presupposes membership in Indian Bands for such children.

Section 12 enacts as follows:

"Any illegitimate child may, unless he has, with the consent of the band whereof the father or mother of such child is a member, shared in the distribution moneys of such band for a period exceeding two years, be, at any time excluded from the membership thereof by the Superintendent General".

It follows from that that the illegitimate child of an Indian woman who has membership in a band is ipso facto a member of the band to which the mother belongs, and can only be removed from membership in such band by the Superintendent General, if he sees fit to exercise the power conferred upon him by the law; and that, if the child has participated for over two years, with the consent of the band (and acquiescence would, I contend, constitute consent within the meaning of the provision), in the moneys of the band, then there is no authority under the law for his removal from membership.

I submit that the illegitimate children of Indian women should be recognized as having membership in the band to which the mother belongs, unless the Superintendent General exercises his right to exclude him within the period aforesaid, which exclusion cannot be by way of a general order excluding all such children from band membership, but must be by specific order in each case; and that every such child not so excluded is entitled to all the benefits of band membership, including Indian educational privileges.

The proper course, and I assume that both the Rev. Father Hugonnard and Mr. McKenna were well aware of this, was to have reported the proposal to discharge the pupils, to the Department for ratification and to forward the application for admission, instead of this the discharge of 64 pupils and the admission of 66 apparently took place at the same time, before notification to the Department.

If Mr. McKenna's contention that
Inspector Graham has taken Half-breed children when he knew or ought to have known such to be the case, is to be further considered, then Inspector Graham should be called upon to explain, although he is very emphatic in his report that he took none but Indians.

The question is once more raised as to whether the Department of Indian Affairs should provide educational facilities for Half-breed children. Legally the Half-breed is a white person, and the education of the whites belongs to the province, not to the Dominion. This is the law: how far should an exception be made?

In 1899 the matter came before the Hon. Mr. Sifton, then Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, who gave a ruling, a full copy of which I herewith attach and from which I quote, "A well defined line can be drawn between 'Half-breeds properly speaking, and Indians. While I do not consider that the children of the Half-breeds proper of Manitoba and the Territories should be admitted into Indian schools and paid for by the Department I am decidedly of the opinion that all children even those of mixed blood, whether legitimate or not, who live upon an Indian Reserve and whose parents on either side, live as Indians upon a Reserve, even if they are not annuitants, should be eligible for admission to the schools."

The Hon. Mr. Sifton in his ruling confines himself to those of mixed blood living as Indians upon a reserve.
and throughout the whole of his ruling he does not go beyond that.

In 1910 a Conference was held with the various churches interested in Indian education, and as a result of this Conference it was decided amongst other things that the Boarding schools should enter into an agreement with the Government relative to the conduct of the school, and one of the clauses of the agreement is as follows:-

"Section (4) -(b) That no Half-breed child shall be admitted to the said school unless Indian children cannot be obtained to complete the number authorized by Article I, Sec. 1, and Sec. 4 (a) of this agreement, in which event the Superintendent General may in his discretion permit the admission of any Half-breed child; but the Superintendent General will not pay any grant for any such Half-breed pupil provided under Article II, Sec. 1, of this agreement, nor any part of the cost of its maintenance or education whatever." This agreement, of course, does not apply in terms to Industrial Schools, but on the 26th January, 1911 following the principle laid down with reference to Boarding Schools, a letter was sent to the principals of all the Industrial Schools imposing on them a similar condition as to the admission of Half-breeds. A copy of the letter is herewith enclosed. I may say in this connection that the same churches are interested in the control of Industrial as well as of Boarding Schools.
Educational institutions established and maintained by the Indian Department are certainly for the Indians, and if the door is opened to allow the admission of a section of the population legally classified as whites, and who in no other way are sharers in the work of the Indian Department, to make use of these schools, when their education belongs to an entirely different jurisdiction, we are face to face with a pretty large and serious problem. The wholesale admission of the 66 Half-breeds to one Indian school is an indication of how extensively this work may be carried on if allowed to apply to the 19 industrial schools and the 54 Boarding schools. Furthermore it is not shown that the province has not included these Half-breeds as forming part of the population for whose education provincial funds are provided, and so far as the Department is aware, these Half-breeds are shown in the Census returns as whites.

Frank Padley

Sir,—
The Department desires to emphasize a very important feature of the work of Indian Agents, viz., their duties respecting Boarding and Industrial Schools, especially their attitude towards recruiting for these institutions.

On many of the reserves the Indians show a disinclination to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the residential schools to obtain an education for their children. The Department has endeavoured, and it is believed with considerable success, to raise the standard of these schools, not only as regards the class-room work, but also the buildings, sanitary conditions and equipment. Notwithstanding this, the apathy of the parents is in many cases apparent, and there are some schools which are not able to obtain their quota of pupils.

It is considered that the active influence of Indian Agents and other officers of the Department would, to a large extent, overcome this indifference. As you know, the Department has power under Sections 9 and 10 of the Regulations relating to the Education of Indian Children (a copy of which is inclosed herewith) to place in these schools children who are not being properly cared for or educated, and you are specially directed to bring all such cases, if any, in your agency, to the attention of the Department, in order that Sections 9 and 10 of the Regulations may be enforced, if, in the opinion of the Department, such action is deemed necessary. In dealing with cases of this class, you should make a separate report on each case, giving full particulars as to the names, condition, and religion of the parents or guardian, also band to which they belong, age, sex, physical condition and band number of the child to be dealt with; and also state whether the child has attended school previously or not.

You will be required to give this matter your careful and sympathetic attention and at once confer with the Principals of the Boarding and Industrial Schools who may recruit in your agency, with a view to co-operating with them and lending them every assistance in your power. When recruiting, orphan children and children neglected by their parents should have the preference.

In order that these instructions may be given effect to, you should, at the end of each quarter, submit a list of the children of school age in your agency not attending school, with explanation as to the cause of their absence.

As you are aware, Boarding Schools are now operated by the different religious bodies under contract, and a copy of this contract is inclosed herewith in order that Agents may familiarize themselves with it. The Department desires that Agents shall visit and thoroughly inspect Boarding Schools, and Industrial, if any, within their jurisdiction at least once every three months. The inspection should include all the various features of the work as referred to in the contract. In addition to these inspections entailing extended reports, the Department will require monthly visits, if practicable, in order that any matters needing immediate attention may be dealt with. Short reports should be made after each of these visits.

I shall be glad to have an acknowledgment of this letter.

Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Referring again to my letter written to you recently regarding the half-breed children who have been admitted to our Indian schools throughout the Province, I beg to say that a short time ago a representative of the Soldiers Settlement Board was visiting Cowessess Indian Reserve, and reported that there were Indian children not attending school in a certain house, where a man was drawing a pension. However, the Agent tells me these children are admitted to the Cowessess school with your authority, and should have been in attendance.

In Cowessess school, there are at the present time nine non-Treaty children, and two more have gone forward for approval. At File Hills I have not admitted one non-Treaty child in the school, and there are other schools throughout the country that are carrying out the Department's wish with regard to admitting Indian children only. But, I am afraid the privilege granted has again been abused, and we are practically in the same position now as we were seven or eight years ago, by having our schools over-run by non-Treaty Indians.

Another matter I would like to have a ruling on—Once these children are admitted, have we jurisdiction over them? Can non-Treaty parents take out their children from school and decide when to send them back? I regret exceedingly that these children are in school. At one time, we had a good clean-up, and it was an easy matter to have kept the schools freed from children, who, in my opinion, have no right to be there.

Sir,

The Department directs your attention to the necessity of the most careful examination of application forms in favour of Indian children who are presented for admission to residential schools. I have, therefore, to invite your attention to, and compliance with, the subjoined facts and instructions.

On the "Application for Admission" form the agent signs the following declaration: "I hereby approve of the admission of the above child and certify that he is eligible to be admitted as a grant-earning pupil."

There is a departmental ruling to the effect that half-breed children living the Indian mode of life on a reserve are eligible for admission to the boarding and industrial schools, or, more fully: "While it was not considered that the children of half-breeds proper of Manitoba and the Prairie Provinces should be admitted into Indian schools and paid for by the Department, it was conceded that all children, even those of mixed blood, whether legitimate or not who live upon an Indian reserve and whose parents on either side live as Indians, even if they are not annuitants, should be eligible for admission to the schools. Houses, however, must be guarded against and every application for admission should be accompanied by satisfactory evidence that the applicant is a half-breed to whom the rule applies, and not a person who has been adopted by or otherwise brought into association with Indians with the express purpose of gaining admission to our schools."

At the time you forward an application, write a covering letter in the case of half-breed or non-Treaty children, giving your reasons for believing the child to be a charge on the Indian Department.

When you have reason to believe that the accommodation of the boarding or industrial school is limited, preference should be given to orphan children or those that are neglected by their parents.

Exercise every care to ensure the placing of the child in a residential school under the auspices of the religious denomination to which the parents adhere. No Roman Catholic child shall be sent to a Protestant school, and vice versa. You will please adhere strictly to this provision of the Act. (See Section 10 of the Indian Act). Concerning the ages of applicants for admission to our residential schools, only in very exceptional cases will the Department authorize the admission of any child other than between the ages of 7 and 13 inclusive.

Check carefully all applications that come before you, paying particular attention to the age, religion and status of the applicant before asking the Department to admit them as grant-earning pupils to a Boarding or industrial school.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Abuses, however, must be guarded against and every application for admission should be accompanied by satisfactory evidence that the applicant is a half-breed to whom the rule applies, and not a person who has been adopted by or otherwise brought into association with Indians with the express purpose of gaining admission to our schools.

Concerning the age of applicants for admission to our residential schools, only in very exceptional cases will the Department authorize the admission of any child other than between the ages of 7 and 15 inclusive.

Check carefully all applications that come before you, giving particular attention to the age, religion and status of the applicant before asking the Department to admit them as grant-earning pupils to a boarding or industrial school.

Sir,— I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of Nov. 9th ultimo with reference to "the admission of children to Residential Schools."

In this Agency, we have a number of "illegitimate" children, and it is difficult to distinguish the difference between half-breeds and Indian children, in many cases. In fact, if we judge by appearance, many of the children are half-breeds; but the "legal" parents are Indians. A few of the Indians leave their legal husbands and wives, and live with other Indians, and, in some cases, with whites. We take care, in keeping whites from residing on Indian reserves, and will not allow privileges to children of persons married (Indian women) to whites.

We have but one residential school available, for our Indians, at Coqualeetsza Institute, many hundreds of miles removed from the Agency, on the mainland of B.C. It is under the auspices of the Methodist Church, while the Massette, the large Band, are all Anglicans. We sent seven children to Coqualeetsza Institute, recently, and making arrangements to send six more. No Anglican Residential school open for these children, and none of the Massette attended any Anglican school, in recent years, for the reason that no such school is available.

No Roman Catholic children in this Agency; hence no question regarding the religion of the pupils.

The principle of Coqualeetsza Industrial Institute requires that children shall be twelve years of age, or under that age; this precludes many, although some have been taken, over twelve years of age.

Fifty more children would attend a residential school in this neighbourhood, or in the vicinity. Many parents object to sending their children so many hundreds of miles from home. If the education of the Indian children is sought, the Day School, attended only a few months in the year, will not assist very much, in the education of the Indian children, growing up and increasing in numbers.

Children, returning from far-away schools, appear foreign to the surroundings here, and are not making good members of the community. In fact, they are the worst element we have.

Duncan C. Scott Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
It may be possible, that we expect too much from the Indian returning from a residential school; but results show for themselves. We are aware that the residential school, attended by our Indians, is conducted in the best manner possible, by earnest workers; but the young men and women come home, with ideas and ideals at variance with those of their parents, and consider themselves charges on their people, instead of getting out, and making homes for themselves. They revert back, to the old customs and habits of their forefathers, instead of progressing further, morally, socially and intellectually.

I have always carefully looked into the status of those sent to Coqualeetza Industrial Institute, and will comply with the instructions contained in your communication. The younger children are more interested in obtaining the fruits of education than ever before; unfortunately they are taken away, to canneries and fishing camps, during the Spring and Summer. If we could place all of the children in Boarding Schools, the year round, they would all be on a level, and good results would follow.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

To Inspectors, Indian Agents,
and Principals of Residential Schools:

The Principals of Residential Schools, when writing to the Department, have referred on more than one occasion to a departmental regulation by the terms of which certain half-breed children were eligible for enrolment at residential schools, provided their parents were residents of Indian reserves and living the Indian mode of life.

This regulation is dated Ottawa, October 18, 1899, and is signed by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs. The purpose for which the regulation was enacted at that time is clearly set forth in the regulation itself. The last paragraph reads:

"The North West Government cannot provide for the education of non-annuitants upon reserves; and if we exclude them from our schools they will practically be debarred from all means of education."

You will readily appreciate, therefore, that this regulation was passed at a time when the provincial governments and the government of the North West Territories were not in a position to provide educational facilities for the children of certain half-breed residents in the outlying sections of the Dominion.

The terms of this regulation have been carefully reviewed by the departmental officials, who have felt for a number of years that the regulation itself should be drastically modified or repealed.

It is difficult to determine exactly the rate at which the Indian school population is increasing, but it is estimated that the Department is called upon to provide for
an annual increase of between two and three hundred pupils at our Indian day and residential schools.

There has never been, nor is there now, any statutory obligation upon the Dominion Government to provide educational facilities for half-breed children. The Government is, however, wholly responsible for the education of Indian children as defined by the Indian Act. Half-breed children are definitely the responsibility of the provincial governments, and it is our opinion that these governments are now in a position to establish schools for the education and welfare of these children.

In view of all the circumstances, it has been decided to repeal the regulation of October 18, 1939, and to inform the principals of Indian residential schools that, in the future, per capita grants will be made only in the case of Indian children of paternal descent. In the case of children about whom there may be a dispute, such cases and the claims of such children should be submitted to the Department through the local Indian agent and a departmental decision obtained before such children are permitted to enter our institutions.

This decision will not apply to students enrolled at residential schools prior to the first of September, 1937.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Dear Sir,

In re-reading Circular #150-9 of Dec. 10th, 1937 regarding repeal of the regulation permitting entrance of half-breed children to Indian Residential Schools, several points occurred to me upon which I am not clear, but not related to the subject matter of the Circular itself, which is, of course, perfectly clear.

1. Legally, what constitutes a "half-breed" in British Columbia?

2. Section 26 of the Indian Act defines an Indian as "any person of Indian blood reputed to belong to a particular Band" and subsection "b" of the same Section defines a "Band" as one interested in Reserve Land, and therefore Annuitants. Of course, eugenically speaking most Annuitants are half-breeds but are called "Treaty Indians". But am I correct in assuming that the Indian Act affects only "Treaty Indians" in British Columbia?

3. Is a half-breed, not a Treaty Indian, entitled legally to a Liquor Permit on an equal footing with a white man, even though that half-breed is living the Indian mode of life and trapping a trapline in the midst of Indian traplines and spends his time with those Indians? The application being that certain half-breeds, or rather non-treaty Indians are able to get in liquor under legal liquor Permits from the Gov't Control Liquor stores and this liquor is taken to the trapping grounds where all adjacent Treaty Indians have access to it.

It is to be borne in mind that these Indians do not live on Reserves but on more or less remote traplines.

Dear Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant with reference to Indians and half-breeds in British Columbia.

As you are aware the Indian Affairs Branch is responsible only for the welfare of Indians as defined by the Indian Act. The Indian Act defines an Indian as:

"(1) any male person of Indian blood reputed to belong to a particular band,
(2) any child of such person,
(3) any woman who is or was lawfully married to such person."

Persons of Indian blood transmitted through the female line are not considered Indians and are usually referred to as half-breeds. In the Province of British Columbia they would have the same status as other white residents of the province and be entitled to the same privileges.

With regard to your inquiry in connection with "scrip", I have to advise you that when the Indian Treaties were being made the half-breeds were given the option of being recognized as Indians and admitted to Treaty, or of being considered whites. If they elected not to take Treaty they were entitled to scrip as recompense for their interest in the land being surrendered. Scrip was issued to all half-breeds making application, and about the year 1905, the class comprising those who were born between 1876 and 1885 were dealt with.

The issue of scrip was discontinued in 1911, the last group being provided for were those residing in the Mackenzie River district in the Northwest Territories.

The Indian Act does not cover the question of half-breeds.

Yours very truly,

INDIAN SCHOOLS

The following are notes from an interview with Mr. P. N. L. Phelan of the Indian Affairs Branch, in reference to Indian schools:

There are about 270 day schools, a few of which are seasonal only, and about 80 residential schools, all supported by the Dominion Government. They are scattered throughout the Provinces, the Northwest Territories and Yukon Territory.

The schools are operated by Mission authorities - Roman Catholic, Anglican, United, Continuing Presbyterian.

The Government grants are along the following lines:

Day Schools

(a) Erection and maintenance of schools with necessary equipment, repairs, fuel, etc.
(b) Payment of teachers' salaries.

Residential Schools

(a) Erection and maintenance of schools with necessary equipment, repairs, fuel, etc.
(b) Per capita grant based on pupils in attendance. This varies from $155 to $170 generally, but ranges to $200 in certain isolated areas, and to $250 in the Yukon Territory.

Teachers

The teachers are required to have first or second class certificates issued by the Provinces. They are selected to conform with the religious views of the Indian communities where the schools are located. The majority of the day school teachers are appointed by the Department but in a few instances the church authorities are permitted to make selection. About 20 or 25 of the teachers are Indians. In the residential schools the churches engage the staff.
Inspection

The schools are inspected regularly, usually once a year, in the case of New Brunswick and Nova Scotia twice a year. In New Brunswick and British Columbia there are Departmental inspectors, but in the other Provinces inspection is made by Provincial school officers, the Department paying for their services.

There are also inspections by Indian agents and inspectors who report on the condition of the buildings and equipment, meals, clothing, dormitories, and any other features bearing on the physical condition of the children.

Correspondence Schools

There is very little training received by the Indian children through correspondence school courses. These courses depend largely for their success on the assistance given by parents or guardians, and the Indians are not generally qualified to give this assistance. The courses may be used, however, by Indian students seeking advanced education beyond the capacity of the Indian schools.

Curriculum

As the teachers provided have received the training required for Provincial schools, the curriculum of the Indian schools naturally conforms reasonably close with the curriculum of the public schools. In some instances the Department supplies a somewhat simpler form suitable for the Indian pupils.

Manual Training

Except in the case of the Indian schools in British Columbia where there is a special grant for manual training, the practical training of this kind is limited to the immediate resources of the schools. Manual training involves the providing of equipment and frequently special teachers, and it is not the practice of the Indian Affairs Branch to make any extensive provision for this purpose.
where it is practicable to do so the Indian boys are taught the principles of animal husbandry, general farming, or any other occupations for which training equipment is available. The girls also receive a certain amount of training in cooking, sewing and suchlike occupations.

The day schools are not considered very suitable for manual training, the children being there only a few hours a day and engaged in other studies. The residential schools, however, are well adapted for the purpose.

Memorandum for Northwest Territories Council

Educational facilities in the Northwest Territories.

The schools in the Northwest Territories are operated by the Anglican and Roman Catholic Missions, assisted by Government grants. There are seventeen day schools and four residential schools listed in the records. Those in the Mackenzie District are located at Fort Smith, Resolution, Hay River, Providence, Simpson, Norman, McPherson and Aklavit. Those in the Keswatin and Franklin Districts are at Cambridge Bay, Coppermine, Baker Lake, Chesterfield, Eskimo Point, Lake Harbour, Pangnirtung and Pond Inlet. Some of the day schools do not operate continuously.

The Government grants for the day schools range up to $500 annually, and at Fort Smith and Simpson payment of $680 is made through the Indian Affairs Branch toward the teacher's salary. The grants to residential schools are $400 each with an additional allowance based on the number of pupils. This allowance is either $130 or $200 per annum for each child according to location. The Government also incurs some additional expense for equipment and supplies.

The policy of the administration in regard to schools in the Northwest Territories conforms with the policy in respect of Indian schools generally, in so far as their operation by the Missions assisted by Government grants is concerned. The amounts of the grants vary according to location or other conditions.

The standard of education can hardly be considered as high in the schools throughout the Northwest Territories as in the Indian schools generally. Except at Fort Smith there is no rule requiring the Missions to employ only teachers having previous qualifications as is done in the case of the Indian schools. Most of the teachers in the Northwest Territories are the missionaries stationed at the various points. In the Indian day schools most of the teachers are appointed by the Department but in the Northwest Territories the matter is left to the Missions.

A further difference noted between schools in the Northwest Territories and Indian schools in the provinces is that the latter are inspected regularly by school inspectors. These are concerned with the educational features of the establishments as distinct from the general welfare of the pupils which is reported on separately by the Indian Agents. In the Northwest Territories the administration does not make any regular inspections of the schools from an educational standpoint.

Owing to the large area of the Northwest Territories and the distances between the points where the schools are located the educational facilities provided by the Mission schools are not fully adequate to the requirements of the population. In a few instances the residents have taken advantage of the opportunity to provide education for their children through correspondence school courses supplied by the Department of Education, Alberta.

There is considerable interest shown by the resident population in correspondence school courses, and this means of providing education for children living at some distance from established schools, or who through disability are unable to attend...
such schools, might be developed to much larger proportions. With this end in view inquiries were recently made at the offices of the provincial Departments of Education, at Regina and Edmonton, and some material collected bearing on the subject of correspondence school work.

There has been furnished a copy of the Annual Report of the Department of Education of the Province of Saskatchewan, 1936, showing that public school courses are supplied free of charge to children whose homes are not situated in school districts and also to children who because of ill-health or other disability are not able to attend the local rural school. The lessons may also be supplied to adults whose education has been neglected, and who now wish to work on the public school course. While the report refers mainly to Saskatchewan, it is understood from the Director of these courses that the Dominion Government might reasonably ask that the service be extended to children residing in the area north of Saskatchewan, provided it could be shown that Alberta was educating children in the area north of Alberta who had no other way of obtaining education. Enrollment forms and other details were provided.

Information along the same lines has been obtained from Edmonton, and includes also sample copies of the lessons provided in Grades I to VIII in the correspondence course. There are fifteen pupils in the Northwest Territories already enrolled and further applications are being considered.

From the information supplied it is apparent that there is considerable benefit to be derived from the study of educational material available in these correspondence courses provided by the provinces of Saskatchewan and Alberta, although a great deal of the progress of students depends on the assistance they receive from their parents or guardians in carrying out the instructions given by mail. Except for private tuition, the only means available for the education of children beyond the capacity of the mission schools is the higher grades included in the correspondence school courses.

It seems desirable to explore any avenues which might lead to improvement in the general situation as regards educational facilities in the Northwest Territories. The Government outlay in supporting the Mission schools represents a considerable contribution toward education and it is doubtful if this could be materially increased. It is, however, possible that improvements may be effected without incurring any considerable additional expense.

The recommendations made in this respect are as follows:

(a) That steps be taken to secure and disseminate through the Northwest Territories as much information as possible concerning correspondence school courses available in the provinces bordering on the Northwest Territories which are or might be extended to include residents of the Territories.
(b) That full information be obtained in regard to the subjects taught in the mission schools and where considered necessary the Missions be urged to include considerable manual training in the curriculum. In the case of native boys this might include first aid, practical training on engines and motors of all kinds available; making and mending boats, nets, dog harness, sleighs and snow-shoes; and the tanning of hides. The girls could learn first aid, cooking and serving meals, child welfare, sanitation, dressmaking, tanning of hides, and the manufacture of skin clothing.

(c) That arrangements be made for an inspection at least once a year of the schools in the Northwest Territories by a school inspector with qualifications equivalent to those required in the provinces, the inspector to be authorized to examine closely the degree of education provided, submit suggestions for improvement and report the progress made by the pupils in each institution year by year.

There has been furnished a copy of the Annual Report of the Department of Education of the Province of Saskatchewan, 1936, showing that public school courses are supplied free of charge to children whose homes are not situated in school districts and also to children who because of ill-health or other disability are not able to attend the local rural school. The lessons may also be supplied to adults whose education has been neglected, and who now wish to work on the public school course. While the report refers mainly to Saskatchewan, it is understood from the Director of these courses that the Dominion Government might reasonably ask that the service be extended to children residing in the area north of Saskatchewan, provided it could be shown that Alberta was educating children in the area north of Alberta who had no other way of obtaining education. Enrollment forms and other details were provided.

Information along the same lines has been obtained from Edmonton, and includes also sample copies of the lessons provided in Grades I to VIII in the correspondence courses. There are fifteen pupils in the Northwest Territories already enrolled and further applications are being considered.

From the information supplied it is apparent that there is considerable benefit to be derived from the study of educational material available in these correspondence courses provided by the Provinces of Saskatchewan and Alberta, although a great deal of the progress of students depends on the assistance they receive from their parents or guardians in carrying out the instructions given by mail. Except for private tuition, the only means available for the education of children beyond the capacity of the mission schools is the higher grades included in the correspondence school courses.

It seems desirable to explore any avenues which might lead to improvement in the general situation as regards educational facilities in the Northwest Territories. The Government outlay in supporting the mission schools represents a considerable contribu-
tion toward education and it is doubtful if this could be materially increased. It is, however, possible that improvements may be effected without incurring any considerable additional expense.

The recommendations made in this respect are as follows:

(a) That steps be taken to secure and disseminate through the northwest territories as much information as possible concerning correspondence school courses available in the provinces bordering on the northwest territories which are or might be extended to include residents of the territories.

(b) That full information be obtained in regard to the subjects taught in the mission schools and the mission authorities be urged to improve the professional qualifications of their teachers, particularly where there is a demand for a higher standard of education than is now provided. It might be represented to the mission that considerable manual training should be included in the curriculum. In the case of native boys this might include first aid, practical training on engines and motors of all kinds available, making and mending boots, nets, dog harness, sleighs and snowshoes, and the tanning of hides. It might also be possible to develop the art of ivory carving. The girls could learn first aid, cooking and serving meals, child welfare, sanitation, dressmaking, tanning of hides and the manufacture of skin clothing. The art of weaving as a native handicraft might also be taught. Information in this respect can be obtained from the Guild of All Arts, Scarborough, near Toronto.

(c) That arrangements be made for an inspection every year or two of the schools in the northwest territories by a school inspector with qualifications equivalent to those required in the provinces, the inspector to be authorized to examine closely the degrees of education provided, submit suggestions for improvement and report the progress made by the pupils in each institution.

Sir,

Referring to your circular of the 12th of Jan., 1914, I have the honour to submit the following on the Ex pupils mentioned.

Joe Allan

After this boy was discharged from the school he came here to the reserve, for a short time he worked with his stepfather at the haying and harvest and worked out threshing for a while, and then he left to go back to work for the principal of the Industrial school again as he said that he wanted him he remained up among the north reserves until May of 1913 when his stepfather sent him money to bring home when he returned he was suffering from the effects of an attack of pleurisy and was not able to work, in July he married a young girl that was just out of the day school he married her on the sly and in the Indian fashion but I insisted on his marrying her properly which he did, he left here for Piapot reserve last fall and as far as I know he is there now. I tried hard to get this boy to do something useful to settle down and go to work but he said no; he did not intend to stay here any way that he was going to Montana where his father is and in any case he would not accept any help from the Dept unless that it was unconditional this of course was out of the question. I do not think that he will ever amount to anything and all he has to show for 14 years in the industrial school is that he talks English fairly well, he said that he learned a little shoemaking and a little farming while at the school but not enough about shoe making to make his living by it and I think still less about farming as far as I know about him at the present time he is well.
Mary Rose Bear

Married while still at the industrial school, Died in April 1913 of consumption.

Letitia John

Unmarried, Died at the school of consumption in Feb. 1912.

Edgar Napaystia

Has no settled place of abode is perfectly healthy, unmarried an utterly useless harmless prowling vagabond wont work for any body would starve first not any to bright mentally, says all the work he ever did at the school was a little gardening spends nearly all of his time among the reserves up north will get up and go off without saying a word to any person and will stay away for months at a time.

Austen Nahbexay

Near Carlyle, health good, unmarried working for a white farmer this man is a cross between a mighty bad negro and not any to good a squaw, for a long time after he was discharged he hung around the school and the north country he served a month in jail for being drunk and flourishing a revolver, this happened before he came here to stay after he came here he always worked at anything he could get to do for whitemen off the reserve and never missed a possible chance to get liquor, in Oct. of 1912 I sent him to Regina jail for three months for the same trouble on the reserve but since his return I have never heard the least whisper against him in any way I believe that he is keeping very straight, I have been thinking of trying to start him farming on the reserve but I hardly know how it would do as he has no relations among the Indians and is a kind of an outcast among them says he learnt some blacksmithing at the school but not enough to enable him to take a job in a blacksmith shop and do the work properly has a rather violent temper hit one of the priests at the school and laid him out.
I am very sorry that I am not able to send you a better report on those pupils but I suppose what you want is the truth there is belonging to this reserve 11 ex pupils of the different industrial schools without counting the women what have we got to show for it, it must have cost the Dept. $10,000.00 to educate them. Of them are farming 4 more of them were farming and dropped it one because he was married to an old squaw who would not let him farm another because he could not do what he liked and two because they were too lazy to look after their teams and do their work. I have ex pupils of the day school on the reserve farming who only went to school for two or three years who are doing better than any of the industrial ex pupils and are much easier to manage.

I don't want to disparage the value of the industrial schools, but I believe that the Indians best interests are to be chiefly promoted by increasing the educational facilities on the reserves. The reserve is the home of the Indian. He can be educated there more conveniently to him and with less expense to the Dept than at one of the industrial schools. The schools on the reserves contribute vastly to the amelioration of the community life there, improving moral as well as intellectual standards, and deepening the Indians sense of responsibility. They stand as constant reminders to him of his integral part in his life of the country, a living guaranty of the Departments active interest in him and its promise to do well by him. Another very potent argument in favour of the reserve school, is its greater advantage in cultivating home life.

D.C. Scott, Esq

This completes the Kenora Agency. You will note I have given you quite
a number more than you asked for, but thought it best to do so.

There are quite a number of Halfbreed children that attended both
the Kenora and Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding school, which I have not given
as I have lost track of them since they left the school.

There are also a number of pupils from other Agencies which have
been discharged, and which I have not accounted for, as they are out of
my jurisdiction. I trust this will be satisfactory.

Will send the Savanne Agency's return in a few days, as well as

Your obedient servant.

Indian Agent.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of above date and number asking for certain information regarding ex-pupils of this Agency discharged from the various residential schools during the past three years. The following is a detailed report on each pupil mentioned in your letter.

David Bird. At present residing on the File Hills Colony, is in splendid health, married in January 1913. This young man is doing very well. He has been farming only two seasons and his last crop amounts to 2056 bushels of good grain. He has 75 acres ready for crop and has bought and paid for a good team of heavy work horses. He owns a good equipment.

Jack Walker. At present working for the Minister of Agriculture where he has been engaged for a year. The training he will receive there will be of great benefit to him. I expect he will start farming on the Colony in 1915. This boy has not yet married. He is strong and healthy.

Harry Assineawasis. This man has not yet started farming. He was working out on the Government road gang most of the summer, making good wages. He is not married and is fairly healthy. I think it will be only a short time before

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
before he will want to start farming. It would be a mistake to force him to begin until he can see for himself that he can do better at it than by working out. He has a good reputation and is making good use of the training received at school.

Nora Keewaydin. This young woman has made a splendid showing for herself since leaving school. She has been acting as maid in the home of Hon. W.R. Motherwell for over a year and the reports I get from time to time are very favorable. Last Spring this young woman had an operation for appendicitis, the cost of which was largely borne by herself. She is a good girl and is savings her earnings to make a home for herself some day.

Alex Assineawasis. This man is a brother of Harry Assineawasis mentioned above. He has been working out ever since he left school and has expressed no desire to start farming. He makes a good living and is steady. He has good health.

George Lavallie. This young man is a non-treaty halfbreed educated at the File Hills School. After his discharge he went to Maple Creek where I understand he has been working steadily ever since.

Eliza Lavallie. This girl is on the staff of the File Hills Boarding school. She is a good, healthy girl and has greatly benefitted by her education.

Rebecca
Rebecca. This girl married direct from school to an uneducated Indian of Piapot Band. I can tell you nothing about her.

Celina Big Sky. Married to Adelarde Star Blanket of Star Blanket Reserve and an ex-pupil. She keeps a good house and will do better still when her husband builds a better home. She is strong and healthy.

Mary Agnes Peskutch. Married to Alan Star Blanket of Star Blanket's reserve. I hope to see her in a better home next summer. She keeps a clean house and is a good wife; does not enjoy very good health.

John Bellegarde. Since his discharge from school this boy has been assisting his father who owns a number of cattle and farms in a small way. He has been out of school only a short time but I expect he will be the means of enlarging their farming operations. He is strong and I have good reports of him. He lives on Black Bears Reserve.

Edwin Nokesis. This man is a little weak minded. I started him at farming but he did not do well. He needed almost constant watching which I could not give him. He is now at the Agency where he acts as mail carrier and does odd jobs. I fear he would get into trouble if allowed to go off the reserve. His health is good.

Arch.
Archibald Nokesia. A brother of the above and is not strong mentally. Has been working for others most of the summer. File Hills is his home.

Sarah Nokesia. Married to an uneducated Indian of Piapot reserve.

Louisa Chief Hawke. This girl is in very delicate health. I doubt very much if she will live long. She lives at File Hills with her people.

Alex Desnommes. This boy has done remarkably well. He is a hard worker and will do well as a farmer. He is at present assisting his father and breaking up a farm for himself. He has splendid health.

Adam Blackfoot. Died Feb. 28th. 1911. Tuberculosis.

Matthew Lowe. Has been farming on the Colony for two years and has done well. This year he had 767 bushels of grain, principally wheat. He broke 20 acres of new land this year and has now 52 acres under cultivation. He is married, has a neat frame cottage and one child. All enjoy good health. As a farmer he will do fairly well.

Veronique Dumont. This young woman has been out at service most of the time since her discharge from school. I understand she will shortly marry one of the young men of the Colony. She has a good record and will make a good wife.

Trusting that the above information is what you require.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Insp. of Indian Agencies.

Sir,

In compliance with your instructions, contained in your letter dated Jan. 12th, 1914, No. 150,000-14, re information respecting ex-pupils who have been discharged from the various residential schools during the past three years, I have the honour to report as follows:

Name - Maria Shanocappo (Maria McKay)
Ex-pupil Pine Creek Boarding School.

Residence - Rolling River Reserve, No.67.
Band No.68.

State of Health - Rather delicate, but no serious trouble so far.

Married or Single - Married to George Shanocappo, No. 68, Rolling River Band, No.67.

Present Occupation - Taking care of her own family and her home. Has two boys, one 1 year & 9 months old & 1 one month.

General Progress - Lived with her father Geo. McKay, No.15, Clearwater Lake reserve, No.61A. Employed at the usual work about her home. Married Geo. Shanocappo in May, 1911. She is a fairly good housekeeper. Has a sewing machine and is a good needle woman. Her home is well provided with the necessary kitchen utensils. Takes good care of her children. Her husband is a good provider and his house is a log one with shingled roof.

To

The Assistant Deputy
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Name - Jean McKay (Jean Bird) ex-pupil, Birtle Boarding school.

Residence - Clearwater Lake Reserve, No.61A.
Band, No.76.

State of Health - Excellent.

Married or Single - Married to Andrew McKay, No.76, Clearwater Lake Band, No.61A.

Present Occupation - Wandering about with her husband.

General Progress - This young woman up to the time she was married, lived with her sister, Mrs. Hunting Hawk, No.51. Preferred to live on the reserve and would not accept service as a domestic. She is inclined to go back to the Indian mode of living. Her husband Andrew McKay, is now about to be transferred to the Rolling River reserve, and is making preparations to build a good log house with shingled roof, on this reserve, which will be built by him next summer. When Jean settles down in her new home, she may show if her education and training has benefited her. Her husband is a good worker, but inclined to roam about.

Name - Donald Runner, ex-pupil Birtle Boarding school.

Residence - Rolling River Reserve, No.67. Lives with his parents.

Health - Scorfulous, but sores now healed up. At present in very good health.

Married or Single - Single.

Present Occupation - Getting out firewood & selling same Works on the farm with his father & and also works out during harvest & threshing seasons, and at other times when not needed at home.

General Progress - Since his discharge from school, has been assisting his father on the farm, having worked out during the harvest & threshing season.
seasons. His father has a small team of horses, which Donald works, but he is handicapped, in the way of not having horses or a yoke of oxen of his own and has to depend on his father for the use of his team. He is getting out logs for a house, this winter, as I understand that he is to be married next summer.

Name XXX Martha Bird (Martha Bird) ex-pupil, Birtle Boarding school.

Residence - Rolling River Reserve, No.67, Band No.8.

State of Health - Excellent.

Married or Single - Married to Peter Bird, son of No.8, Rolling River Reserve, No.67.

Present Occupation - Care of her own home.

General Progress - A very good housekeeper & needle woman. Has a swing machine and makes her own clothing. Keeps her home in excellent order. The home is nicely furnished and good care is taken of it. She had some assistance from the Department. Her husband never attended a school, but is an excellent provider and has built a log house with shingled roof and upstairs apartments. Martha is very reticent and will hardly converse with any one in English, and then in so low a tone as makes it almost impossible to carry on a conversation with her. The assistance given her has had good results.

Name -- Jared Bunn, ex-pupil Birtle Boarding school.

Residence--- Bird Tail Sioux reserve, No.57.

State of Health--- Excellent.

Married or Single - Married to Ela Ben, widow late Andrew Ben, No.38.

Present Occupation - Farms on a small scale and works out during the threshing season. Works for Indians on the reserve, hauling firewood, hay & in the care of stock.

General Progress - Rather too fond of travelling to the Sisseton Indi...
the Sisseton Agency, South Dakota. His wife owns a quarter section of land there, left her by her father the late James Enoch of that Agency, and they are trying to have the same sold. She receives a rental of $50.00 per annum, from the land, rented as a grazing lease. This land keeps Jared from settling down, as he makes frequent visits there to hurry up the sale. He had in crop the past season, 20 acres of wheat and 7 of oats and put up 10 ton's hay. Worked well for other Indians on the reserve and was fireman on the steam engine, during the threshing season on the reserve. Has no house of his own and generally stays with his uncle, Moses Bunn or his grandfather John Bunn. He has steadied down the past summer, and there is hopes of betterment in the future. I regret to say, however, that his wife died on the 5th. instant, after confinement, and the little one, a girl, after a few hours after birth.

Name - George Blackface, Birtle Boarding school.
Residence - Oak River Sioux Reserve, No.58. with his mother, who is married to Waste, No.19, same band.
State of Health - Excellent.
Married or Single - Single.
Present Occupation - Working at odd jobs for farmers in the vicinity of reserve & doing some trapping.
General Progress - General farm labourer, during seeding haying, harvest & threshing. Roams continually between Oak River Sioux, Bird Tail Sioux and the small towns, in the vicinity of these reserves. Has taken no advantage of his education or training, so far and will not settle down to steady work on his home farm.

Name - Rosie Bunn, Birtle Boarding school.
Residence - Bird Tail Sioux reserve, N.57. Keeps house
house for her father, Moses Bunn, No.25.

State of Health - Excellent.
Married or Single - Single.
Present Occupation - Housekeeper for her father and has
the care of her younger bothers and sister. Has a
good home, frame building with kitchen and upstairs
apartments. The kitchen is well furnished with all the
necessary articles for it. Rosie attends to the
poultry and feeds the pigs, when her father is away
from home, attends to the cows and makes butter for
their own use, as well as attending to her housework.
Her father is well satisfied with her and the train-
ing received at the school, has been made good use of
in her case. Has swing machine and does all the family
sewing in addition to the general housework.

Name - David Bear Bull, Birtle Boarding school.
Residence - Bird Tail Sioux reserve, No.57.
State of Health - Fairly good, inclined to be tubercular,
but seems to be throwing it off.
Married or Single - Single.
Present Occupation - Assisting Indians on the reserve
getting out firewood and looking after stock. He is
a roamer, and is not satisfied to stay in any place
longer than two or three weeks at a time, generally
less than this. Will not settle down on the reserve.
Has had several good places, with steady employment
as farm hand, in good families, but the roaming fit
takes hold of him, and he leaves without giving any
explanation to his employers. When hard up he returns
to the reserve. Resents supervision and will tell you
that he is quite able to look after himself. Those he
has worked for state that he is a good worker, and
would not wish for better on the farm, but as no re-
liance can be placed on him, he is only employed now
to fill a gap. He may settle down in the future.
Name - Cecilia Bopha, Birtle Boarding School.
Residence - Birtle, Man.
State of Health -- Excellent.
Married or Single - Single.
Present Occupation - Domestic, Home Agent Wheatley.
General Progress - This young woman is giving excellent satisfaction. She is a good bread maker and is good general servant. Seems glad to be earning her living and seems to have no wish to return to her reserve, Bird Tail Sioux, No.57. She is a good tempered girl and devotes most of her spare time to reading. She is making good use of her education and training received at the school.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,

Sir,

With reference to letter # I50,000-I4 dated Jan 12th, I have the honour to report as follows.

1.(1) Peter Ross.(2) Living at present with his Father-in-law, Jackson Myrick, on the Oak River Reserve.(3) Good.(4) Married in December 1912 to Eva Myrick of the Oak River Band.
(5) Visiting his Father-in-law.(6) This boy has only been on the Reserve about two months and he is not a member of this Band.

2.(1) Louise Wasicunna.(2) Oak River Reserve.(3) Good.(4) Married in the Anglican Church to Willie Minie(Water).(5) Housekeeping.
(6) This girl married a very good steady boy, a member of the Oak River Band. He never went to School but he has a good home for her and has money in the Bank. The Department bought her a sewing machine and she does all the sewing for her household. She seems to be a fairly good housekeeper, tidy and clean. She is teaching her husband to write and speak English. They are both members of the Anglican Church.

3.(1) Emma Demas.(2) Oak River Reserve.(3) Fairly good.(4) Married to Kenneth Eastman,(Indian Fashion).(5) Housekeeping.(6) This girl left Brandon School for holidays and instead of returning she married Kenneth Eastman. They are not getting on very well.

(4) Caroline Wasicunna.(2) Oak River Reserve.(3) Good.(4) Married to Norman Chaskie, in the Anglican Church.(5) Helping her Mother to keep house.(6) Carrie is a bright smart looking girl but she is not a very good housekeeper, she is inclined to be lazy and extravagant. She married Norman Chaskie, an Indian from Portage-la-Prairie. He helps her Father who is a Farmer.
3.(1) Ida Eastman. (2) Lives with her Father on the Oak River Reserve. (3) She left School with Tuberculosis and was under the Doctor's care here for a long time; she is almost well again now. (4) Single. (5) Nothing, living with her Father and Mother. (6) This girl has not made any progress in the right direction, her character is not by any means above reproach.

6.(1) Annie Taylor, Brandon Industrial School. (2) Oak River Reserve. (3) Good, had a touch of Tubercular glands but is better now. (4) Married on Jan 11th 1913 to Zepherin Sioux, Agency Interpreter. (5) Housekeeping for her husband and baby. (6) Annie received a sewing Machine from the Department and she makes good use of it; she is getting along well and keeps her house and Baby nice and clean.

There are several Ex-Pupils who were discharged previous to 1910 who might have made good if the old people had not kept them back. Since the others have come and are doing well they are acting as a stimulant on the older pupils and they are making an effort to amend their ways, with gratifying results.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

General remarks.

I regret to say that the surroundings in this northern country are such that these ex-pupils cannot exercise the knowledge of farming gained. They are however all doing well, being earnest and willing workers. The men hunt furs, fish, work on survey parties, and on steamboats. Their knowledge of English stands them in good stead, and they are much sought after by travellers for this reason. The girls do not make the use of English that the boys do, not having the same chance, but they are cleaner in their habits than those brought up on the reserve. The assistance given by the Department to these pupils, is always much appreciated, and well used. When lumber has been supplied it has been used to complete their dwellings, while the girls upon marriage are supplied with a little furniture, which they take pride in keeping clean and tidy.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No: 150,000-14 with a list of the ex-pupils from Industrial and Boarding Schools who were reported as having been recruited from the reserves in this Agency.

I beg to submit herewith a report on all those enumerated on your list of whom I have knowledge.

Colin McNab No: 94 George Gordon Band.

This ex-pupil is residing on Gordon's reserve; he is married to Hattie Wasabadiwa, an ex-pupil of Elkhorn Industrial School; they have one child.

They appear to be healthy and have taken up farming as an occupation.

Colin's unmarried brother makes his home with him; between them they are making their living. They have 41 acres of land cultivated and appear to be ambitious but are rather hampered in their progress through lack of the means of obtaining proper equipment. This will be overcome I hope in time and they should do well.

Charles C Pratt No: 5 Gordon Band.

This man is an ex-pupil of the Elkhorn and Gordon schools. He is unmarried and lives with his brother on Gordon's reserve. He has taken up

farming as an occupation, has forty acres under cultivation and may be classed as progressive. He is a bright, clean living boy, keeps himself well dressed and is a credit to his school.

Fred Cyr No: 60 Gordons Band.

This boy was transferred from Gordons Boarding school to Elkhorn, he is at present residing with his mother and is a step-son of the Touchwood Agency Interpreter, he is healthy and a good worker.

Since leaving the school he has obtained a small team of horses and makes a good deal of money by hauling wood and working out for farmers and threshermen.

Fred intends to get married during the coming summer and in that event he will make a home of his own.

Christina J Pratt, No: 59 Gordons Band.

Is married to Charles Worm of Poormans Band and has one child. She is a clean, tidy house-keeper and deserves to be assisted.

Her husband has erected the log walls of a commodious dwelling house but has not the means to purchase the lumber to finish it with.

This woman is healthy and has been benefitted a great deal by her school training.

Paula Pawistawat, No: 43 Gordons Band.

This girl is married to Paul Simon Ochcho No: 52 of Gordons Band. She is healthy and keeps her house clean and tidy. Her husband makes their living by selling wood and working with farmers.
St. Pierre Gunville - Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

This man is not a treaty Indian but is a French Half-breed; he is unmarried has no settled home and lives amongst the half-breeds.

Joseph Thorn - Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

This man has been reported to me as dead. His father resides at File Hills.

Michael Geddes - Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

This man is not a member of Gordon's Band in this Agency.

J Adam Shetak - Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

I have no record of this ex-pupil.

Prisque Mamaquon - Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

This boy lives with his adopted father "Pierre LaCree of Star Blakete Band in the File Hills Agency" I have had no report on him.

Kate Worm - Gordon's Boarding School.

This girl is married to Andrew Morris a non-treaty half-breed and lives with him on his homestead. She has one child and is a clean and tidy housekeeper.

Emily Worm, Gordon's Boarding School.

This girl is married to David Gordon son of Chief Moses Gordon they reside on Gordon's reserve. Emily is a clean and tidy housekeeper. They live with David's father who has a roomy, storey and one half house. They always present a very respectable appearance and can be said to have benefitted by their school training. They have one child.
Luke Ewinin - Gordons Boarding School.

This boy is unmarried and lives with his father on Poormans reserve, he always dresses well and works out occasionally, but appears to be lazy and indifferent about making a home for himself.

Minnie Keahkewaypew, Gordons Boarding School.

This girl married Paul Ititahkoose of Day Stars Band before her time at school expired. She has two children. They live in a house of their own on Day Stars reserve and I am pleased to say that the house is always found in a very clean condition. The children are also well cared for.

This couple were both very young when they married and have received very little help. They deserve to be encouraged.

Their home is much superior to that of the girls parents and I have no hesitation in saying that the improvement is due to the training which she received while attending school.

Robert Keahkewaypew, Gordons Boarding School.

This boy was an incorrigible truant and was discharged before he had completed his term at the school. He is unmarried and has no settled home and does not appear to have any ambition to settle down and work.

Maude Bitternose, Gordons Boarding School.

This girl is married to Albert Cyr of Gordons reserve and lives with him, they have two children. This girl is healthy and keeps her children clean and tidy. They live with her husband's father, but Albert has got out logs to make a house for himself but so far has not had the means with which to purchase lumber to complete it.
They are a well behaved couple and deserve encouragement.

Louisa Cyr, Gordons Boarding School.

This girl married Harry Bitternose of Gordons Band and resides with her father on the reserve. They were only married last Fall and I have not been able to judge regarding her capabilities as a housekeeper but am of the opinion that she will prove to be clean and tidy.

The young man has shown a great aptitude for work since his marriage.

Joe Harry Favel, Muscovequon Boarding School.

This man is a non-treaty half-breed and does not reside on the reserve. He is single and healthy but I cannot report favorably regarding his character as he has been twice convicted for supplying intoxicants to Indians since leaving school.

This boy was a good worker at school and was very civil but the half-breed influence with which he has been brought in contact since leaving the school has been very detrimental to him.

Justine LaPierre, Muscovequons Boarding School.

This girl was bright and capable while at school but as she is a non-treaty half-breed she has returned to her parents and does not come under my supervision since her discharge.

John Green, Muscovequons Boarding School.

This boy is unmarried and lives with his mother on the reserve; he is not ambitious and I have a great deal of difficulty in keeping him steadily
at work. I have found him a disappointment and he has not carried the lessons of industry taught at the school into his life on the reserve.

Francis Desjarlais, Muscowequons Boarding School.

This man has married a daughter of the Chief of Poormans Band and resides at that reserve. He is healthy and strong and now that he is married appears to be anxious to get an equipment with which to start farming.

This man was given a yoke of oxen when he left the school but as he showed no disposition to make good use of them I took them from him and gave them in charge of another ex-pupil.

I believe that he is now worthy of being given another chance.

Sarah Green, Muscowequons Boarding School.

This girl is married to a non-treaty half-breed and resides with him on his farm, they have one child and live respectably. I have heard nothing but good reports regarding this girl since her discharge from the school.

Marie Desjarlais, Muscowequons Boarding School.

This girl is a non-treaty half-breed and resides with her parents at some distance from this District. I have not had a report regarding her since her discharge.

Charles Bruce, Muscowequons Boarding School.

This boy is unmarried and lives with his parents on the reserve, he assists his father in caring for the stock and with his farming operations.
he is fairly industrious and should do well if he were only started for himself and married.

Jean Baptiste Nesjarlais, Muscowequons Bay School.

This boy is unmarried and lives with his father on the reserve. He made a fair start at farming but is not strong and the indications are that he has consumption in an advanced stage.

Mary Tanner, Muscowequons Boarding School.

This girl resides with her husband Norbert Bruce on Muscowequons reserve. She keeps her house clean and tidy and as her husband now has a fair acreage under cultivation and is increasing his stock I am hoping that with luck they will soon make a creditable showing.

Margarite Bruce, Muscowequons Boarding School.

This girl is married to a Half-breed named Baptiste Pelletier and as he is a worthless fellow the girl has not had a chance to take advantage of her training as they have no settled home.

I believe that were she given the opportunity she would have made a good housewife.

Damehilda Denomme, Muscowequons Boarding School.

This girl is a non-treaty Half-breed and lives with her parents at some distance from the reserve. She has not come under my notice since her discharge from the school.

Larose Pinace, Muscowequons Boarding School.

This girl is unmarried and lives with her parents. She keeps their house very clean and tidy.
a condition which did not exist in that home before her return from the school.

Larose works out as a servant occasionally.

Peter Windigo, Muscowequans Boarding School.

This boy lives with his father on the reserve and contributes considerably towards the support of his parents who are both advanced in years.

He has made several applications for assistance to enable him to start farming and I believe he is worthy of being given a trial.

He is healthy and always keeps himself well dressed and tidy.
