Sir,

I have the honour to submit the information concerning ex-pupils belonging to Carry-the-kettle's band as requested by your letter dated the 12th ultimo.

William Birrel Grey was a pupil of the Regina Industrial school during part of the time that it was in operation. After this school was closed he was transferred to the Brandon Industrial school, but only remained there a short time, escaping by night and walking all the way back to his people who live on this reserve. The late agent Mr. Grant reported his return to the principal of the Brandon school but no action was taken in having him returned. This boy is fairly well educated and has proven to me to be a good worker with every prospect of making a good showing in the future. Since leaving school he has resided mostly with his father assisting him in many ways. His health is good and is still unmarried. During the past summer I gave him a yoke of oxen and harness. The breaking season was past when he received them, but he is making preparations to commence farming on his location in the early spring. I will be very much disappointed if this boy does not make good progress.
James Medicine Rope was a pupil of the Qu'Appelle Industrial school. Since leaving he has lived at home with his parents. His health was very poor when he left school but he appears to be getting stronger. He is still single and occupies his time with his father and brothers by attending to stock and farming. Sometime he may start out in life for himself.

Lena Kennedy was a pupil of the Qu'Appelle Industrial school for about three months during the year 1910 and her brother Daniel was also a pupil for the same length of time. I have made special inquiries with reference to the placing of these children in the above school from their father Daniel Kennedy who is residing on this reserve. He informs me that it was his intentions to have them educated in that school, but it appears that the head master gave his boy who was then only six years old a severe punishment which caused bodily injuries and he may be affected for life. This he strongly objected to so he brought his children home. Shortly after these two children were sent to the day school at this Agency and have attended up to the present. The health of these pupils is good. They are making good progress considering they are living five miles from school.

Samuel Whit-Cap graduated from the Qu'Appelle Industrial school a year ago last July. He is now residing on this reserve and occupies his time mostly by working for other Indians. From this source he obtains sufficient money to cloth and board himself. He is still single. His health appears to be good excepting that at times his
mind seems to be deranged and he acts very foolish. I don't think it would be wise to start this boy for a little time yet because he would not be capable of managing his own affairs, viewing it from a progressive standpoint.

Robert Medicine Grower graduated from the Qu'Appelle Industrial school in June 1912 at the age of eighteen. His health has been good since leaving school but I am sorry to say he is badly deformed. One of his legs was severely injured when he was young and has not grown as long as the other. This necessitates him using a crutch. He is still unmarried and occupies his time by working for other Indians on this reserve. It is surprising how smart and sincere he is with his work. This boy if he was not crippled he would certainly be an object lesson for some of the others. I have not made any effort to start him on his own resources as yet because I believe he would rather be working for wages until he gets over his boyish ways, but when I think he is competent then I will advise him along these lines.

PUPILS DISCHARGED FROM THE Cof E Mission School.

Lucy Welsh. This girl is married to another school boy from this school, Dick Beef Tea. They are doing well living on the reserve. The woman is a good clean housekeeper and healthy, as are their one child.

Annie White Rider. This girl is now married to Joe Ely also an ex-pupil of this school. After leaving school she went on a wild career for three months. I attribute her then dissolute life to the fact that she was married against her will and desire to an unsuitable mate. She left him served three months in female gaol; on her return to the reserve she again married; she since seems to be living a quite uneventful life but suffering from diseases contracted during her first three months out of school.

Harry White Rider. This boy is married to an uneducated Indian girl is living on the reserve. I am not able to say anything in favor of his progress, who he has never been in any mischief to my knowledge. Rather an inside sort of boy lacking the spirit to do either much good or much wrong.

Mamie Wearing Old Clothes. This girl is married on the reserve to a worthless Indian, Iron Shirt. I believe she would have been a good woman had she been given a fair chance; but the cupidity of her relatives forced her into an unwished for marriage that has brought her much injury. She is a clean healthy young woman, tidy in her dress pleasant in her manner.

Janie Neely. This young woman is married to James Gladston a half-breed graduate from the same school. She has lived in the town of Lethbridge nearly all the time since she was married where her husband is about for the Mrs Gladstone R N W M T. At present they are living on the reserve at her father's home. This young woman is one of the few instances of the second generation being educated her father being the first Blood Indian that received an education. As a result marked progress is noticeable in all the children in this family.

Clean living; good vegetable gardens milk and butter are their daily fare, as a result progress is very marked indeed.

Edith Clem. This girl is married to Harry Mills also an ex-pupil is a good girl but has had a great deal of trouble with her eyesight. When they first became sore her friends forced her to allow Indian doctors to attend them as a result her sight was nearly ruined. After she obtained proper treatment, she gradually recovered. Edith otherwise the woman is quite healthy and progressive. She lives on the reserve and she and her husband are among the most progressive set.

Ruth Cotton. This girl eloped from school and married Indian fashion with an Indian who had been married three times previously. She is healthy, clean; but the crassly unreliable characteristics of the Indian are her predominate qualities. It is a question whether school life has not been detrimental to this girl.

Jim Realy. Quite inside sort of fellow incapable of either much good or harm. Will never show either much progress or get into trouble. Lives on the reserve with his father.

Elgie Standish. This young woman is married to a worthless Indian Alone Rides In the Day Time. She is a good house keeper and healthy. She has two children. Is a good mother will progress rapidly.

Ida Weasel Fat. This girl is married to David Mills a negro indian half breed. Seems to be a good girl but will never amount to anything with her mate. She is healthy and a good worker. Lives with her husband's father.
Dick Deer Fox... This boy is a good worker married to Noi on this list they are doing well. Lately there has been some trouble about his health, some indisposition caused from the eating of too much meat. Also they now have some vegetables grown this year in their own garden yet their tastes still cling to the exclusive beef diet.

Jack Bird Bull. An ex-pupil of the R C school seems to be a fairly good worker is clean well dressed and he is becoming anxious to get any work in sight. He is very healthy and will progress. Is not I unmarried. Lives on the reserve. With his father does a good deal of freighting.

Maurice Many Fingers. This ex-pupil of the R C school is a good clean young fellow and is a very industrious worker. I am going to have him start farming the coming season. He is married and to Annie Doe also a graduate of this school and they have a good clean home well kept. They are healthy well dressed up industrious will advance rapidly.

Many Bears. This young man is one of the best workers on the reserve. He is married and one of our best farmers. I look for this young man to lead the way in progress among all the people with whom he comes in contact.

Terry Plain Woman. This young man is also a splendid worker and industrious. He is unmarried lives with his father who is a farmer and who thru the winter months works at our cow camp. The boy as well as farther are two of the employees here. This boy will make good.

Tom Eagle Child. This young man also a graduate of the R C School is a good worker a hustler but not so careful as I would like. He strives to make great last
great headway but lacks that balance which makes for effective advance. It will turn out well and be one of our very best Indians. He is married to Fanny Face, an ex-pupil they have a good clean home. He is also one of our farmers and at the present time he is engaged as scout and interpreter for the police.

Joseph Spike........ This boy is dying with consumption at the block hospital having been sick almost all the time he has been out of school.

David Mills....... This boy is the son of the assistant interpreter David Mills is not a treaty Indian. He is no good and I question if he ever will be. The admixture of Indian and negro blood in this case has been a failure. He lives with his father off the reserve and is married to Ida Weasel Fat an Indian ex-pupil. He is no good, a sneak thief.

Bertha Charcoal. Not on the reserve, is no good and it is questionable if education has not made her a worse Indian than if she had not gone to school.

Tom Weasel Shoe. No good has got in with a bunch of would be bad men, and is nothing but a tough.

Mary Frank now Mary Sweet Grass girl cleanly in her habits, has a fairly good husband but unfortunately is living with her husband's parents who with whom there is constant friction. This has almost led to a separation from her husband. I have brought this young girl to my own home where she is now my wife's domestic, until such times as the weather is warm enough for she and her husband to live in a tent. This young woman if given any chance will make good.

Maurice Prairie Hen. This boy has been transferred to the Peigan reserve where his mother lives. I believe he is a good boy but cannot give you detailed information.
Polly La Chappelle. This girl is married to an ex-pupil now Joe Bullshield. She is a good wife and mother has as yet no home of her own but will have this summer I am going to make her husband one of our farmers this year. She is healthy cleanly and sensibly dressed. This woman has made good use of her training and I am satisfied she will continue to do so.

Arthur Bullshield. This boy died two years ago in Edmonton penitentiary where he had been sentenced to a term of two years for horse stealing. As far as I can learn his sentence was not deserved. He died of Bronchitis.

Albert Mountain Horse. This boy has as yet shown no strong inclination to go to work. He is a very bright boy and not given to anything harmful but innocent. He is healthy. Is at present living with his mother on the reserve.

Ethel Crazy Crow... this is a splendid woman. She is healthy and married now to another ex-pupil Red Tail Feathers. Has two children

Red Tail Feathers. This woman's home is as clean and well kept as the average white home. She is progressive in every way and has and will make great use of her training. She will influence strongly for the better any Indian with whom she comes in contact.

Willie Blose... is subject to fits which has affected his mind. I hardly ever see him. He lives on the reserve with his aunt.

Minnie Jokers... This girl is in a peculiar position, she lives with Miss Wells her late teacher in the C of E School who now lives on the reserve devoting her whole time and attention to the advising of her one time charges. Miss Minnie has been raised by Miss Wells and is such a splendid young woman that she seems too far in advance of any Indian boy too to entertain the idea of marrying one. I do not know of an Indian that I would like to see Minnie marry. She is a good seamstress always industrious,
industrious.

Minnie Secker. A good housekeeper. She has had some trouble with a swelling on her knee, but this disease seems to be cured. This is a peculiar circumstance, a girl educated, trained in a manner too far above the only station in life her parents allow her to fill. I shall take a deep interest in watching and guiding the outcome of this young woman.

Lucy Gladstone. After this half breed girl left school she did not come on the reserve, and I do not know her whereabouts so can give you no information.

Fanny Page. This girl is married to Tom Eagle Child, is a good housekeeper clean and healthy. They live on the reserve and are one of our farmers.

Mary Bare Jack. This girl is married has as yet no home of her own but is a good wife, clean and healthy. She lives with her husband in the home of her uncle.

Mar Iron Horn. This boy is no good a sneak thief has served several jail terms, is worse than the Indian that has never went to school.

Robert Steel. This boy lives with his father is as yet unmarried is a clean trim looking rather insane boy not given to do anything mean, yet not much good.

Francis Red Crow. This boy is one of the brightest young men on the reserve if he could keep his cleverness rightly applied. I have had a great deal of trouble with him. We give in many respects one the idea of being the educated fool, just enough education to give him a swelled head. The I look for him to steady down and become a good man. He is married has a family has a good home, and plenty of property. Is healthy clean well dressed and mannerly.

Sir,— I have the honor to enclose you herewith my reply to your letter #15000-14 dated February 17th. I have sought to obtain you as definite information as possible, but on account of the extensive area comprising this reserve I have not become as intimate as I would wish with the scattered population.

Generally speaking there has been a marked advance derived thru the influence of the mission schools especially so in reference to cleanly appearance and living. But the Indian traits, superstitions and beliefs seem to be so strongly fixed that it is in many cases almost a hopeless task to uproot them. The greatest discouragement to the ex-pupil is that there is now too great a gap between school life and lodge life which often has ruinous results on the young women especially. In the few isolated instances where the children of ex-pupils are attending school there is a marked improvement over the native condition.

There is now a strong inclination on the part of the parents to send the children to school and our two schools have no difficulty in getting their full complement.

Despite the religious instruction given I question if there are many of the ex-pupils who have any faith in our religion. They attend church especially so if there is a feast in sight.

A little later when I feel that I am competent to form a comparative idea I will send you a letter giving you a comprehensive view of the school conditions here. As an ex-school teacher, there are many
conditions that I do not like in connection with our two schools here especially the C of E school. I have refrained from writing you on this subject until I acquainted myself with what was expected from the missions, and gained a comparative idea with other school of the same class.

There are several radical improvements needed in the C of E school, though to make it acceptable both to my views and also the expectations of the ex-pupils who have children. I have wanted to become thoroughly conversant with the conditions under which the principal was laboring before suggesting anything to the Department.

I have the honor to be

Sir

Your obedient servant,

Referring to your "Circular letter" of January 12th, 1914, No. 150000/14, requesting information re ex-pupils, in reply I offer the following:

Philomenus Peltier:- Living about 3 miles north of Cowessess school, Marienvale P.O. Health good, married to Fred Allary. Two children, one is a girl, sex of other unknown. Allary withdrew from treaty about 1886. Earns living principally by working out. Hand to mouth existence.

Joseph Robillard:- Living with father, Alec Robillard. Never was in treaty. Living on Quarter Section adjoining east boundary Pasqua Reserve. Fort Qu'Appelle P.O. Health good. Single. Earns living by working out. Hand to mouth existence.

Flora Robillard:- Daughter of Tom Robillard, non-treaty half-breed. Present residence unknown. Health good. Married to Michael Trottier, supposed to be in treaty around Fort Ellis. Had one child which died. Trottier earns living principally as a labourer. Circumstances and progress unknown. Agent Wheatley may be able to supply more accurate information.

The Secretary Henry Daniels:- Son of non-treaty Half-breed. Living at Pine Hills. Health good. Single. Occupation labourer. Parents dead. Hand to mouth existence.

Henry Daniels:- Son of Charles Racette (non-treaty) (non-treaty)
half-breed. Living with parents at Lebret. Is about fifteen years of age. Health good. Single. Chores around home. Chance poor for much progress.

Antonia Obey:- Father dead. Mother married to Chief Standing Buffalo. Antonia married to Gilbert Stone, Standing Buffalo Band. Stone is making only fair progress, farming in a small way, and working out. This girl has hip disease.

Julius Tahkwisk:- Living on Muscowpetung Reserve. Son of No.61 Muscowpetung Band. Health poor. Suffering from spinal tuberculosis. Was operated on lately for tuberculosis of the hip. He may live for a long time, but will always be a cripple. He is unmarried.

Mary Bird:- Living on Muscowpetung Reserve, of which Band she is a member. Health good. Sometime after leaving school she went to work as domestic on Mr. Graham's farm, where, through illicit relations with one of the hired men, became pregnant. Returned to Muscowpetung, and shortly before quarantine (December 10th, 1915) gave birth to a child.

Rachel Mewson:- or Tuckwaynow:- No.98 Muscowpetung Band. Living at Qu'Appelle Industrial School. Health - deformed with spinal tuberculosis.

Angus Katowens:- Residing on Pasqua Reserve. Married to daughter of No.92 same Band. Health excellent. Farming on own account, and making good progress. Is a bright, intelligent, and steady going man. One conviction for using intoxicants registered against him, for which he served one month. This was at the beginning of his career. Since when he has been a model example.

Leon Fournier:- Residing on Pasqua Reserve, No.49 same Band. This boy was discharged from
from Qu'Appelle School some six years ago, in very bad shape from scrofulous glands, and appeared to have no chance of living. He has, however, grown stronger and more robust, until today he is in a very fair way to do for himself. He is about 19 years old, and is unmarried.

Maurice Missens:- No.165 Pasqua Band. Living at File Hills Agency, where his father, Missens, No.21 Pasqua Band, moved to shortly after Pasqua Band surrendered a portion of their Reserve, and has remained there ever since. Maurice is healthy, but has grown at such an abnormal rate, that he is not very strong. He is doing very little, if anything for himself. This boy married Veronique Peltier, No.108, Cowessess Band, Crooked Lake Agency. They have two female children.

Daniel Tabasco:- No.266 Piapot Band. This boy was discharged from the Qu'Appelle Industrial School in 1910, and married Rebecca Mosey Bird, daughter of No.42 Little Blac k Bear's Band, File Hills Agency. This boy was suffering from tuberculosis, or weak lungs for some years. He made a start for himself after leaving school, but gradually weakened, until he died in May 1915, from tuberculosis.

Anthony Ironchild:- No.264 Piapot Band, resident on Piapot Reserve. This boy was discharged from Qu'Appelle School in 1910, and married Clementina Rock Thunder. Health excellent. Made a good start for himself before he was married, but owing to some trouble with his brother fell away last year. He is a good boy, and now that he is married, I expect that he will turn in again, and make good progress.
John Gabriel:- No.268 Piapot Band. Married widow of No.251, same Band in 1912. This boy made a very weak attempt to do for himself, and naturally failed, although effort was made to keep him going. He has been living at Battleford Agency since last Treaty payment.

Paulus Piapot:- No.271 Piapot Band. Resident on Piapot Reserve. Went to Qu'Appelle school when about fifteen years of age, and returned to the Reserve when about eighteen years old. Married Sarah Nokosis, daughter of No.42, Peepeekisis Band, File Hills Agency. Both the man and woman have weak lungs. The man does a little in the way of farming. He is not fit physically to expect very much of him.

I have the honor to be,

Sgd.,

In reply to your letter No. 286,000-34 SP January 19th 1956, regarding the en-pupils of the Settlement Agency, I have the honour to make the following report.

Henry Brown
This Indian resides at Red Pheasant reserve. His health can be considered as fair. He is single and has no permanent occupation. He complains of being ill as an excuse for not working, but is well to the front in all Brotherly exercises.

Adam Basquito
This Indian lives on the Stony reserve. He has good health and is single. He helps his father with whom he lives. This young man does not appear to make any endeavor to advance.

Maria Haggins
Maria Haggins lives on the Great Stone reserve and is married to an Indian named John Pinchey. Her health is good. She looks after her home well.

Samuel Burgess
This woman lives on the Red Pheasant reserve. She married and enjoys good health. She was first married to a non-Indian Indian, and was afterwards married James Schneegans. Her husband is not of much account as a worker.
Edith Blackstar

This woman lives at Red Pheasant reserve, and is married to Magheire (Badboy). Her health is good and she keeps a good clean house and looks after her children well.

Joseph Chamberlain

This young man resides in the Pas Agency, and as far as I can ascertain enjoys good health. He is single and earns his living by teaching school. He is of a better class than most of the other Indians, and is trying to advance himself.

Gilbert Buttenoo

This man, until recently was on the staff of the Industrial School at Battleford, acting in the capacity of outside overseer. He has since gone to Edmonton. He is single, and enjoys excellent health. He is a good worker and I believe he will make a success of his life.

Henry Higgins

This man resides near Prince Albert, and is in very fair health. He is single and at the present time, so I am informed is working for a farmer in that vicinity. He is a steady industrious young man, and is trying to improve himself.

Jessie Benaga

This woman lives on the Stoney reserve, where she is married to an Indian by the name of Warmshark. Her health is only fair. She keeps a fairly clean house, but does not have much chance to show what she can do.
Isabel Poyeshew

This woman died of consumption in Nov 1920.

Charlotte Benson

This woman resides at Red Pheasant reserve, and is in good health. She is married to Sam Tobaccojuice, who is not a very industrious man. She does the best she can, taking into consideration her surroundings.

Ida Armstrong

This woman lives on Red Pheasant reserve, is single and enjoys good health. She assists her mother at home, and occasionally works out for a month or two. She has given satisfactory answers wherever she has worked.

Edward Nicetino (Tobaccojuice)

This young man resides on the Red Pheasant reserve, is single and his health is fair. He does practically no work and is lazy like the rest of his family. He makes the excuse that he is ill.

Lydia & Maria Cardinal

I know nothing about these two women. They do not reside in this Agency, and I understand that they are living either at Buck Lake Agency or at Snake Plain.

For some time past the attention of the Department has been drawn to the procedure in the case of discharges from Boarding and Industrial Schools, and it seems advisable to issue some special instructions in this matter. It is desired wherever possible to give some assistance to discharged pupils to enable them to immediately put to practical use the instructions which they have received. You should therefore give special attention to pupils whose term of residence is nearly completed and consider each individual case according to its needs. No discharge should take place as a mere matter of form. The Department requires that there should be careful preparation for this most important event in the life of a school pupil.

The Principal of the Industrial or Boarding School and the Indian Agent should, some time before the proposed discharge, communicate with one another and decide what recommendations as to the pupil's future should be made to the Department. The medical officer of the school should also report at the same time upon the health of the pupil.

Indian Agents should carefully select the most favourable location for ex-pupils, and should also consider the advisability of farming them into separate colonies or settlements removed to some extent from the older Indians.
To male pupils who intend to begin farming on the Reserves the Department will render some degree of assistance outright, where any assurance can be given that a loan will be repaid, a certain advance will be made to purchase stock, building material, implements and tools.

Most careful thought should be given to the future of female pupils; the special difficulties of their position should be recognized and they should be protected as far as possible from temptations to which they are often exposed. They will be assisted in any effort to become self-supporting, or helpful to their parents, or at the time of their marriage.

Except in the case of girl graduates who may marry at a later date, it will not be possible, unless under very exceptional circumstances to consider assistance to ex-pupils who do not within a period of approximately two years from the date of their discharge, take steps to establish themselves on their reserve.

Marriage between pupils should be encouraged, and when a marriage takes place, the Department will give assistance to the young wife in some form to be afterwards decided upon.

The instructions contained in this circular supersede those of the circular which was issued on the 2nd July 1909.

The aim at this time (1914) was to secure complete records and to determine what were the general results. Were the large expenditure for plant and the more generous per capita grants for residential schools warranted?

In 1914 there was also a circular to principals and agents, giving special instructions concerning the discharge of graduates of residential schools. The aim was to give assistance wherever possible, so that graduates could immediately put into practice the training received. Prior to graduation the individual pupil's needs were considered and preparation for the most important event in the school life was requested. The discharge was not to be a mere matter of form. Principals and agents were to communicate concerning a proposed discharge and make recommendations to the Department concerning provision for the graduates' future. The medical officer was to report upon the health of the pupil. If a male graduate was to establish a home of his own, agents were requested to select favourable locations and to consider the advisability of grouping ex-pupils in colonies or settlements somewhat removed from the older Indian centres. At times equipment was given or loans were made to male graduates who commenced farming on the reserves. Female graduates were assisted at time of marriage or if they were helpful to their parents. Marriage between graduates was to be encouraged.

It is proposed to again stimulate the efforts to make graduates self-supporting and good members of their communities. Certain office machinery has to be set up for the purpose of securing the necessary information and compiling records.

Dear Mr. Graham:

It is proposed to stimulate the effort to make Indian residential school graduates self-supporting and good members of their communities. The history of each graduate will be secured and proper records compiled. Before approving the discharge of a pupil, the Department will ask both the principal and the agent to sign an application form, give information concerning the pupil's plans and make recommendations concerning helpful action to be taken.

I am prepared to arrange for larger appropriations for the assistance of ex-pupils and the Department will be guided by the recommendations of church and department representatives. Principals will be asked to keep a register showing the record of graduates and agents will report on progress and changes in residence and status each year.

Both church and department representatives will be asked to consider the individual pupil's needs and to prepare him or her for graduation - the most important event in school life. The principal will be asked to correspond with the agent before a pupil's graduation in an effort to determine the best way to provide the graduate into worthwhile activity. If a male graduate is to establish a home, agents will consider the advisability of grouping ex-pupils in settlements and will select a favorable location. Equipment for the farm or dwelling can be granted and loans made, if considered advisable. Further, marriage between graduates will be encouraged.

Please give this programme thoughtful consideration and offer constructive criticism. Any contributions to this scheme that you or your inspectors can make, will be appreciated.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

You will remember that we discussed the ex-pupil problem when you were in Ottawa. I am convinced that more definite steps must be taken to prepare pupils for graduation and to guide them into lives of usefulness. Much thought, many efforts and large expenditures by the Church and this Department are being put into Indian educational activity and there is no reason why the ex-pupil should not receive more of the attention and energy than heretofore.

Academic instruction in Indian residential schools has been stimulated from time to time and more satisfying results are being obtained. We must now emphasize particularly the vocational training received in Indian residential schools. This training must be coordinated with conditions under which the graduate will live and to be effective should be applied soon after leaving school.

I propose to inform the church authorities that principals of Indian residential schools are to be asked to cooperate with the Department in the effort to secure efficient instructors for vocational training. Every effort must be bent to secure properly qualified incumbents who will ever bear in mind that the pupil's school life is a preparation for useful membership in his or her home community. In all provinces girls should receive
thorough domestic training. In farming localities boys should receive instruction in farming, gardening, the care of stock and the handling of tools. Where Indians do not and cannot farm, the boys should be trained definitely for the earning of their livelihood.

In the second place, steps should be taken to surround the graduate with influences and aids that will make him or her self-supporting and a good member of the community. There are many inherent difficulties to this phase of the problem and I am writing to you and one or two others to assist me with the preparation of a programme of supervision and assistance for ex-pupils.

I should like to enlist our present staff of agents and other workers on reserves for this activity. As in the past, the Department will make grants for equipment and will allow loans for buildings, etc., when such action is wise. It might be well to consider settlements for graduates who are establishing homes.

Please let me have suggestions at your earliest convenience.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Canada, May 14th, 1932.

To Indian Agents
and
Principals of Residential Schools:

As the great majority of discharges from Indian residential schools usually occur at the end of the academic year, it is considered timely to again emphasize the necessity of principals of Indian residential schools and Indian Agents cooperating as far as possible.

When a pupil is approaching the age for discharge, the principal should communicate with the Indian Agent from whose agency the pupil comes, with a view to ascertaining the conditions in the home to which the pupil is going, and, at the same time, giving full particulars regarding the pupil's capabilities. Both church and departmental representatives should give careful thought to individual pupils' needs and to prepare him or her for graduation - the most important event in school life.

Indian Agents are being instructed to reply promptly to such inquiries from principals and it is expected that, as a result of this interchange of correspondence, the departmental officials on each reserve will take a real interest in the Indian school graduate's welfare and will endeavour, in every possible way, to guide the graduate into worthwhile activity. Special attention should be exercised where home conditions are not as good as might be desired, and, in such cases, Indian Agents should not hesitate to communicate with the Department with a view to working out some plan for the graduate that will ensure him or her making profitable use of the training received in the residential school.

Principals of residential schools should also enlist the sympathy of the local missionaries with a view to having these gentlemen cooperate with departmental officials in encouraging graduates.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

UNITED CHURCH SCHEME FOR PLACEMENT OFFICER

IN BRITISH COLUMBIA,

AS OUTLINED BY PRINCIPAL RALEY.

The Churches and the State have partly eliminated the Inferiority Complex of the Indian student but have by no means solved the problem of the Indian graduate. The problem resolves itself into (1) How can the ideals of the school be kept alive? and (2) What occupations can be provided for the graduate?

In the past, the effort was to make the Indian healthy, to train his mind and to save his soul. However, with the influx of the white man, the Indian's freedom has been curtailed (e.g., Fisheries and Game Acts, White Man's competition) and the Indian, with his inherited tendencies, his culture and traditions, has been swallowed up. The golden age for the B.C. Indian has come to an end and he has to throw in his lot with the white man. The Churches and the State have thrown a mantle of protection around the Indian, or the white man's contaminations would have made conditions worse than they really are.

The problem of the graduate, always keeping in mind the inherited tendencies of the Indian, resolves itself into (1) Health, (2) Academic Attainment, (3) Vocational Training, (4) Character. The Department and the Churches have pretty well solved the first two problems. Certain schools have done exceptionally well with vocational training and all of them are giving a good moral training.

After graduation, we find the real problem. There are drifters in the cities and other centres of population. Others go to the canneries before returning to their villages. Work is a salvation but the great majority find the old life comparatively easy, free firewood, free fish and occasional labour at good prices. The graduate does not feel satisfied that he has made good. He has a constant urge for a better place in the world. Further, he does not always fit into the old reactionary environment, as his education has not fitted him for primitive conditions. There is a chasm, separating him from the people. He cannot follow the old trail and would like to blaze a new one. He goes to the city to find work. Here, he knows no one and good jobs are at a premium. Pretty soon, he becomes a drifter and is living in a poor section of the city.
where drinking is common and vice is open.

The girl graduate who marries solves her own problem, provided she becomes a good mother and housekeeper. The level of the people is raised with each generation. The chief danger for girls is in the canneries and at casual labour, in cafes, etc. Girls, as a rule, however, like to improve their homes and living conditions. They are often considered snobbish and so many give up the struggle and seek work in the cities. Others make undesirable marriages. Unless those wishing to enter domestic service have made previous arrangement, they get into undesirable lodgings and are soon drifting where the colour line is no barrier.

As far as British Columbia is concerned, the most immediate and pressing problem is the future of the graduates, both boys and girls, who are moving into the cities. The city of Vancouver would be a good place to try out a new scheme. An Indian supervisor could be appointed, who, if he had a good knowledge of Indians and was able to maintain a check on graduates in the city, might be of great value in having young Indians placed in safe boarding places and in suitable positions. The success of this scheme would depend on the supervisor appointed.
Parry Sound, Ont.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

For some years past this has been a matter of great concern to the authorities of our Church in general, and to the authorities of our Missionary Society in particular. Careful action is being taken in keeping with the terms of that Resolution and the special committee which has been appointed to deal with the whole question has been quite busy in collecting data which may help them to formulate a system that will place the whole matter on a more satisfactory basis, than that on which it has rested hitherto. The members of this special committee have a strong feeling that, without the whole-hearted sympathy and co-operation of your Department's representatives, and especially of the Indian Agents, the work of supervision and direction of graduate pupils can never be made a success. and the missionaries in those Dioceses, will help to the fullest extent of their power, and it is greatly to be hoped that the direction you have given in your circular letter may be productive of the results which, I feel sure, you earnestly desire to secure.

1. If you had the opportunity again would you apply for enfranchisement or would you remain in treaty.

2. Do you think you have benefitted yourself by obtaining enfranchisement.

Glad to have got your letter some time ago. We are all well at present and quite happy. Robert Tobacco came here a few days ago but left for Split Lake by lake his old fort there and got so to his trapping ground. Robert is doing well and we make last lot of money in winter time. Elyal Tobacco and the brother R. Tobacco just send in his application to Ottawa to get out of treaty in the mean time. Elyal will be trapping while hopes along the east of Bay where Nick St. Croix, to White Rapids from Shetley. Portage, I was down the Pao last month to see old Doc Cook. I am applying for pension—this me getting it I might push so well get it. If I can get it, the time was dead, hard times everywhere no mining activity all the way. We still keeping a few claims, just enough to keep us going for a while—everything went to pieces when the cruel came and many people went broke and some others badly hurt.
Old town is still alive and that's about all, even by as the very devil in town since he is doing no business at all. No one likes him. Bob Miller got all the business which going in the town. Bob nearly got broke too spending too much on worthless mining claims, but we put him in his last of air. Rob was quite plentiful last spring, but the price was simply enough although we can pick lots of snow last fall before old weather set in. We had thirty four hour snow storm. Snow was nearly two feet deep to start with. That stop all my trapping, very poor winter for trapping any way. Our town is improving. We have two big sections houses and a coal bin, also one watch tower for fire rangers and one milk punch. Wells is still here. One of my boys got married last month to one of the old jin. Butten's girls. Mr. Fraser Principal of the new school was here for the reunion. I'll soon feel like an old man.
Matthew Wood is now Chief for the Nelson House Band and James Harvey the present Chief of Split Lake Band will resign his job next year. It seems this Swede fell fellow the Indians agent-up here unpopular among the Indians in this agency. I do not know anything about this fellow Donald Lindie, the son of W.C. Lindie and another trapper got their traps from dead white traps last winter they were out along the coast of N.Bay that fall while foxes came South much earlier than former years it happens often that there was a rain but this river was open the foxes could not get across so these two trappers went to work and put their shot guns to work when shells were exhausted they got out their .47 rifles and simply moved down the foxes in great style until they got over six them dead. Great luck
My old father is still living but he's still working as hard as ever, but the old fellow is getting old now.

My only brother Alex got married last summer—much work is going on along Hudson Bay Railway but it's impossible for any body to get a job now. I am having very much trouble to get a job at Churchill for the last three years but with no avail. I hope your family are very well. To Indian Agents and Teachers of Indian Schools in Saskatchewan:

The Saskatchewan Department of Education has drawn to this Department's attention the fact that there are held in different localities, from time to time during the academic year, gatherings of public school teachers. At these institutes, discussions on pedagogical methods and the general associations have proved a source of much helpfulness to school teachers. These meetings are teachers' conventions and take up from one to four days per year.

Teachers in Indian schools have been offered an opportunity to attend and participate in these institutes, and the Department of Indian Affairs will permit its schools to be closed any day, or days, on which there is a teachers' gathering in the vicinity. Days on which Indian school teachers have been present at an institute will be credited as "days taught" when salary is being paid. Indian residential schools, also, have permission to close classrooms on such occasions, if the teachers are attending an institute. The public school inspector will intimate to the teachers in his inspectorate the time and place for any such meeting.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter re above, I beg to explain that my plan was simply to hold a gathering (day) of the teachers of the three schools on the Peguis reserve, and the two teachers on Fisher River Reserve, at which each school seems, on further consideration, to be most generally convenient. I may be able to do something in some other way for the teachers on Lake Manitoba Reserve, who is greatly in need of guidance.

My idea would be to hold a one-day school, and giving the teachers a chance to assist as much as possible, and also to question and discuss procedure. Dear Sir,

I held the teachers conference for above named agency on Friday the 9th inst. All teachers of the agency schools were present except the Jack Head Teacher, whose isolated position make it impossible for him to be present without considerable loss of time. We also had the cooperation and attendance of Indian agent McCuish, who has always shown the utmost readiness to cooperate in educational efforts.

The teachers showed great interest and availed themselves of every opportunity for question discussion, and elucidation. I believe they all feel greater confidence in the possibilities of their work and clearer ideas of how to realize these possibilities.

I enclose herewith an outline of the subjects and problems considered and demonstrated.

Considerable emphasis was placed on the practical aims of a good Indian school as compared with a white school; and how best to work these out. Training in self-reliance and good citizenship were also fully considered. The correlation of school and out-of-school interests was also emphasized.

A Boys' and Girls' Club was organized, of which the Department will no doubt be advised by the Officers.
Inspector R. Ferrie Esq., Inspector of Schools, Manitoba

Inspector R. Ferrie, who was at Hodgson at the time, came up with me, and gave us valuable assistance in our conferences.

The teachers passed a resolution expressing a wish that such a conference might be held twice yearly at Peguis and Fisher Reserves alternately; provided that I could arrange to hold same.

I pointed out that the matter would have to come before the Dept. of Indian Affairs before any decision was arrived at. Speaking for myself, I could meet this plan if the fixing of dates were left in my hands, on the understanding that I should notify the Indian agent at least a month in advance of date fixed.

In this case, I would charge only my expenses, which would probably be about the same as those to this conference. (About $10.00 together with any expense bill the Indian agent may put in for board and driving on the Reserve.)

I am also sending through the regular channels a supplementary report of water supply at Peguis Centre and North.

Yours truly,

G.W. Bartlett

Demonstration Pugiscentte School, 8-6-22

A Practical Aims in Indian Education: how attain

1. Cleanliness and observation of elementary laws of health, and decency.

2. A pride in self-support, and usefulness.

3. A rational attitude to practical problems rather than away of tradition and superstition.

4. Appreciation of the beauty of useful work well done—a well-kept garden, a clean house, &c., conversely, a distaste for carelessness and slovenly work. The foundation for the appreciation of good taste and simplicity in decoration, dress, etc.

5. Good manners & Relation to foregoing

6. Good morals

B School attendance Conference, in which we were greatly assisted by the Indian agent and the Anglican missionary.

C How to interest Indian children

1. Adaptation of school program to their experience and environment.

2. More observation and manual work as source of information usually gathered from books.

3. Arithmetic, English, and other subjects based on real problems of the Indian boy or girl.

4. Study the Indian child; talk to him about school interests; get acquainted; win his confidence.

5. Do not be too critical at first. Show appreciation of the smallest effort toward good work. Accept the crude decoration of colouring at first, and work gradually to better.

P.T.O.
Special Subjects

1. Number Work: Explanation & objects of the work outlined in progress latest.
   (a) Value of use of rule and measure.
   (b) Chronological order in fundamental.
   (c) Fill in essential data in the Indian School.
   (d) Never allow pupil to attempt to work a prob.
      which he does not know the meaning.
   (e) Short snappy lessons of specific aim.

2. Reading:
   (a) Must first arouse a desire to read.
   (b) Read interesting story to pupil.
   (c) Talk about interesting topic and write simple words of sentence board.
   (d) Danger of beginning in the book too soon.
   (e) Danger of mechanical routine procedure.
   (f) Select appropriate lesson folly of the "cover to cover" method.
   (g) Supplementary reading.

3. Spelling:
   (a) Stress on familiar words in common use.
   (b) Written superiority of sentence dictation to word lists.

4. Geography:
   Necessity of home geography and study of environment as foundation for formal study.

Indian School Graduates

The subsequent career of graduates from different schools was considered somewhat minutely, and so far as concerns this agency, the results are not encouraging.

Considering various cases, the failure to make good seems due to the sudden change of condition from the environment of school to outside, especially in Boarding Schools. It would appear that at this stage and for a year or two, until the pupil gets definitely established at a vocation some follow-up system might be devised, or existing agents adapted to advise, guide, assist, and report on each case. The loss of the right leadership from these pupils in later years, is a serious matter.
