I feel that such a meeting is the only way whereby we can get things in line and have uniformity, progress and system in our schools. Much time & energy is certainly wasted from the lack of system. A good, far surpassing the expenditure, is sure to come from such a convention. There will be a sacrifice of time & an inconvenience to myself & teachers, yet little progress is ever accomplished without sacrifice.

Yours respectfully,

Frederick C. Ryan.

P.S. Should the Dept. have any suggestions to offer that might further the progress of such a Convention, I would be pleased to have same. I am booking many Notes, that I have, from time to time, found, that may be of more than little interest to our teachers.
Ottawa, August 5th, 1927.

Rev. Sir:

Relative to that portion of your letter of the last instant regarding the holding of a teachers' convention at Meductic from the 5th to the 7th of September, next, to be attended by all the teachers in the Indian schools in New Brunswick, I beg to say that the Department approves of this conference being held at the time mentioned. It is hoped that all the teachers will be present at this conference and that much benefit will be derived by them in their work. I would suggest that school management, classroom work and the interesting of the children therein, and the teaching of domestic science, be among the subjects discussed. We will allow the teachers leave of absence from the 5th to the 12th of September in order that they can attend this conference, and salary will be paid them during that period.

We will allow a grant not exceeding the sum of $150 towards the expenses of the transportation of teachers. We will forward this amount to you upon request, and you should administer the same in the payment of transportation and other expenses. You should obtain from the teachers, if possible, receipts covering the cost of their transportation, and you should prepare a voucher, in duplicate, accounting for the expenditure of the amount allowed.

The Department will leave the arrangements and details for the holding of this conference in your hands, and I shall be pleased to have a report from you after the conference is over giving the names of the teachers who attended, the various subjects discussed and the general results achieved.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. F. O. Ryan,
Inspector of Indian Schools,
Red Bank, North. Co., N.B.;
Rev. Fathers & Sisters, Fellow Teachers:

It gives me great pleasure to be present at this convention of Indian School Teachers—the first of its kind to be held in the Province of New Brunswick. I have been asked by Rev. Tucker to pay my esteemed Inspector of Indian Schools for the province, to offer a few practical suggestions on the teaching of some of the most difficult subjects which are taught in our Indian Schools.

The motivation of teaching consists in planning or teaching the work of the school so that the tasks of the pupil are made significant & purposeful to each child, by relating them as closely as possible to his childish experiences, questions, desires and needs. The child's work is not motivated whenever he sees a real use in it, or when it helps him to attain a definite end. If the different subject were presented in an interesting manner, children would not consider their school work such a drudgery.

Let us consider Arithmetic. To be compelled to study...
or to engage in certain occupations whose interest is utterly lacking is work; if the interest is sharply engaged, it is play. Mathematics, the stumbling block of many children's lives, can be made a joy by treating it as a science of quantity. Their imaginations should be developed by giving them practical examples of every day life, such as playing store, etc.

Let them play games on the blackboard, such as composition in addition, subtraction, multiplication and division tables, by having teams to see which side wins out by the rapidity and accuracy with which they play the game. I think it would be a great help if a copy of Kennedy's O'Hearn's Arithmetic could be secured as a hand-book for teachers to assist them in selecting practical examples. To my mind, the present day Arithmetic by O'Brien is not practical, especially for fractions.

Let us next consider grammar, which ranks second only to mathematics, as a mental discipline study. Yet it need never be irksome as a really enthusiastic teacher can make it one of the most fascinating subjects of the course. In the lower grades, instruction in English should take the form of language lessons, which merely emphasize what is correct or correct what is wrong, without teaching...
a system of rules; for instance they should be taught to say, "I saw it," he has gone." It is true she has done it without knowing exactly why; for grammar is a science, and the minds of little children are as yet too undeveloped to grasp scientific principles. When they come to the study of formal grammar, they learn the logical reasons for these things, and then they begin to take a real pride in speaking correctly. In teaching the parts of speech, the teacher should lead the child to see that the same word is not always the same part of speech, but may serve in a number of capacities—verbs as nouns, nouns as verbs and adjectives—for instance, "The good is always beautiful;" "The beautiful is good;" both "good" and "beautiful" are used once as noun, and once as adjective. And so on through the different stages of this subject, I think the teacher can make it very interesting.

Our present day History of Canada does not seem to appeal to the childish mind. As you all know children are fond of story-reading, and for this reason, I think that a history written in the form of a continuous story, and containing but very few dates would be
more easily studied and remembered by the children.

Geography may also be taught in many practical ways, for instance in map-drawing. A map is not a picture but merely a representation. Have the children make a map of their class-room (this should be done on a scale) marking desks by horizontal lines, the teacher's desk by a square, the heater by a circle, etc.; or they may make a map of the school grounds, their own home & grounds. Later they may map their village and so on. In teaching definitions, such as island, peninsula etc., when possible have the children go to river bank & really make an island & peninsula. In this way I think the impression will be lasting. So I have already detained you too long. Thank you for your kind attention.
Difficulties in an Indian class-room
How to overcome them.

No matter what occupation one takes up in life, difficulties are bound to arise. They may be small or great. The outcome of these difficulties, very often lies in the ways and means one takes to overcome and conquer them. Once a difficulty has arisen and is overcome, then one can be on guard to see that it does not occur again; and if it should then at least one knows how to overcome it from our previous experience. So in the long run, the optimist will not view a difficulty in a tragic light, but rather as another rung in the ladder of experience.

So it is with various difficulties which arise in an Indian class-room. In this paper I will try and deal with a few which have come within the range of my experience. These may be familiar to you, if again, you may not have met them.

First, let us consider
the two starting difficulties, namely those of "Beginning school" and "Regular Attendance," which we as teachers know to be so important, if the child is to accomplish anything.

The Indian child, by nature, is a lover of a free outdoor life, so naturally dislikes the idea of being enclosed within the school room for a period of five or six hours a day. Even again, the child may have been prejudiced by older complaints against school life, and had developed a dislike for school before it actually commences. We should always discourage such talk among older pupils and warn them against speaking of their class-room troubles before smaller children. This will in a measure overcome the starting difficulty. It has also aids us, by requiring all children of school age on the Indian reserve, to be enrolled at the Indian Day School and it is the duty of the truant officer, to see that this attendance is continued; thus lifting the burden from the teachers' shoulders to a
certain degree. Let us say now that the child has begun school life. The second difficulty now arises—that of regular and punctual attendance; and this one I believe, the teacher alone must cope with. The one great method of overcoming this difficulty, is for the teacher to create an interest for the child in school. Make those five or six hours so interesting, that the boy or girl will feel, that he or she is losing a great deal by not being present when the bell rings for the first morning session. Similarly for the afternoon. We all still have our own original ideas as to arousing this interest. May I suggest one or two ways. For instance, the first period of the morning, given to religious instruction, why not begin that period, not with a demand for the home prepared lesson, but by some simple interesting story dealing perhaps with the lesson which is to follow, again have a series of holy pictures for the children to examine, which are always inspiring for
anyone, more especially to the child who can retain what he sees more readily than what he hears. The lesson then following will be of interest for the children, because through story and picture study they have a knowledge of what it is about. Tales events follow one another in regular order, so as in the end to have one long complete story. Then the interest will be redoubled, and the child will always be in place in class, in order not to miss one event of the grand story which takes place daily in his or her school-room. Again, knowing the story and being able to recognize it in picture form, will make them eager to study and find out things for themselves. So I think that with a little originality on the part of the teacher, this simple plan could be followed not only with regard to the Catechism classes, but to all other classes as well.

Instruction—another great class-room difficulty. The lesson is being explained
by the teacher, and at its close she may inquire of a pupil, some fact connected with it. How discouraging to find that the pupil cannot give the required answer so soon after hearing it. The result of inattention on the part of the pupil—yes, and I can safely add, on the part of the teacher. Do not wait until you are all through talking before consulting pupils. Talk, explain and question as the lesson advances also have the children question you. Knowing what is then expected of them, pupils will have no time for their minds to wander off to what we term "Day Dreaming."

Cleanliness—The absolute necessity of the school-room. Insist that the boys and girls are particular about their personal appearance. Every teacher, sir, I am sure, extremely thankful for the establishment of Domestic Science, in our Indian schools, due to the untiring efforts of our Reverend Inspector. You will all agree that this branch of our work is
their original ideas in dealing with classroom difficulties. These I know would be of benefit to all of us.

Eileen Delaney.
The Best Methods in Guiding Indian Children

The greatest privilege an Indian child can receive is a sound education. We may define education as the training of an individual to enable him to succeed in whatever he undertakes during the future course of his life. Education includes the training of the mind, the body, and the moral faculties in order to reach the desired goal.

In our schools the mental training takes up most of our time. The results obtained from a lesson correspond with the methods employed by the teacher. To be effective a lesson must first of all be interesting. Many things may render a lesson attractive and interesting. The most important of these are concrete objects such as pictures, specimens, drawings on the blackboard, and samples. At a very early stage it is necessary to make the lesson especially attractive by using bright-colored pictures, letters, and figures, action pictures, and motion songs. At this early stage it is not possible to do away with concrete objects when teaching arithmetic; let the child see, feel, and hear the lesson that is taught. The senses of feeling, hearing, and seeing working in harmony should produce better results than one by itself. This rule is followed when the teacher explains the lesson, provides concrete objects, and lets the child handle them.

Teaching must be as natural as possible, that is, the work in the schoolroom must be linked up with the outside world.
world and should spring out of the element of life. Experiences provide natural means of teaching and are splendid for the teaching of nature study and geography.

In order to stimulate the memory of the child, examinations and reviews should never be omitted. The introduction of recitations and plays also serve the memory. Mechanical teaching cannot be done away with, but it must never take the place of teaching through ideas when possible. For example, spellings, addition and multiplication tables must be studied mechanically but if a pupil was asked to study and remember all his lessons in a mechanical way without reasoning he could never remember them. The classification of a child deserves notice for if he is classified too far ahead for his ability he cannot progress; on the other hand if he is classified below his ability he will lose interest. A careful preparation of the daily lessons by both the teacher and the pupils is necessary.

The seatwork like the classwork should be made interesting and it is the teacher's duty to see that it is always done in a correct and neat way.

The physical training is as important as the mental training for if a child is not physically fit, he is likely to be mentally defective. A class will be more alert if comfort is provided and it should be seen that pupils have proper light, material, desks and a properly heated
and ventilated room. A five minutes period of physical drill during each school session not only promotes correct habits in standing and walking but furnishes a variety of work after which the child feels and works better. These exercises are of much more benefit if taken in the open air. If physical drill is given at ten and two o'clock and recesses at eleven and three, all the pupils are prevented from helping to their seats longer than an hour and in this way their health is safeguarded.

The necessity of cleanliness should be impressed upon the mind of the child by insisting upon his keeping of himself and his school property clean and neat. The class is to regard the school as their own to beautify and care for.

A course in domestic science not only helps the child by furnishing him with clothing but provides him a training that he will need in after life. While the girls are busy at sewing, the boys may knit, unmake old clothes, mend slates, books, maps and other things. This course is an incentive in itself.

The religious training that the child obtains at school and elsewhere is of utmost importance for his behavior in later life depends upon it. Nothing can inspire more to religious ideas than the opening of the school day with religious exercises. These should be repeated before closing.
School. Holy pictures and stories seem to impress the Indian child.

If a teacher really wishes to aid his Indian pupils he must use every means in his power to overcome the difficulties that cross his pathway. He must ever be gay and encouraging and never falter so the children will follow his example.

Alice Tremblay
Practical Education for Indian Children.

This Convention of the teachers of the Indian schools of New Brunswick is the first gathering of its kind ever held in our province. And it might be fitting to remark, that the pretty town of Woodstock so beautifully situated in the heart of what was once the pride of Indian territory, is one of the most suitable locations that could have been chosen for this meeting.

I assure you, Rev. Father, that I consider it no small honor, to be selected one of the speakers at this Convention, but I feel that my qualifications for performing such an important duty are so limited, that I fear I shall not be able to say anything which would add much to the deliberations of this Convention.

However, I assure you, that I appreciate the confidence which you have placed in me, and have attempted in my humble way to prepare a paper on the subject on which you asked me to speak, namely, "Practical Education for Indian children, both as to school work and in Domestic Science."

Education consists of training, discipline, development and instruction. The proper meaning of "Education" is not only a drawing out, but also a training up, as a vine is trained to lay hold of and rise by means of what is
stronger than itself. In true education man's whole being, that is his physical, intellectual, and religious nature is developed. The object of education is to form habits of right thinking and doing. The aim of Practical Education is to enable the individual to co-operate with his physical, social and religious environments; to form good and wise men and women. The material with which the teacher works, is furnished by the home, the state and the church, and unless the school works in harmony with these three great forces, little is accomplished. The pupils of many Indian schools, when they return to their tribe, quickly lose what they have gained, because they are thrown into an environment which annuls the ideals that prevailed in the school. The controlling aim of the teacher should be, therefore, to bring her teaching into harmony with what is best in the life of the child. The teacher's attitude must be that of sympathy with her pupil.

The subjects which should be included in the Course of Instruction for Indian schools are, reading and spelling, elementary arithmetic, Canadian history, with special emphasis on the history of New Brunswick, geography of New Brunswick, and the general geography of the world,
English composition, physical drill, drawing,
domestic science, music and religious
instruction.

All children before leaving school,
should know how to read fluently
and with expression, and should know
how to spell all the ordinary words
found in their school books and words
of common use. In arithmetic, they
should know the fundamental operation
of addition, subtraction, multiplication,
and division, and should be able to
apply these to whole numbers, fractions,
mixed numbers and decimals, and
should be able to work easy problems.
Mental arithmetic should be practiced
daily in class. In composition, they
should be able to write simple
narratives and to know how to
properly write a letter both of business
and friendly types. They should know
how to use capitals and the principal
punctuation marks. Domestic science,
should include sewing, mending and
knitting for the girls. I might say,
some of the older girls of my school,
became quite expert at knitting. They
are now able to make sweaters for
themselves of the latest styles and
patterns. While the girls are working
at their domestic science, the boys
are occupied at drawing.

The chief concern of the teacher is
to develop faculty, to form character,
to point out the means whereby knowledge may be acquired and if need be communicated. Her aim is not to make learning easy, but to accustom the pupil to labor, since nothing but one's own industry can develop faculties or give them grasp of mind. In our elementary schools, pupils are trained mainly to habits of work; in the higher schools, they are educated to self-activity, made capable of helping themselves, and of fulfilling any duty that may be assigned to them. Schools must be places of order, punctuality, obedience and honesty, where attention and industry are kept constantly awake. In such places work grows to be a habit, and delight in work is the result.

The teacher's resolve then, is to aim at making, first of all, men and women, whose hearts are pure and sympathetic, whose minds are open and enlightened, whose motives are benevolent and generous, and whose purposes are high and religious.

Mary T. Hughes.
The First Day in a New School.

Reverend Father Inspector, Reverend Father, Reverend Sisters and Fellow Teachers,

How often have we heard and how often have we used the expression, "Vacation is over, we go back to school today." But how many realize the importance of the first day.

What depends on the first day in a new school—The success of the whole school year and every one should be prepared for a successful beginning.

To insure success a well-planned programme should be prepared and carried out systematically and carefully thus securing the confidence of the pupils.

Not later than 8:30 on the morning of opening the teacher should be at the school and the school must be ready for the reception of the pupils at least fifteen minutes before opening.

As each pupil enters the room he should be kindly greeted by the teacher and if time permits engaged in a brief conversation. It is of great importance that the children receive a good impression of the teacher; it will make his own work in the school-room easy and will secure at once the
goodwill and favor of the pupils thus providing the conditions under which success may be expected.

When the bell rings it is wise to let the pupil take any seat he may have in mind if necessary a change may be made later.

The Opening Exercises should be followed by a talk with the pupils. The object of this talk is to gain the confidence of the pupils not to impress rules and regulations on them, or in other words to give the pupil the impression that he understands his work and is quite confident that it will be a success.

The next step is to assign work to each class. The programme which has been prepared should be put into effect. This should be done promptly in order to avoid any confusion.

A class of new beginners are usually lazy and backward, and so special attention should be given them. They are not accustomed to classes so the first lesson may be taught to any class other than the primary. Pictures and books if supplied them will keep their attention for a few hours until they become
accustomed to their new surroundings.

Small classes on the first day the lesson should not be too long as the pupil will find it difficult to start the new routine of study. After the holiday,

During the day Physical Training and Social should not be neglected.

During recess on the first day of the teacher will go out on the play ground the pupils will feel that he is interested in their games and this will also help to gain the confidence of the pupils.

The teacher should make a point of doing some effective teaching in the various subjects so that when the hour of dismissal comes the children will feel that the first day at school has been both profitable and pleasurable. To have this impression carried into the various homes of the community is to commence work under the most favorable conditions.

Thoughtfulness is always an excellent characteristic in any teacher but is especially noticeable in the experience of his first day in a new school. Kind and considerate treatment is due every child. The teacher should not parade his authority.
nor exhibit any desire to repress the pupils' indulgence whatever is to be extended but all should be treated with dignity fairness and sympathy.

The teacher should be perfectly natural in his attitude towards his pupils as an assumed manner is readily detected.

The teacher should not assume the whole responsibility for the day's work as it deprives the children of one of their most important rights that of learning to do things for themselves and others.

The teacher must also be optimistic. He must expect success and work hard to attain it. At all times during the first day and every day the teacher should concentrate his attention upon the duty in hand and at no time should he worry over the mistakes of the past or be too solicitous about the future. Many emergencies will arise during the day and some surprises may await him; but the teacher who exhibits a genuine interest in his school and conducts the work in a thoughtful and optimistic manner is on the road to success.

Estelle O'Brien.
Physical Drill and Ventilation.

Reverend Dr. Inspector Reverend Bailey,
Reverend Sister and Bishop Brother.

Physical Culture is one of the several terms that have come to be applied to the development of the physical organism. The person who undertakes to apply its principles must know the value of exercise, pure air, ventilation, and proper breathing. Certain forms of gymnastics will build up and organs, or muscles, while another kind of exercise will affect an entirely different set of muscles. Club swinging, for example, develops the muscles of the arm, wrist, back and shoulder. The diving exercises develop the waist, hips, and abdominal muscles, giving flexibility and grace to movement; running not only strengthens the leg muscles, but by forcing deep breathing brings about better chest expansion and lung development. It is this feature of adaptability to individual needs that makes gymnastics so helpful, for by carefully following the course of exercise prescribed one can correct almost any defect in his physical organism.
which all physical training should aim.

It is a matter of note that educators are giving more and more attention to bodily development as an essential part of education, and are obtaining good results in the course through physical exercise.

The ventilating problem is a two-fold one, involving the exclusion of impure air and the admittance of fresh air. Unless there is a constant circulation of air in a room, such a room speedily becomes unhealthy and unsuited to be inhabited. It is not enough in providing for the ventilation of a room to open the windows from the bottom. Fresh air cannot enter unless the warm impure air is allowed to escape. This may be provided by opening the sash from the top. It is one of the most important duties to see that bedrooms are ventilated so as to provide proper room.

Ventilation should aid thought and work; improve health and comfort, and decrease fatigue and errors. The most important help is an ordinary reliably thermostatically placed in the room four feet from the floor on an inside
An important thing in all gymnastic work is to know where to stop. It is dangerous to carry an exercise so far that any part of the body is developed at the expense of the rest. All-time strain should be avoided. Moderate exercise leading toward good all-round development of the body is the ideal for brain training, rather than abnormal development in any one direction.

A large part of the benefit from gymnastics aside from the muscular development comes from the fact that the exercise makes it necessary to breathe harder and more deeply. For this reason the room in which the exercises are performed should invariably have its windows open to admit plenty of fresh air. Still better of course it is to do the work out-of-doors. The exercise keeps forcing more air into the lungs than would ordinarily be inhaled. This gives pure, vitalized blood to the heart and sends a healthy glow through the body. The action of the stomach and other organs is stimulated, the appetite increased, and the digestion improved. These all make good health, and good health is the goal at
wall, not too near a door window radiator, stove or other influence. The temperature should be read every half hour by the person responsible for the temperature and change of air. It should never be warmer than 68°, and if people are working or creating heat by their own effort, the temperature of 60° or lower is more pleasant. Dried cool air should come in through the open window. If it is zero outside and 65 inside, a very small opening will allow a large amount of fresh air to enter.

Basically it must be emphasized in closing the discussion that the problem of overheating is the primary essential in all systems of ventilation. Air change, direction of flow and all other facts are secondary, but should be well in mind that however simple or however complex an apparatus may be installed for air conditioning, a constant and intelligent vigilance in regard to operating and maintaining is the price of health and comfort.

Francis Sheppard.
The subject which I have been asked to discuss here today reads: "A General View of what is required for the progress of our Indian children at School. What we are to consider, to discuss, to suggest, to oppose etc... is therefore very clear and in order to render this discussion more real and more practical, let me for a few moments repair to our own individual classrooms.

When have we met them last Thursday, September the first? All met no other but the Indian child. And vice versa, whom and what has the Indian child met there on his or her first schoolday? He met a language and an education alien to his own. Thirdly, whom will both the Teacher and the Indian child meet there twice in the year? What is the purpose of this most welcomed Visitor? To ascertain, on the part of the Province of New Brunswick and the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa the progress of the Indian child at school.

But how is this progress, exacted of the teacher, to be realized and what is required to realize it? Such is the purpose of this meeting.
Unfortunately I am the first called upon to give my views on the subject and I hope that after listening patiently to what my limited experience will allow me to say on the matter, I shall be gratified with other and more experienced views than my own.

On a Reservation the teacher meets no other but the Indian child. A close insight into the nature of that child is to me a first requisite, and the main characteristic discovered in his suspicious nature. The child consequently has the same attitude toward all classroom activities, and like the stoic of old will not betray one expression, one ray of enlightenment, not even a satisfactory response.

On the other hand he looks forward to some word of approbation from his teacher; he therefore secretly wishes to please those to whom he is entrusted, and if always disapproved of will easily get discouraged. If the Indian child is therefore informed of our ideal of a bright, smart, clever child he will secretly strive to attain this ideal, and a firm hand but compassionate heart will cause the child to move in this direction with the result that the child will readily
respond to the classroom teaching. His suspicious nature will gradually give way in the presence of an upright, frank, and open living example.

When once aroused the child has quick perception but his mind is not retentive, and he cannot concentrate for any length of time. The subject matter to be taught must therefore be presented in a striking way and briefly. He is also fond of stories, so that all subjects which lend themselves to story form can be made use of and arranged in such a way as to arouse his curiosity.

The Indian child is also very obstinate his home motto being - do not contradict me - and the child is thus fostered to even feign anger in order to attain his end - to do as he pleases. The Indian child is not therefore an obedient child but he easily submits in the presence of unrelenting firmness.

I have, as you see, based the first requisite for progress on the education of the Indian child, and instruction will, to my opinion, be successful inasmuch as the child is led away from the three above mentioned defects of his nature - suspicion.
Lethargy, stubbornness—not forgetting his counterbalancing qualities: desire to please, quick perception, fondness for stories. Tribes possibly differ one from the other, and I should be thankful to know if you found the same natural characteristic.

On the other hand the Indian child, on his first school day, meets with a language and an education alien to his own—the former being naturally the greater drawback to the child. The latter has just been discussed. What we require for the successful teaching of English to the Indian child is the next item to consider.

The first requisite here is plenty of blackboard space for every lesson taught in terms with difficulties of all kinds, and unless the child be given a chance to visualize these difficulties he or she will never be enabled to master them and the teacher's efforts and the teacher's time is spent uselessly for repeated drill is required for both spelling and proper enunciation.

Easy and well-illustrated supplementary reading in literature, history, geography and nature study and covering the work contained in the school course.
would also help immensely for the reading of the text books is rather trying for the child and must necessarily be and in rather brief and therefore of little interest to him. The teaching likewise has to be brief. Difficult words would thereby lose some of their monotony and from mere words would become real existing persons or objects and consequently something worth while learning about.

My third requisite in the teaching of English to the Indian children is some means of creating competition among them. They are susceptible to this training and I know through actual experience for we dissuaded an Indian mother from taking her child from school on the ground that he was first in his class. A monthly report of some kind, and suited to meet the purpose for which it is intended, would serve both as a stimulant and as a test of the child's mastery of the subject by requiring a written test from the older pupils, and an oral one from the younger, or both, to award class standing, and a reward of some kind to be given to the successful ones. This would mean a little more work to the teacher and a little expense to
the government but I think that the re-
sults would prove worth while attempt-
ing. It is possible that this system is
already introduced in the schools.

The Indian child also meets
with new surroundings and these must
contrast with his home surroundings
in cleanliness, tidiness, order and arrange-
ment or disposition. The reason for this
is quite obvious.

Before passing on to my last
word I should like to stress particu-
larly the need in our schools of plenty
of material for illustration work, and
whenever possible, the object itself.

Both the Teacher and the Indian
Child meet twice in the year our kind
Inspector whom we all know and
whose visit we all enjoy. He is the
connecting link, if I may so express
myself, between the Educational Depart-
ment and the School. I shall not com-
ment on this subject very lengthily, but
shall summarize all by recalling that
he is the organizer of this Convention,
and shall therefore be but too pleased to
favor us with advice for the time being,
and both advice and material mentioned
for the future, as he has done in the past,
in order to forward education in our
schools. I should therefore be thankful
to hear some of you complete the numer-
ous missions on this so important
subject to the Teachers of: "What is required
for the progress of our Indian children at
school," and to discuss these requirements
in the presence of Representatives who can
be and hope will be of immense help
to us in the pursuit of so sacred duties
as we are called upon to perform on
the Reservation confided to our care, and
to foster in the hearts of these Indian
children the true sense of duty to their
God, to their fellow creatures, and to
themselves.

I thank you.
The Best Method to adopt in teaching Economy to Indians.

Before adopting a method of teaching economy to Indians, let us briefly consider their mode of living.

Do our Indians, and here I refer to the majority, dress according to their condition in life? Do they distinguish between working clothes, Sunday clothes, and clothing for other circumstances? Do our Indians buy for the wear they get out of the articles bought? And these articles when once procured do they care for them as they should? Do they buy useless articles when financially unable to afford them? These questions I leave to you to answer. The only two articles which I noticed they seldom get is an umbrella, to protect them from the rain, and rubbers for their patent-leather shoes. Do you consider this economy? All other articles they find means to obtain. To repair, to clean, to press etc., are little known to them, they would rather entrust these to their kind protector the St. John. Shoes found along the lanes show that their only harm is a worn out sole. At very little cost
these could have been repaired for weeks.

So much for raiment. Let us now turn to their food articles. Do our Indians try to raise all the vegetables they can in order to store them for the winter? Some raise a little, others nothing. They have land for this purpose but claim they have no cellars. They either have to walk or pay their fare to some centre where these articles may be procured, and here again taste often prevails over substantiality, even at the risk of buying their food the next day. A few manage to put a little money in the bank, but these are the exceptions.

It is true that their homes present to them very little comfort, but they easily put up with this state of things by remaining in them as little as they can, and make up for this want of comfort by amusements. The neighboring cinemas find in their audience a good number of our Indians.

Outside labor is their only means of subsistence. Do all take advantage of it? Many are good workers but how many are constant workers? Still many manage to pull through but the majority are thriftless. What they lack therefore is want of economy. But how are we
to teach economy to them?

We could talk to them days at a time on this same subject but to no effect. We could strive to give them the most practical personal example but with no better result. The only way that I see open to attain this end is a practical follow-up system. To introduce the system and then carry it out successfully would require a little time for the confidence of these people would first have to be won. Through repeated meetings and agreeable conversations with them the subject could be easily approached and timely suggestions and common good sense lead the way.

The teachers have the Domestic Science Class to come to our help, and on the Observations where all the ladies are supposed to attend, a move has been made in that direction, but two hours work per week would prove insufficient for all that is to be done, and more time can hardly be devoted to this branch since the women can attend at no other time but class hours.

Furthermore, the Indians readily accept all that is given to them gratis, but would they consent to buy the material to be cut and sewed at the Domestic Science Class? They would
rather buy ready-made clothing so as to follow the style, and spare themselves the trouble of making it. The teacher would have to shoulder both duties of teacher and dressmaker, and be quite skilled in the art of cutting in order to attract or win over the women to make their own clothing. Cooking and manual work form part of the Domestic Science Course, but Household economy is not the only form of economy to be taught. Who is to teach the other forms of economy? It seems that a home industry of some kind employing the men and women of the Reserve would keep them at home and in this way favor labor and greatly reduce expenses.

A number of poor families call at the Dispensary for clothing etc., these calls could serve the intended purpose of suggesting economy means to them. Account books could be suggested for the homes and there occasionally verified at the Domestic Science Class. But here again I fear that much would be left out of these account books, both in way of revenue and expenses. Still there is a beginning to everything, and with time deceit would give way to sincerity.
A yearly exhibition of vegetables raised might prove a great incentive for home gardening.

These suggested means would serve the purpose of indirect follow-up work in economy teaching thus giving time for more direct means to take root and develop.

I have suggested a method of teaching economy to Indians—the practical follow-up system—and mentioned the Domestic Science Class as the chief agent in the teaching of Household economy as well as hinted means of indirect follow-up work. As to the best method to adopt in teaching economy to Indians I leave to this Convention to pick out.

I thank you.
Domestic Science.

The Domestic Science classes which our Reverend Inspector has established in the Indian schools are a source of great benefit to the Indian people. For in our classes we instruct not only the school children but also the Indian women in the art of sewing and cooking. It is necessary to give frequent lectures to the women on economy, so that the Indian people are familiarized with the use of material which could be put to good use.

We believe at times from the Indian agent's store of old clothes, these ladies repair, mend, and make into garments for the boys many of whom cannot afford to attend school through lack of clothing if they had been sewing classes.

The girls and women are delighted to make articles of clothing, also to knit stockings, sweaters, caps, and mittens.

All Small Pieces &
of material are used in making quilts these attract the Indian women, as quilts are rare, and when they see the small pieces which they have always discarded put into such good use they are pleasantly surprised.

The cooking classes are more attractive to the Indian women and children than the sewing.

The first thing they're taught is to have a stove in their kitchen and keep it in good order.

We watch our classes closely to see that the dishes and pans etc., used are washed clean.

Many arrangements can be made in the division of the cooking classes permitting me to draft my plan.

Each class five girls were chosen to do the cooking while the remainder of the classes sewed or knit. One of these girls is chosen as housewife while the remaining four are subject to her authority, supervised by the tea chef.
The housewife sees that her cooks copy the recipes and that their dishes are washed, and the hand towels are hanging in their proper places. This gives the pupils a sense of responsibility.

The homes of the schoolteacher also aided the Indian people by her special work. The First Communion class and their pupils at the Board School were dressed entirely with clothes made in the Domestic Science classes. The boys' white blouses and caps were made by the mothers, also the girls' underwear and dresses.

In the feeding classes many of the little children who were at times without food in their respective homes were given pancakes, porridge, fish cutlets, etc.; these classes were not established in the schools many of the children wanted more than without food at school.
During the school year especially during the winter months many of the people and the children were ill. The Domestic Service teacher accompanied the doctor to the different places and aided him in tending the sick, acting on the physician's advice and instructions. Poultries were applied and medicine given at the stated time. The Indian people are grateful for these acts of kindness and prayers often attened the Domestic Service classes because they wish to please the teachers who aided them in their illness.

Thank you,

Evelyn L. Brown,
Agent Church,
Indian Service.
The best method to maintain order and attention of the Indians' children in the class room.

Essential to good beginning is the first day of the term. By phrasing manners and first day of the term the respect and confidence of your pupils will grow from the hearts of the children; your influence without limit.

Every teacher ought to know something of the family life, habits, and the history of the parents of the Indians' pupils. It is an advantage to become personally acquainted with the parents.

My hopes deals with the best methods to maintain order and the attention of the Indians' children in the class-room. First let us consider order in the class-room. The pupils should be trained to perform
the necessary movements as methodically and as quickly as possible; so that they may be given every morning for the first two or three hours throughout the day. During these hours the teacher will explain to her pupils what she expects them to do, the mistakes she has noticed and at times a few words of praise. The pupils have done fairly well in the past, and have been taught by the teacher herself. They will enter the class in an orderly fashion. They same order should be used in dismissing the classes. Certain signals should be observed when calling classes from their seats. For example, the pupil will not squat himself until the teacher gives the command. All the pupils must stand while answering questions, and the answer...
delivered in a tone loud enough to be heard by all in the class.

Special privileges such as raising the hand getting a drink etc. It is well to arrange for quiet signal code, such as raising two fingers between the pupils and yourself by which the request or granting of any privilege or interruption caused by spoken words.

Much of the routine work of the school ought as collecting and distributing books, anything serving etc., should be done by certain pupils appointed after a definite period. This work by the pupil as a privilege, hang up cases for misconduct these privileges may be withdrawn.

Registration of all teachers present was next order of business.

Rev. F.C. Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools in New Brunswick, delivered an opening address touching on the various matters to come before the Institute. This address was divided under the following headlines:

I Christian Education.
II Letter Sounds.
III Need of order in Class Room.
IV Lessons made easy.
V Emulation between pupil and pupil.
VI Text Books.
VII Supervision of Playgrounds.
VIII Teachers' life in School.

in the present law which would make it imperative for all females on the reserve to attend school until they had reached the age of seventeen years.

The REPORT on the TEACHER's Convention held at Woodstock,
in the interests of all Indian schools in N.B., Canada, -
from the 6th to the 8th, of Sept. 1927, presided over by
Rev. F. C. RYAN, Inspector & Supt. of Ind. schools for N.B.

To the Dept. of Ind. Affairs
Ottawa,

It gives me much pleasure to report on this our first Convention
of teachers for our Indian Schools, in N.B. -
All teachers were present and read their very interesting papers
that I had assigned them.
I opened the Convention by laying before teachers the work to be
followed during these days of session, -a synopsis of which
you will find inclosed. -however, many other important matters,
not included in the said paper, were brought before this Convention,
and fully debated on.

Our first PAPER -by Mrs. Stella Kehoe, -entitled "TEX-BOOKS"
was carefully read and then thoroughly debated on. -The
Convention unanimously adopting the following:

(1) That the Progressive Series in ARITHMETIC by KENNEDY &
O'NEILL be used in conjunction with the present N.B.
Arithmetic (CAGED), as found in the N.B. white schools;
(2) That for beginners, ONE NUMBER a day is all that can
be well mastered by the PUPIL;
(3) That each method should be clearly taught, and thoroughly
understood by the pupil, before taking up another.
example, Multiplication, well known before DIVISION is
taught, &c., &c., &c. Never mixing the two together, until
both were well known by pupil.
(4) That before taking up the different parts in the Arithmetic,
a good plain instruction be placed before the Pupil, showing
the need of, and how useful, & necessary that part of Arithm.
will be to him in life &c., &c., this will give him a great
interest in same and he will naturally work harder to accom-
plish same.
(5) That Games & be used on "BLACK-BOARD" to interest all pupils
in all their work, as far as possible.
Example for Arithmetic, -Rev. Sister Eleanor of the
Woodstock White school, gave a wonderful demonstration
to all our teachers in this method.

As the Month of Sept. is always known as the month for
the EXHIBITION at Woodstock, and for all of N.B., -She
drew on the "BOARD" with different colored chalk, "TROTTERS"
& tracks, each horse corresponded in COLOR to each track,
numbers of the multiplication tables that were then known
to the pupil were placed along this TRACK. Now, each child
chooses its TROTTER & track, its name is the name of the
PUPIL, -off each child starts with the numbers, all other
pupils watching, --The child going the fastest and with
the least mistakes wins the RACE, -
during the Month of October, -An apple tree is drawn on
"Board" shown apples on tree & on ground, the Multipli-
cation tables in the numbers known to child are placed
on the APPLES on ground or tree, -the one who goes the
best over these numbers gets the most apples &c., &
The Month of Nov, a forest is drawn on BOARD with deer
& moose &c., heads, reflecting faintly from trees, on
the ground are many bullets and on the bullets are the
multiplication tables, -the pupil that does the best is
the most successful hunter, &c., &
The Month of Dec, is Christmas, -forts & snow balls are
used. The snow balls have the Muli; tables on same, the
best pupil takes the fort, -On-in all these games, -
two teams can be chosen with "teams", -the side doing
the best work wins, In this case, the leader of the team
is often seen at RECESS & noon hour instructing the dull
members of his team so he will come out first.
For the Month of March, floating ice cakes are taken, -
April, Easter eggs are used,
May, the May poll is used with the num-
bers on the stringers hanging from the POLE.
Thus throughout all the Months are the different things chosen to interest the pupils.

(6) Sounds, ----

Rev. Sister Mercia of the Woodstock Ind. school simply held our teachers' attention during one of the most interesting instructions given at this convention, and that on a subject that forms the most trying work for the teacher.

She took up the sounds of all the letters—then the many sounds that apply to the same letter, or a combination of one or two letters.

Examples:

For the short (A), she drew on the BOARD, a LAMB bleating.

For (B), two DOVES making their accustomed guttural sounds, &c., &c.

(F) a cross cat snarling &c., &c.

(J) a JUG

(G) a bottle lying down with water gurgling from it.

(P) a steamboat puffing along, with a heavy load.

(L) a very tired boy showing how he was puffing going up hill &c., &c.

(M) A cow mewing, &c., &c.

(V) a fly buzzing, &c., &c.

(W) a tree showing the sound of wind going through its branches, &c., &c.

and thus she continued with all the LETTERS.

To facilitate this method of teaching, she used games, such as—

"The post office game."

This represents a mail box in a post office, so the pupil that will get the most sounds correctly, will get the most letters, &c., &c.

She used what she termed the "GUESS GAME."

The teacher thus simply asks the pupil this question:

Who can tell me the word that I am thinking about, that will rhyme with—"HAT"? The pupil guesses "RAT,"—the teacher says no,—at the same time print this word RAT on board, and thus continue through the whole class, giving each child one or more chances, but writing down all words guessed, then the teacher places the proper word on BOARD at the end of all the guessed words. This retains the attention of all pupils.

Another method is adopted in the building up of words. A house is drawn on BOARD, —say called the "AN" house. The pupil is required to place in this DRAWING only such words as belong to the "AN" family, as—can, man, fan, ran, &c., &c., the one getting the most words wins the game.

Practical methods were adopted for the study of Geography, requiring the pupils to go to the shore and with a shovel make a LAKE, BAY, ISLAND, CAFE, &c., &c., &c. The full class watching for mistakes, &c., &c. Currents, tides, &c., &c., could also be thus taught.

In the same way GRAMMAR could be taught, as the thing made called a noun, the making of same, the verb &c., the size, the adjective, the speed in making, the adverb, &c., &c.

Thus along these lines, the Convention found wonderful methods that will make their schools both interesting and progressive.

Miss Cahoon's paper on "The best method to retain order in the school room," attendance at school, was listened to with deep interest.

The convention adopted the following:

(1) As all Ind. children have a deep RELIGIOUS disposition, and do reverence holy objects, All teachers agree that, if a small table (like a table like an ALTAR, with a statue on same & light burning,) the school would so resemble a church, that they would respect same, this I have tried out with perfect results.
How to keep order in school continued -------

SIGNS to be used in school -&-:

ONE FINGER RAISED, must go out,
Two "s" "s" "s", get a drink,
Three "s" "s" "s", permission to ask a question,
&c.

All school material not required for present work going on in school, but later required, is to be kept on teacher's desk, and distributed by the most worthy pupils at RECESS, or such time that will not disturb the silence of school room, &c. Each Ind. child considers it a mark of honor to give out books during this period, and do try hard to attend school, and give good attention &c., &c., &c., in order to do this work, &c.

All teachers claimed for Attendance, --the best and only method lay in the channel of LOVE, affection, and in making SCHOOL LIFE more attractive than their home.

Rev. sister Mary of Victory read a beautiful paper on what is required for the progress of the Ind. child.

All teachers agreed to use the BLACKBOARD system more, also the reading of short stories that will leave a moral effect on the pupil, and aid him in his school work, &c.

Also to use the system of EMULATION, &c.

Being brief in explanations, yet simple, & clear,

Miss Delaney read a paper on the difficulties in the classroom.

All practical suggestions, in said paper, were adopted, as religious pictures, for emulation purposes, The making of school room attractive.

Good ventilation, Pleasant surroundings, A variety in work, &c.

After difficult work, change to that work that would be pleasing to pupil &c. Keep INTEREST ever living in the school-room.

Miss O' Brine's paper on physical drill & ventilation &c., gave teachers an added interest in this.

A series of exercises will be adopted for all schools.

At recess, games will be encouraged by the teachers being present and even taking part in them, &c.

Good ventilation, &c., Warmth in school rooms will be avoided.

Lectures, (one per week) will be given, on different subjects pertaining to Health, Temperance, thrift, Habits, The necessity of work to keep the body healthy and strong, and all other useful subjects that will uplift the Ind. child.

Miss Alice Tremble read paper, entitled --Aiding Ind. children.

We adopted the need of opening and closing all our schools with prayer, &c., and keeping schools clean & attractive & well ventilated, &c., as adopted from other papers, &c., &c.

Miss Mary Hughes read paper, entitled best methods in aiding Ind. CHILDREN, in general.

We adopted the following,

(1) The use of mental arithmetic,
(2) Simple composition
(3) Any and all legitimate methods that would encourage the Ind. child to work and love work &c., how work soon grew to habit, which meant bright and happy children, &c., men & women, bringing prosperity, riches with economy & long lives & health.

(4) Teachers to have great affection & kindness for the Ind. child learning a new language, and often coming to school with but little to eat, or wear.

"DOMESTIC SCIENCE."

Miss E. Cahoon read a paper on this branch of our work.

The following methods were adopted -------

(1) To induce all Indian women to interest themselves in this branch of work

(2) Lectures on various subjects pertaining to the importance of this branch of science

(3) Divide RESERVES into five sections, thus, each section would represent, with other lines, a day's work, in this way each Ind. house would be visited weekly. Then some day taken, every two or three weeks, not known to the Ind. women, a general visit of all houses to see if instructions given were being followed out, &c., &c., Where it is found that Indians will not try to follow out instructions on HEALTH.
HEALTH &c., then, if such families are receiving poor aid, means should be adopted to stop same until this family attends to the fulfillment of all instructions, &c.

To successfully interest the Indian woman in this important work, great care & precaution must certainly be taken in the first visits to their homes.

The first, even second or third visit may seemingly meet with little recognition, yet if the Domestic TEACHER would on these first visits reach the mother's heart through her little children, which certainly is the true road—what confidence would soon be placed in this teacher. Always delight on the good looks of the little child, its growth, its nice eyes, & all its good qualities, & all the little ones about the house &c., showing always a great interest and love for them, &c.

That the Field Matron should teach all rules governing health, &c., and spread about the Ind. homes LITERATURE, pictures showing the different stages of disease, &c.—cards in the form of large signs containing health rules & regulations, &c., that might at all times educate & interest the Indian home. Thus they would not avoid vaccination, and would at the same time keep their homes clean, &c.

TEACHERS PRESENT VOTED to petition the Dept. of Ind. Affairs to provide "foot-wares" for all Ind. children of school age. It was claimed that the little children suffered greatly from the want of shoes & many were sick from heavy colds, &c., largely due to the want of covering for their feet. Many cases were most pitiful and INHUMAN.

ALL SUGGESTED that the Dept. buy a set of GUM-RUBBERS, say about 150 for Oct., &c., about 250 for Dec., have the Ind. AGENT buy a few cow-hides, have same well tanned and cut into different sizes and sewed and be given to the children for Winter, this would be a cheaper way than about 40 March supply them with another pair of GUM-RUBBERS—thus all school children could be cheaply provided with footwear. Parents could buy, if able, shoes for SUNDAY for their children. Thus children could attend school, and much sickness & deaths prevented among them.

Note: We PETITION the Catholic Women's League of N.B., for all the old clothes available, to be sent to different centers to be made over for our Ind. children; at the same time we expect the Dept. to furnish yarn, &c., anything, from time to time that will aid us in our work. The Indians, &c., today, are face to face with grave difficulties. They can get but little employment, very little demand for their wares, with no profits from HUNTING, less from fishing, little or no fish, or material to work with, or at such long distances from their Reserves, that it is almost impossible for them to get same. From the above, the Dept. can readily see that it is faced with the problem of providing foodwear & much clothing to all our Ind. children.

Rev. SISTER Mary of Victory, &c., a parmer—"The best method to adopt in teaching ECONOMY to INDIANS."

We adopted

(1) Lectures to be given daily, if possible, or, as often as time would permit, on how to buy food, clothing, how to cook all foods, &c., how to care for clothing. In many cases the teachers claimed that there was a great waste about the Ind. homes, that must be corrected.

(2) The follow-up system in cooking was adopted, that is a daily memorandum of their meals and how they prepare same, the cost, &c., then followed by such instructions that will bring about better results in economy, &c.

(3) To advise INDIANS to use rubbers, umbrellas, &c., that they may save their clothing.

(4) To teach the Ind. women how to cut out their own garments, &c., children's husbands, &c., also how to spin & weave, &c., card, make mats, &c., quilts from old clothes that would otherwise be thrown away. Also to have Children & mothers save all their STOCKING LEGS, the wrists of mittens, torn sweaters, &c., that they may be repaired, new feet knitted into these old legs, new bottoms for the mittens, and new pieces knitted into the sweaters, &c.
NOTE -

All teachers claim that it will be impossible to continue successfully the Domestic Science, if the Dept. will not provide their schools with sewing machines. On any Reserve where there are over 16, or 18 children attending school, it is very difficult to provide all with clothes by hand sewing.

Mr. Fraser read a paper on Current EVENTS.

All teachers adopting many of his views which they noted down.

Rev. Father Lockery read a paper on religious Instruction, as his paper was quickly put together, it is not among those sent. However all adopted the practical methods as given by him:

He asked teachers to have children write out their prayers so they would better know all words well, and have a clearer understanding of same.

He pointed out many very simple and clear ways for the teacher that will aid them to bring about greater success in this branch of work.

The CONVENTION closed after two long days of real hard, but interesting work, covering, so the teachers claimed, more practical work than they had ever seen at any convention of teachers for the white schools.

All teachers had their NOTE BOOKS and all methods adopted were written down to be put into use at once.

Thus, all teachers have returned to their schools with more than joy, expecting to make in the school year before them, a wonderful improvement. Work that was before so difficult to both teacher & pupil, is now made easy, &c., &c., &c.

You will note that the deepest stress, at this Convention, was laid on the first GRADES, from the first to the VI, included, from this Grade up, we have little trouble, the practical methods adopted in white schools could then be followed, but the first grades are most trying, and so little progress achieved, it takes so long for Ind. children to reach the VI, & VI1, Grades. It is just this that we have set out to conquer, and all teachers claim that we have this progress well our way, since the convention.

It is therefore, with much pleasure that I submit this my REPORT (rather in a form of a SYNOPSIS) of our first Convention of the teachers of the Indian schools in N.B., thus bringing to a close one of the most important STEPS ever taken by the Dept. of Ind. education, in the history of the said schools in our Province, --one that will bring without doubt, lasting results of greater progress, not only to children, but to all our Indian people in general.

We, therefore, are most thankful in offering to the Dept. of INDIAN EDUCATION our sincere gratitude for its never tiring ZEAL, as well as its deep devotion, that has ever been manifested in our Indians and their schools in the PROVINCE OF NEW BRUNSWICK.

Humbly and faithfully submitting same to the Dept. of Ind. education for their kind and faithful consideration.

Inspector & Supt. of Ind. education for the Province of New Brunswick.

Charge & address laid before the convention of teachers of the Indian schools for N.B. - Canada. Sept. 6th, 1927.

Rev. Fathers, Professors and teachers,

I know not a greater privilege than this fortunate occasion in being able to address this, the first Convention of teachers of the Indian schools in the Province of New Brunswick.

This achievement is the crowning event of anxious years of labor and as such our Province is certainly indebted to the generosity of the Rt. Hon. Minister of the Interior, Mr. Stewart, his worthy deputy, Mr. Duncan Scott, as well as to the zeal of Mr. Ferrier Supt. of Ind. education for the Dominion of Canada, Mr. Sutherland and other faithful members of the Indian Dept. at Ottawa. Their unbounded devotion to the education of the INDIAN and their generous have today opened this broad avenue through which must now march success and progress to the two great branches that form our work in connection with the Indians and their schools in our PROVINCE, namely, that of Education and Domestic Science.

We are therefore called together for a great work, that we may seriously and carefully consider while here the many problems, that from time to time has rather impeded the course of our labors and unless solved must necessarily hamper ever desired progress. With this end in view, and with but a few days to act in, I hastily sent out to you, the teachers of our Ind. schools, subjects to be written up, which you gracefully received without a murmur, as to the shortness of time allowed for their preparation and are now about to read same, which will be listened to with deep interest, at this convention.

The idea of Christian education -----

True education must include every element or means of INTELLECTUAL and SPIRITUAL WELL-BEING, that is, Education must apply to the uplifting of the soul, and be able to meet every capacity of the soul, bringing out everything and every power that is in man's soul, and not at any time sacrificing ONE for ANOTHER, but equally faithful to the full development of ALL. At the same time carefully educating the HEART, the AFFECTIONS, the WILL, -- This later education, is as important as that of the soul, even much more so than that of the INTELLECT, -- for MAN'S MORAL life is determined by the education of the WILL and the HEART. Let man's intellect be a tower in education, this will not necessarily make him GOOD, HONEST, PURE, and OBEDIENT. Have we not today many an INTELLECTUAL man lying in the GUTTER and DEBRIS of his own FILTHY heart. Let us strive to educate the HEART, the AFFECTIONS, the WILL, then, and then alone will the mind bring out these powers STAMPED with the ONE DIVINE RESEMBLANCE thus fixed within them. -- thus having the heart, will and affections prepared, all knowledge can now be poured into the intellect, leaving to us for citizens, truely "MEN-OF-GOD".

I have only lightly touched this matter of Christian education in passing, as Rev. Fr. Lockery, our benificent host has kindly consented to address the Convention on this subject.

It will be our duty while here to discuss and go deeply into methods that might be adopted to facilitate the teaching of LETTER SOUNDS, --- &c., The Rev. Sisters of Charity, at Woodstock, have more than a natural talent along this line, that will provide us an excellent treat on a subject that forms the most trying work for both teacher and pupil. We all realize how difficult are the sounds applied to many of our LETTERS. Our CONSTANTS cannot be perfectly uttered unless joined with a vowel; then there are the different sounds given to each vowel, & letter combinations &c., &c., &c.

How very hard must the Indian child labor and what a nervous strain must constantly be upon the teacher over the seemingly slow progress of the BEGINNER. An interesting paper will be presented on this subject at this Convention.

The need of order in the CLASS ROOM

Order in the Class room is indispensable for the success of the pupil. All here realize the restless nature of the Indian child due to the environment that daily surrounds the child in an almost FREE and UNGOVERNED HOME. You can, therefore, realize that the Indian child enters upon its first training on the day it enters SCHOOL. It will be our duty while here to discuss the best methods that should be adopted to always maintain GOOD ORDER in the Class Room.
Lessons made EASY at home -

I note that Ind. children take deeper interest, and do so much better prepare their work at home when the teacher previously explains lessons assigned, that is at the time such lessons are given. At the same time the teacher could point out some method to be followed at home that might facilitate their home work for school. Many a road I feel could the teacher thus open to the child that would make home study more interesting.

Lessons made easy in the school room -

Could not a subject that an Indian child had a fondness for be used occasionally to give it a deeper interest in harder studies? --

Example --

We all realize how passionately fond of drawing are Ind. children, then could not this their beloved work be used to strip the dryness from Geography, or from certain parts of history, or other studies, --for the geography lesson, --the Ind. child could draw a map or part of same, naming rivers, lakes, bays, mountains, towns, populations, race, imports, exports, &c., &c., or whatever would correspond to that day's lesson, Or as a REVIEW, he could draw a CANOE TRIP say from Montreal to St. John indicating on same waters to be passed through, gulfs, straits, seaports, bays, names on the way, towns, people, industries, government, people, race, when and by whom were the said places discovered, dates, &c., &c. Thus three or four subjects could be brought out together without confusion, and in such a practical way as to make a lasting impression of class work on the mind of the child. The merit of such methods, &c., will also have our consideration at this convention.

Emulation -

Emulation should be encouraged among all Ind. children by a method that the Rev. sisters of Charity will clearly place before our convention, which certainly is bound to stimulate all school work making it less burdensome to both teacher and pupil.

Textbooks -

For textbooks we have closely followed those of the WHITE schools of N.B., except in READERS, all Ind. schools using the Sadlier's series.

Re. the Arithmetic, about all teachers even in the White schools find it far from being practical, that is the McMillan edition. We therefore could use in conjunction with the above edition, the old progressive school series of KENEDY & O'HEARN. More practical histories & grammars are demanded for our Indian children.

I have a series in British history by Cecil Kerr; & Forbes, and a Canadian History by J.E. Bigby, and a number of other books that are used elsewhere in our Ind. schools for grammar, so the Teacher can use practical methods adopted by herself and so laid down by this Convention An able paper on TEXTBOOKS will be read at this gathering. However it must be our one determination to keep as near as possible to the school books as are in use in the White schools of our Province. Our standards at least from the FIFTH GRADE must ever keep abreast of the White schools, so with this IDEA before us, we will discuss this matter on its merits during this convention.

Supervision of playgrounds -

As successful teachers exercise ever care that pupils give their best attention to all instructions, and that proper order is always maintained in the classroom, so in like manner should the faithful teacher supervise the playgrounds. Games should be encouraged, that would afford active amusement, and every legitimate means should be taken to have pupils enjoy same. The GIRLS could be provided with such games apart from the boys, that would surely aid in building up in their feminine LIFE, that dignity and refinement, so essential for the future success of their RACE.

Recreation is a period that means so much for good or evil. On such occasions children often take an extravagant view of life, and what seems to them but childish pleasure in the present, later on brings but a blush of shame. Nature, the weakest at this age must be strengthened to meet its conflict later. What bright and snappy children you will find in a class room after good hearty active play. The teacher too is refreshed, so that the whole class-room resounds with progress and vigor.
Re ventilation of the classroom, I feel you ever give careful consideration. We all realize that an overheated classroom renders pupil inert, unfitting them for mental action.

Domestic Science.
Some years ago, I found it necessary for both the progress of the Indian and their schools, to inaugurate this branch of work. In many of our schools, the Ind. child came very scantily clad, and without the morning meal, and always very untidy. This branch of work is today carried even beyond the school, by faithful field matrons, into the very homes of the Indian, instructing the Indian woman in sanitary methods, good housekeeping, care of infants, the sick, economy in cooking, teaching them how to turn old things into new, and useful articles, as saving old clothes and making quilts and mats.

In school, both boys and girls are taught to economize, also to sew, to knit; many boys as well as girls now making their own stocking caps & sweaters. They must also be taught to keep their school books clean, and repaired, and taken given as to the cost of these books, had they bought same for them.

Health conditions were low on many Reserves—the simplest rules along these lines were frowned upon. Astounding ignorance in sanitary methods about everywhere manifested itself. Thus-tubercular conditions gained rapid headway, and in many instances was fast encircling & depleting the ranks of this race, at the same time, offering rather a serious menace to the WHITES wherever they came in contact with the INDIANS. I am pleased to state, at this convention, that such conditions are largely under control, yet not without sacrifice. It will be remembered well, that Rev. Sister Agnes gave her life, and many others theirs health for this great cause.

We must yet admit, that this branch of Domestic Science is but in its infancy with many, nodoubt, workable conditions still unsolved. Your valuable papers will, with our open discussion on this subject, bring about, I feel, at this Convention, other methods that will assure greater success in this most important branch of work.

A teacher's life in our Ind. schools.—It can be readily seen from my general outline and your own experience, that a teacher's life in our Ind. schools is one of great sacrifice, yet an interesting one, where the teacher is devoted to duty. I cannot but deplore a statement made by one of our teachers some years ago, to the effect, that teaching in our Ind. schools, lacked interest as well as work. Now what was really wrong in this case? This particular teacher had no room for INDIANS and much less for their children—thus school (as well as all other work) was opened and closed under an atmosphere of indifferance. There was no home preparation on the part of this teacher for the school room—less in the study of principles, or methods that might facilitate lessons, so as to leave a lasting and clear impression on the pupil. Arriving at school, nodoubt, she was often confused as to where or how the day's work should begin. Thus confusion ever reigned—therefore no success. Faithful teachers must understand, that they, like the pupils, must also prepare schoolwork after school hours. There are the weekly lectures, on honesty, Temperance, Thrift, Obedience, economy, &c., to be prepared also METHODS to be studied in order to interest pupils, as well as different ways thought out, so as to aid the Ind. child to grasp more readily the tasks assigned, &c.

In consideration of what I have here outlined and from what I will further place before you while here, together with your well prepared papers, on these and other subjects that I have not here touched, I feel we will have sufficient material for a very interesting Convention. It will, therefore, be our pleasure during these days, after a full discussion of all matters, to digest from the whole what may practically be applied for the better advancement of the work among the INDIANS so intrusted to our care in the PROVINCE of NEW BRUNSWICK.

Faithfully and humbly submitted to you at the opening of our first Convention, on this the 6th day of September, 1927.

Inspector of Indian schools for the Province of N.B.
