The best method or methods for efficient work and attention in the school room.

To teach effectively, the teacher must know facts clearly and accurately.

Every teacher, as a rule, knows enough about the subject to be taught; the problem then is the best method or methods to be employed in presenting the subject to our classes, that we may give the best results to our pupils.

If our method be one, which will arouse interest on the part of our pupils, then we will have a basis on which to ground our efficient work.

First of all, our school must be well organized and governed. This organization includes proper classification of the pupils, arranging the equipment, planning the daily programme, assigning distinct duties to the pupils, making provision for a record of their attendance and work, and giving them instruction of a general nature.

In the government of the school,
favorable conditions for health and work must be maintained, time and energy economized, the pupils' interest secured and retained, good habits formed and progress made toward accomplishing the end for which the school is organized.

The school must be organized and conducted in such a way that all its activities shall contribute to the development of high qualities of character in its pupils, and to their practical equipment for efficient members of society. It is essential that pupils should be taught in such a way that they may be able in later life to fit themselves into the conditions that exist or to bring about a change in those conditions, that are favorable to their activities. This adjustment affects our relations to people, to the things around us, and to new ideas about things.

It is necessary that teachers possess this power of adjustment, as we are often confronted with the problem of a new subject introduced in school, for it may be in dealing with some
abnormal pupil, a defective or a genius. Such a teacher will be able to lead his pupils to make adjustments, and thus secure real educational activity, as making an object larger than the model, but of the same form and proportions.

Making an article for a definite purpose, suggested by the pupil, as to cover a book etc.

Such adjustments could be required in any subject taught.

The successful teacher is he, who organizes his school, and teaches his classes that through the regular, daily work of the school, he is able effectively to inculcate the school virtues, moulding the character of his pupils, and developing their power of self-control, self-activity, and self-expression, and so make them efficient members of the social order, in which they are to find their fitting place.

All work here should be so conducted, as to relate as far as possible, the work of the school to the experiences of later life.
The problems in Arithmetic should therefore deal with matters that come within the range of practical experience.

The exercises in Grammar should be assigned with direct reference to the effect upon the pupil's power of using and interpreting language.

Good teaching, proper assignment, and intelligent application to study, will gradually develop in pupils habits of thought and action, that will make them efficient members of the social organization in which every man should be ready to play his part.

Two important functions of the school are: the correction of bad habits and the formation of good ones.

Occasions may arise for the establishment of the habit of punctuality in school.

The first step is to show the pupils the need of punctuality. In addition to the loss of time by the pupil who is late, the whole school is disturbed when he enters.

A reference to the loss of time when working for pay by the hour, will show
Punctuality is regarded in business.

The second step toward making up our mind to form the habit, as a promise of all the habits to be punctual.

The third step is to seize every opportunity for the practice of the habit, and to allow no exception to occur, until the proper habit is established.

This will probably call for a daily reminder of the promise, with perhaps some interesting lesson.

The teacher of course being a pattern of punctuality not only in coming to school, but in beginning each lesson, and in closing the school.

All the school routine should become habitual by practice, until it goes on from day to day with machine-like precision.

But the teacher has also to reform the habit of the pupils—a much more difficult task than that of forming good habits, since there is the resistance offered by the old habit.

The same steps must be followed—but in addition, the conditions must be made
very favorable for forming the new habit,
and unfavorable for continuing the old.

In correcting the habit of speaking indistinctly, the correct habit of speaking should be impressed upon the pupils by calling his attention to some good examples, or should also be pointed out to them, that distinct speaking in class, on the telephone, and in the shop saves time, and avoids misunderstanding.

Pupils while speaking require a proper position, with the absence of disturbing noises.

Corrections made such as these, with subjects made interesting, and the proper form of questioning, cannot fail to demand attention from the pupils while reciting.

In every recitation there are two distinct parts:—the handling of the lesson that has been prepared for the occasion, and the assignment of a new lesson.

In assigning lessons to pupils, the teacher must make each lesson stand out in the child's mind, as something definite to be done.
Much attention must be given to the nature and training of the child. Each pupil must be appealed to in terms of his interest, and knowledge of the subject in hand. In this way he will be taught how to study his subject intelligently—that is, he will exactly know what is demanded of him in the preparation of his lesson.

Intelligent study demands accurate observation, concentrated attention, and memorizing what is observed. The child will then have used his senses, his reason, and his memory—which have results in his later life.

One of the school's greatest sources of waste is the teaching of facts in isolation. A fact learned from any book is more or less isolated, so far as its real meaning for the child is concerned, until it has been found in some other relations.

Good books, maps, etc., may be used for such helps, or perhaps some books than one used on the same subject, with for reading, or studying, is helpful.
Such preparatory work has an interesting effect upon the lesson of the following day. With this interest from pupil and teacher, the class will unconsciously have an absorbing interest in the lesson, which will in itself demand the attention required in school on the part of the pupil.

Dear Fathers and Fellow Teachers,

We are assembled in Convention today as we were also two years ago, to mutual benefit and for the purpose of discussing educational problems, which especially concern our work among the Indian children of New Brunswick.

I have been invited by our Provincial Inspector to bring to your attention and discuss for a few moments a subject of vital importance in the educational work being done in entirety of the Indians.

Does a religious atmosphere in the school room influence the Indian child in more efficient class work?

Childhood is the impressionable period. It is the impressionable stage, and the importance of things taught is measured by their effect on conduct. The child must early be accustomed to consider actions from the viewpoint of right and wrong. A religion of the head, and of the heart—intellectual, spiritual, spiritual and ethical—should form part of the child's life.

If the child grows in knowledge of secular things, vital truths should be imparted to the end that his development may not be one-sided—that he may grow in knowledge of God and right.

In the purely secular school, only the secular morality may be taught, and whatever our opinion of this system of ethics may otherwise be, it is manifestly deficient in the power which appeals to the heart and the conscience.
The child lives in a world which imagination creates, where faith, hope, and love, appear as images of beauty and delight. The spiritual and moral virtues, which are to become the very life-breath of his soul, are thus presented mystically, not confusing, but in a wonderful way, and thus the child learns automatically as he lives without effort, eyes fixed to see that he is a child of God, the infinitely good and all-wonderful.

And we prefer to believe instead, and yet avoid the name to be spoken in the lock-room, where we seek to train the little ones as is done in the Baptist schools?

Education is the end of education, such as Christ gave the schools, the ideal character, who for over nineteen hundred years has been the chief inspiration to righteousness, and heroism; to whose words patriots and reformers have appealed in their struggles for liberty and rights, and to whose planning the modern age owes its faith in the brotherhood of man?

What is the value of education? Education equips for the struggle for existence; for the race for wealth and place. It gives command being the capacity for higher life, for finer pleasures, for the highest freedom. It is the key which unlocks the secrets of nature; it is the password to the delightful world of the best human thought and achievements, making the wisest and noblest, who
have lived since my being, the familiar acquaintance of all rightly cultivated minds. It makes us able to gain a livelihood, and what is infinitely more precious it inspires the wisdom which shows us how to live.

The teacher's main business is to awaken and confirm interest in the things which make for power and value; life for interest, comfort, and kindly attention, and interest and attention result in education, and amazement which are the characteristics of cultivated minds.

It is easy to live in things which interest us. In rightly educated minds, intellectual culture is inseparable from moral culture. Real character is the only foundation on which the temple of life can stand symmetrical and secure; and hence, the aim and end of education is to form character. It is youth by right education to make saints discreet, heroes of words, truth lovers of laws, tragic super-mindfulness to the curious, and nobility to the amanuendus.

There is urgent need in our day that the young may be made to feel that virtue is power, courage, wisdom, joy, sympathy, and blessedness; that they may learn reverence and obedience, respect for others, that genuine progress is progress of spirit, that in all stations, human and divine, piety is the indispensable thing, useful alike, for the life which now is and for that which is to be.
The religious atmosphere is the natural medium for the development of character; in religion is the actual element in character.

A religious atmosphere in the school room promotes the spirit of reverence, of gentleness, and of obedience, of modesty, of purity, which is very essential for the well-being of the school; it also tends to give the Indian child a desire for what is excellent. It is good for health, strong, brave and hardy, but it is also good for virtues and way. In this way he is stimulated to do better work and to perform his lessons more carefully. This striving after perfection, blessed and dignifies life.

Spiritual exercises, such as prayers, loud songs, etc., exercise the faculties of the soul, the memory, the intelligence, the will, and make him stronger in the path of right willing, and right living and thus bring out the better self.

All this being true, what serious fact, should we not want to give our Indian children a firm well-grounded and deep religious instruction and training in their schools. To better effect this end, nothing could be more suitable than to have an altar erected in the school room, before which they could regularly offer up their prayers.

If we can interest them sufficiently to assist us in the erection of an altar in the schoolroom, our hope of directing
and guiding their minds and hearts in His will is quite secure.

They first act daily before routine work begins in school, to think of God and to pay Him what He rightly deserves, first and foremost in their minds and hearts.

Next, kneeling in respectful posture before the altar, with all diviner conditions suggestive of humility, reverence, faith, and adoration, they offer their prayers and ask for the favors which they need for themselves and blessings thereby for the success of this work.

Next, too, they consecrate their thoughts and their work daily to God, so that all their actions are as prayers in His sight.

On the altar stands the statue of the Sacred Heart, bringing to their minds the holy life, the noble deeds, the pure mind, the generous heart of Him whom it represents, and encouraging and urging them to follow His example.

Here also shines the light, which burns for their attention and which tells them that Christ is the light of the world, living in the world, ready to help those who are willing to help themselves. And therefore are led to make up their minds to spare no pains to get for themselves a good education, and to upbuild their being to its full height.

Frequently during the day, their
minds are directed towards God by the recitation of ejaculations and the whole school atmosphere is aglow with God's holy light. If the close of the day's work, special prayers are offered. And so the work proceeds from day to day, and from week to week, until may we hope, strong habits are formed in the young and growing minds of order, regularity, punctuality, obedience, reverence, respect, truthfulness, honesty, industry, and above all, the seeking after, and the desire to know Him, love Him, and serve Him, and be happy with Him forever in heaven.

If it could be so thoughtless as to say that a religious atmosphere in our schools does not act as a strong factor in helping us to make of ourselves what God intended them to be—men and women whose minds are open and enlightening, whose hearts are pure and sympathetic, whose purposes are high and religious. And if they become such stimulus both to what pursuit they may turn in after life, for whatever their occupation, honor, truth and intelligence, shall go with them bearing like mercy, a blessing to Him that gives and Him that takes.
Gordie

That the school and the home are united is evident. Children go to school with their hearts open, and they return at night carrying it in mind that the spirit of the school will aid progress.

The Indian child, as a rule, has a very unfavourable home life, chiefly due to lack of equipment, unsanitary conditions, and home training. When the Indian child begins school, he enters a new environment entirely. The life of the Indian child hitherto had been one of absolute freedom, for Indian parents make little effort to train their children. How the Instinct of Reverence may be used to promote efficiency in the class-room.

Reverend Father Inspector, Reverend Fathers, Reverend Sisters and Fellow Teachers.

The subject of my paper is the important part which the sense of reverence plays in the class-room. Reverence means holding in religious respect, and with my knowledge of Indian life, I find religion is an important part in the life of an Indian and one of the greatest factors in training the Indian child.

Reverence for Authority: Authority comes from Almighty God and children should be taught to respect authority for that reason. Advantage should be taken of every opportunity to teach obedience to authority and respect for the property and rights of others. If this is impressed on the pupils the teacher will have very little difficulty in enforcing regulations.

Anything that is taught to pupils as part of their religion will be remembered longer and more assiduously adhered to than if taught as part of a school programme where the teacher
gains her ends by asserting authority as coming directly from her alone, and any breach of a rule must be satisfied to her and her alone. If we make a child see that this breaking of rules is contrary to the teachings of our religion and in direct opposition to our Lord's desires, we have a remedy much simpler and better than any meted out by a mere teacher and thereby promote more efficiency in the class-room by saving both time and labor as it lessens the number of punishments usually used by the teacher.

An altar to the Blessed Virgin should be erected in every class-room. The pupils may have full care of this altar under the supervision of the teacher. The pupils gaining the greatest number of merits for the week, have the privilege of caring for the altar during the following week. This has some very good effects—It promotes devotion to the Blessed Virgin, a devotion dear to the heart of every Indian child; it causes the child to regard the class-room as they would the church and thus eliminates to some extent the un-necessary noise.
misconduct etc found in many class-rooms.

Character Building. The home influence is of course the best character builder, but as this influence is lacking in most of our Indian homes this development falls upon the school. If there is something about the school such as pictures, statues and other religious articles which effectively though silently speaks of the Presence in the world of an All-seeing Power and reminds the pupils that each one has to answer to that power for the deeds of life you may readily see the influence on character which will follow.

Development of Sense of Reverence. We find the sense of reverence may be developed in teaching the different branches of our curriculum, for instance, in teaching Literature we may develop this sense by singing hymns, by the lives of the Saints and by the many parables found in our readers. We may also develop manners and morals by examples of character and conduct.

In teaching nature we find both man and nature are manifestations of the great
Divine Mind, therefore we must train the child to see in Nature the Spirit of Deity.

Likewise with the majority of our studies, if the pupil perceives in them this sense of reverence he will more readily put into practice the instructions of the teacher.

August 23, 1929.

The part that religion plays in Indian education

Of the three factors of education, namely the mental, moral and physical training, the moral training is by far the most important. At the reserve school many Indian children do not seem to make any use of their education but their character remains with them through life.

Habits form your character. Good habits conducive to right living and noble character; bad habits to the opposite. The task remains almost totally to the teacher to break the bad habits of the Indian children and to install good ones in their stead.

As habits are often formed unconsciously by command has little effect in preventing the formation or breaking bad habits. Have the child understand that such habits mean failure in all things and perhaps despair to our fellow creatures.

If a teacher wishes her pupils to be kind, peaceful, truthful, charitable and the like, she must above all be living examples of these qualities. Many important morals we attempt to impart to the child do not seem to impress him, but your actions especially if wrong speak louder than words.

The catechism lesson offers an opportunity to form the character of a child. This subject like all other school subjects must be made interesting. Short original stories that correspond to the lesson not only interest and help the child to understand but may impress
him so much that the moral will remain with him always.

In all classes but especially in the lower grades the simplest and most effective way to impart religious instruction is through the use of songs. Large coloured ones are most impressive. That this method be successful the teacher's collection of pictures must be extensive and she must renew it frequently to prevent monotony.

Care should be taken that the catechism lesson be not too mechanical. The pupils may be asked to repeat their answers by heart but they should also be able to explain their meaning. She requires an explanation by the teacher when assigning the lesson the previous day.

The teacher should use every means within her reach to promote greater faith among the Indians by encouraging them to receive communion frequently and to hear Mass every Sunday. The child's environment tends to counteract this attempt and it is only by convincing the child of the importance of these religious duties that the desired goal may be reached.

Each school session should be opened and closed by prayer. Require a different child to say the prayers each time. This acts as an incentive towards learning and remembering their prayers.

The little altars introduced in our schools certainly brought about a spirit of greater devotion. I believe that they have provided a source of common interest to the pupils, parents and teacher. For example...
Some time ago I asked the people if they would like to have a flower garden, but I did not get much response. This year I asked them again if they would bring seeds in order to have flowers to decorate our altar and all who could brought some, and when Harbour Day came how they worked hard at this garden. In every other way this altar seems to bring about a spirit of good will.

A few sacred pictures and a cross should be in all Catholic schools. The words "God See Us" written on our blackboards reminds the scholars that their work of the day is for God. In order that these words will not be forgotten I require the pupils to write them on top of their slates before beginning to work.

When teaching other subjects such as literature and reading by using stories that come up casually the teacher may do much good to determine the child's ideals.

Good discipline in the classroom should lead to right actions. For example discourage fighting and you are teaching peace. In this manner you may impress upon the minds of the Indians the need to be honest, peaceful, charitable, obedient, industrious and the like.

If you can get the Indian children to conduct themselves well, not through force but because they know that fair play is the only right way, you have accomplished a lot. The habits formed in childhood remain nearly always throughout life.

Mrs. Tumblay
Rev. Inspector, Rev. Sisters, Fellow Teachers:

I have been asked to discuss the methods used to overcome the natural shyness of my Indian pupils. If since our last meeting, in the opinion of our Reverend Inspector, I have made some little progress along this line, I am very grateful for the opportunity of passing along to those engaged in the arduous duties of instructing the young Indian population of our Province the methods which, to my mind, are most likely to produce results in this direction.

While the shyness of the Indian child is noticeable in many ways, the one with which we are most familiar, is the shyness or timidity which manifests itself in the reading of lessons or the answering of questions concerning the lesson we are dealing with. The first requisite in overcoming this condition in our schools, is the possession and use by the teacher, of a voice which is loud and distinct. I realize fully well that our voices are not all strong enough to stand up under the load imposed upon the voice by continual loud speaking. But if we wish to meet with success, we must use this potent agency as much as possible. If we speak to our children with a voice which is devoid of timidity, in a very short time the child in reading and answering questions with considerable less shyness than previously displayed.

Having arrived at the point where your school has shown some improvement in speaking louder, the teacher must not feel that she may rest on her new laurels, and I find that the expression "Please speak loud" is never amiss and should be repeated indefinitely.
I think we have all, at some time or other, felt humiliated when an unexpected visitor stepped into our school, and when a class was called to read, to find that they suffered for the time being, a loss of voice and naturalness displayed when with the teacher alone. This is a form of shyness which I believe is best overcome by the encouragement of visitors to the school. It helps considerably to have the visitor, on certain occasions, hear the lesson or address the class.

A great deal of the shyness displayed by the Indian child comes from fear, and consequently a teacher can make little progress in overcoming shyness in her pupils unless there is an understanding between the two. We must treat our Indian children as friends, and encourage conversation between the pupils and ourselves. Shyness is also present due to the fact that most of our children are not overly familiar with the English language. I find that certain periods set aside for English conversation between the pupils, with the teacher making necessary corrections, not only overcomes shyness, but makes them familiar with the language we are endeavoring to impart. I insist at all times on English being spoken on the school grounds and in the school house, and although the enforcing of this regulation requires strict vigilance on the part of the teacher, the advantageous results are soon noticed and the teacher may feel well repaid for whatever she puts forward in this direction.

Competition between the pupils themselves is an aid in doing away with the shyness the children manifest in the class room. I find aid along this line is derived by allowing the children to engage in debates, dividing the older children into two sides and the teacher assigning some simple subject for debate. Allow each child to
Write his or her own impressions and read them at the proper time before one of the class who acts as chairman. The rivalry established for the time being, between the two sides, inspires each with extra confidence which gradually helps to dispel the natural shyness of the children of both sides.

I think you will all agree with me that in most cases the bright child is not troubled with shyness as much as the duller child. Therefore any exercise which tends to really brighten the child's mind is an aid in overcoming natural shyness. During the last year I have used the following method considerably. I place before each child in turn the same picture. I allow each child, say, one minute to examine the picture, and then set down in words the different objects the child noticed in the picture and what impressions he received concerning the objects. It is really surprising the number, color and description which are transmitted and imprinted on the Indian child's mind in the short space of a minute. There are many ways in which this exercise may be performed and I find that each time it is tried it helps somewhat in removing some of the natural shyness of the Indian child.

To my mind one of the greatest chances the teacher has to overcome the natural shyness of the Indian child, is during the two periods of the day which are devoted to recreation. Play with your children on the school grounds, and the realization soon dawns on the child, that the teacher is somewhat human, and not a cold, austere pedagogue whose only duty in life is to preserve order and decorum in the class room. The more the children realize that the teacher is a human being, the further into discard is pushed the former shyness displayed by the child.
I am a great believer in teaching Current Events, especially those which have to do with the civic life of our country, to our Indian children. The Indian child is interested in this study, and I know of no better way of overcoming shyness than by occasionally giving this work some little place in the curriculum of the school.

The foregoing are the methods I have used to overcome the natural shyness of my pupils. In summing up I would say:- Speak loud and distinctly at all times and insist on the child's answering in the same manner. Have frequent visitors to the school and have them examine the pupils. Endeavor at all times to be on a friendly working basis with your pupils. Introduce as frequently as possible into your class, competitive and brain building exercises. Play with your children at recreation periods. Interest your Indian child in the country in which he lives, and above all insist upon your Indian child speaking English at all times when under your supervision.
The Indian Child's instinct of Justice in Right and Wrong Punishment.

The subject of punishment in Indian Schools is one that will bear a great deal of discussion, and one that always presents a multitude of arguments for and against.

Children are all agree to punishment of every kind; yet the child's instinct which has developed points out to him right from wrong must naturally lead him to see the justice of punishment for wrong actions, as he respect and delight in rewards for good. Very often the child may through ill training develop a one sided view of this argument. Here then is a task that lies with us teachers to administer punishment in such a way, so that the instinct of the Indian child will grasp the justice of the act, in the same manner as he would delight in

We all recognize the fact that those very boys and girls in our classes today will in time become the men and women of the nation; hence the growth or lack of the decay of the nation is in a measure in the hands of its teachers. This is most particularly true of Indian teachers, for as a general rule, we find manifest in Indian homes a weakening in parental control and home training. This of course has a corresponding tendency to throw extra obligations on the teacher. The chief agencies for the training of children are the home, the church,
and the school. The closer these are associated the better will be the result for the boy or girl. The home comes first, and no matter how competent or zealous the clergyman or teacher may be, he can never supply the want of proper home training. One of the first things a teacher is wise to do is to get acquainted with the home life of the pupils— their environment, their parent, big brothers and sisters. A sympathetic acquaintance with these will help to a better knowledge of the children and will be of great value in dealing with individual peculiarities during the year. Furthermore it will prevent possible trouble in another way, for parents sometimes through the exaggerated reports of children get a distorted view of the character and personality of the teacher and this jeopardizes his or her honest efforts to be of use in the community.

The successful failure
of the school, as an agency for the training of the pupils, lies almost entirely in the hands of the teacher. For six hours every day it is practically the home of both the teacher and the pupils, and instead of being thought of as the cold, dark, and repulsive thing that it too often is, it should be the centre of attraction, enlightenment, and progress to which both young and old look for guidance and inspiration. The school should be the centre of clean and healthful amusement and its all-round atmosphere should vibrate with steady progress along every line of enlightened human endeavor; for no investment gives a higher return than the money, time and energy spent in training boys and girls to become useful and efficient members of the community.
Some thoughts and ideals common to the Indian child both in the Material and Spiritual life that may be of use in Early Language and Reading Lessons.

The problem of Primary Reading is one of the most complex and difficult in the whole range of school instruction. Much time has been expended to find the appropriate and natural method of teaching children to read.

Reading and Language should be taught, one in connection with the other.

In early years the minds of children may be enriched with ideas through stories told in the way of oral language.

Indian children have many thoughts and words common to them that may be used in school in telling them stories to give a foundation of English for a mind filled with ideas is quicker to learn than a mind barren of thought. The interest aroused in the stories transfers itself to the reading lessons and gives greater spirit to the efforts at learning to read in the Primary Grade.

In placing topics before children
it is always advisable to touch up the knowledge already possessed by them. The crudest efforts of little children must be received with kindness and encouragement. A great difficulty is to get correct English on account of home influence so it makes the work an uphill task; still with effort it can be accomplished.

The Indian child is familiar in the Material world with tent, bow and arrow, trees, canoe, birds animals and the names of children.

We can take advantage of this, tell stories concerning them in order to give the child some form of expression.

Again in the Spiritual life of the child it has thoughts and words concerning God that may be used in the telling of Bible History stories. All these increase the child's vocabulary which is so important in the training of the child to read.

After the child has some knowledge of language and it can reproduce to some extent the story told, short sentences including its oral words may be placed on the board by the teacher. Each child reads these and is
soon able to point out the words. As new words are learned they may be placed among others for drill. The Indian child has a great love for his dog and he also has the thought that God loves him. If the language lesson has something about a dog, the child's interest is immediately aroused and a reading lesson can be taught at the same time.

Thus: "I love my dog."

God loved me.

I love God, etc.

After a few lessons some simple words are taken from which to learn the sounds; the sounds are associated with the letters. These letters are met in other words and as soon as a number of sounds and letters have been learned new words can be formed by dropping a letter or adding one.

Throughout Language and Reading must be combined; one as a help to the other.

After the child has acquired some knowledge of reading he must be taught the further expression which is more easily secured if the child is interested in the lesson and this can be accomplished by proper questioning and occasional examples by the teacher.
Correct emphasis will naturally follow.

From the first the child should be encouraged to articulate distinctly and not allowed to say e.g., las for last. In the case of white children they usually correct themselves later but an Indian child generally speaking continues an old habit.

We must also strive to get vitality into the voice. To aid in this have a child act out something as fishing, playing ball, etc., and then have another child tell what he did. Practice in this will give force to his utterance for children are anxious to give to others what they know and also to give it in such a way as to be understood.

In no other subject of the curriculum has the teacher so great an opportunity for producing the right impression on the mind of the child as in the early language and reading lessons presented to him. These to be effectual must deal with subjects common to his environment and by means of objects of which the child has a concrete perception he may be taught many lessons which will help him both spiritually and materially and what is more to
the point by these means many of the defects inherent in his race may be at least suppressed if not eradicated.

The Indian child can scarcely ever be driven as the obstinacy and stupidity of his mind would work against such methods but if persuasive methods be used the child can be led to do through kindness and trust those things which coercion would fail to secure.

In the selection of materials for reading I think there is nothing better than the Beacon Chart now in use in our schools together with the prescribed readers. The Pictorial illustrations add beauty and clearness. They deal with both the Material and Spiritual life of the child and contain many thoughts and words familiar to him.

Reverend Inspector, Reverend Sisters, Fellow Teachers:

In my experience with the Indians, I have always found them very observing, and I think one of the best methods to interest them in thrift is by trying to show them by your own example, just what you want them to do. For instance take the children. Mostly, if a button was needed on their clothing the first question they would ask was "Where will I get a button?". I have a button box in which I keep all kinds of buttons. This is brought continually into use. At first it was kind of a novelty for them. Any button they would find would be given to me for the box. In a very short time they were saving the buttons at home. This is a very small item, but I find it is a great help in interesting them in thrift.

The same thing applies to pieces of twine and other kinds of string. When they needed a shoe lace, which was very often, they would come looking for twine. I would give them the box of twine and let them make their own shoe laces. In no time they had caught onto the idea of saving the twine at home. This also interested the parents, and almost without their noticing it, they had become accustomed to saving odds and ends around the house. We also have them save nails, pieces of wire, bolts etc., and not only the children come looking for them, but they have come several times, and when they found how convenient it was to have these things on hand, they became interested in the idea of doing it for themselves. Wrapping paper, paper bags, boxes, bottles, corks, pieces of soap and anything that turns up from day to day is saved, put in its place and is always on hand when needed.

Another thing that had to be overcome was in the line of clothing. Some of the children who were fortunate enough to
being a good clean housekeeper. I also explain to them that it is much healthier to have things clean, and how much easier it is to get work done when things are neat and clean. In some cases it is almost impossible for them to keep their houses looking clean. They have so little to work with. The walls and floors are so rough and hard to scrub. Screens are unknown to them. The chimneys are pieces of stovepipe through the roof. This lets in the rain and the stoves and pipes are nearly always rusty. I think if the Government would supply whitewash for them, or do something to help them fixing the insides of their houses, there would be a great change noticed in many places.

The houses are very cold in the Winter time, and when the children sleep on the floor, which they do in most places, it is impossible to keep them from taking cold. I have been able in some cases to get the men to make little wooden couches for the children, and have had the women make straw mattresses for them. This has helped some. I always encourage them to wash their old clothing and make quilts out of them. Also to keep their clothing good from season to season. That is to put their Winter clothing away during the warm weather. Sometimes these are thrown around all Summer and when the cold weather comes they have nothing to wear. This is watched especially in the case of the children. Their caps, sweaters, stockings and mittens are darned and put away so as to be ready when needed.

In summing up, I would say, that in my opinion, if you want to interest the Indians in Thrift, try to show them by your own example just what it means. Take an interest in them and in their work. Always be ready to help them in any way you can. Keep a competition worked up among the women. Explain to them how much healthier it is for themselves and their children if things are neat and clean in and around the
have two coats, insisted on wearing their good coats to school. This was discouraged from the very first. Some of them had to be told several times to wear their old coats and keep their good ones for Sunday. I explained to them that I would not think of wearing my best coat every day. In a short time their old coats were patched and worn to school. Another thing I found that helped along this line was wearing rubbers on a rainy day. They soon notice these things and become interested in thrift almost without knowing that you are trying to teach them this very thing.

Another instance which proves it is easy to interest them by your own example. Last October we bought a few hens. At that time there were about twenty-four hens on the Reserve. Several times I noticed the Indians looking the hens over. They asked all kinds of questions about them. I always made it a point to be pleasant with them and answer all their questions. One day not long after we got our hens, one of the Indians came home with ten hens. A short time after this his neighbor brought home six, another fellow bought four, several bought two and some of them started in with one. They often came and asked for information regarding the care of the hens. I always helped them all I could. Several came to me this Spring for settings of eggs, and when school closed in June there were over one hundred chickens on the Reserve, whereas last year there were no more than twenty-five.

I also find that a few words of encouragement once in a while help a great deal. Showing an interest in and always being ready to discuss their work with them, works wonders along this line.

From my experience with the women, the best way to keep them interested in cleanliness and neatness is to work up a sort of competition among them. When I go into a clean house I always compliment the woman on her work, and during the course of our conversation pass a remark about Mrs. So and So.
house. Instruct them in personal cleanliness, and always have a word of encouragement for them which will help you over many rough places.
How to Promote Higher Education among the Indians

(a) By interesting the children.
(b) By interesting the parents.

With my limited experience in dealing with the Indians, even with the children, it is not possible for me to say much that has direct bearing on the title subject.

My first suggestion in regard to the education of an Indian child is not to send it to school too young. The little mind may be easily stunted and by the time the child should really be able to grasp the allotted work it has become tired of school and looks on it as a penance or bore-dom. It will acquire a distaste or aversion for study which will increase as it advances to the higher grades; if indeed, it can be kept in school until what we might call the higher grades has been reached.
The free restless nature of the Indian child should not be restrained too much or too suddenly. The school room is not the natural element of these once children of the woods.

A good beginning makes possible a good ending, but a poor beginning, while it may terminate well doesn't give much hope for final success. Hence, if the life in the lower grades is made interesting, the child should develop a certain attraction for school work and be desirous of continuing in a sphere where it feels that a personal interest is taken in its welfare.

Cleanliness and attractiveness of the school room will make life more pleasant for the children. Work should not be presented as drudgery, but should be made as interesting as the subject will allow. All work and no play does not appeal to anyone, especially to children.
So a little recreation occasionally, such as a story or a game, a little exercise or play will help to keep the children attached to school life.

A keen but friendly rivalry should be manifested by children who are physically and mentally normal.

Their little ideas must be drawn out and encouraged. Little personal talks on what the future holds in store, as a possibility for them if they make use of present opportunities, should be some incentive to leading them to desire a more complete education which would enable them to take their places with other boys and girls in the world.*

A well educated person will earn a living much easier than one whose education has been neglected.

*The old boast "I can't read or write but I always made my living" is not unknown to the Indians.

Even the little children have a tendency to think that as they are only Indians...
they cannot expect to do or be much. This idea should not be fostered. We must lead them to see that their becoming good men and women does not depend on their race but rather on the manner in which they prepare themselves for the great events of life, and the surest foundation for this lies in the proper education.

Indian parents, are as a rule very fond of their children, but like many of our own people their affection is often misapplied in so far as they pamper the likes and dislikes of the children to the detriment of their later life.

Parents are much to blame for the want of interest and lack of energy in school work on the part of the children when the children should be getting their much needed rest at night, to fit them for the coming day, how many are on the roads or visiting in the neighbor's houses? Parents should be brought to realize that this is not giving their children justice.
Another thing the parents think nothing of keeping the children out of school one or two days each week, to wash, or take care of the baby, etc. This break in the regular work not only spoils the child's own interest but upsets the whole class.

The introduction of domestic science and manual work will make the parents realize that there is more to education than the three 'Rs'.

Praising and encouraging the parents in regard to the abilities of their children will be some inducement to their keeping the children in school and encouraging them to higher studies.

Of the realization of the proper kind of living could be brought to the parents' minds then there would be a start to advanced education on the part of the pupils toward better and higher life.
Domestic Science.

Domestic Science is a subject taught in most schools at the present day, and which should form a most important factor from the standpoint of the school and the home as well. This subject forms an important part of subjects taught in Indian schools. The science includes teaching of cooking, sewing and general housekeeping.

The teaching of Domestic Science for Indian children is even more necessary than in ordinary schools, since the children of Indian schools lack home training in this respect; the mothers being less competent than the ordinary housewife; thus the children are not instructed and are more or less careless in home duties.
In all cases, as a rule, the children make use of their school experiences in later life; so will it be with that of lessons learned in Domestic Science; they will begin to make use, as soon as they are able, of their lessons learned in School. This will affect their after life to the extent the attention has been given them in their school days.

Their home life will be much benefited by the introduction of this study in the school, not only in the saving of their food and the practice of neatness and cleanliness in their homes, but will also give a pleasing effect among themselves and their relations with others.

They will have a greater home life, and will encourage outsiders with the same spirit, thus making a better and healthier community life.

The mothers will also benefit by these lessons and example from their children,
which will make both mothers and children happier in their homes, thus the daily task of household duties will be made lighter and more pleasant for both.

Sister M. Clare P.M.
Tobique Indian Home
Maliseet, N.B.
THE ORGANIZATION OF A FIELD MATRON -- TIME AND DUTIES.

It is rather difficult to say much of interest on this subject as I have had only one year's experience in the work and besides the pioneer work on the Woodstock Reservation was done when I took up the work. However I will attempt a few words on the subject.

The instructions from the Indian Department and Reverend Father Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools, were:

First, to come to the Reservation daily during the School term at the hour of the opening of school in the morning.

To visit the homes daily so that all on the Reservation be visited at least once during the week and of course oftener when advisable.

To send a report of the conditions found and the work done once every month to the Inspector of Schools and once every three months to the Department at Ottawa. This Report is to be under three headings:

Conditions in the homes;
Hygiene and Nursing;
Domestic Science.

The Field Matron is on the Woodstock Reservation also the Domestic Science teacher and I find that in a small Reservation the two tasks can easily be handled by one person.

The work of the Field Matron must be planned by herself generally, according to existing conditions and special needs. It is chiefly that of a Social Service worker and includes a little nursing but mostly instructions to the Indian women as to the care of minor injuries such as cuts and burns, boils and abscesses; how to render first aid to the injured, etc. Then instructions to prospective mothers; how to care for themselves and what to prepare for the coming event of childbirth. Then later instructions and demonstrations on the care of the infant and proper feeding to supply the maternal deficiency which is common.

During the regular daily inspection of the home, the chief advantage is to encourage the women to improve the sanitary conditions and to induce them when possible to greater cleanliness and order in the homes. Sometimes to reprimand when they fall back or refuse to do what is reasonably asked of them. I find, of course, that reprimanding does not effect much unless mixed with encouragement all the time.

The Field Matron has also to keep in touch with the cases requiring relief so as to prevent the ones not in want from getting same on false pretenses and informing the Indian Agent when there are cases needing help, so that these be supplied with what is necessary by the Indian Department.

In regard to infections, especially tuberculosis and venereal, there is ample work for the Field Matron to
instruct the people as to both prevention of infection and care of those already infected. This is rather difficult as they often cannot be made realize the danger of the infection. With the cooperation of the physician in charge and by means of sending the worst cases for treatment to Sanitariums, the spread of the diseases may at least be lessened.

The condition of the Reservation is much improved since the work of the Field Matron was begun here. The Indian Department however also has helped to bring about this improvement as a number of houses have been built and others repaired so as to enable the Indian people to have separate sleeping rooms and better homes. There still remains much to be done.

Sister M. Katherine
Reg. N.
Woodstock Indian Hospital

Reverend Sisters and Dear Teachers of our New Brunswick Indian Schools:

Through the ever increasing INTEREST manifested in the Indian Schools of Our Province, by the Minister of The Interior Rt. Hon. Mr. Stewart, as well as that of his most worthy Deputy, Mr. Scott, likewise that of Mr. Perrier, Supt. of Indian education for Canada, together with Mr. Sutherland and all co-workers of the said Department of Indian education, we are again able to hold this our second convention. Our last convention, the first of its kind to be held in New Brunswick, or perhaps in Canada, took place between the 5th and 9th of September, 1927, at Woodstock, N.B., made possible there through the invitation of the then most worthy Pastor, Rev. Father Lockery, whose kindness on that occasion, as well as that of his dear people, cannot easily be forgotten. We are now in the hands, and largely at the mercy of the excellent Pastor of North Devon, Rev. Father Denchee, who, I am sure, will leave nothing undone to assist us, in every possible way, to achieve and even surpass, the scope of work so faithfully and earnestly carried out at our last convention.

It is a pleasure to note that most of the teachers who were at our last convention, are with us today, and a still greater pleasure to know and feel that, with but few exceptions, all have faithfully tried to make workable on the Reserves, the RECOMMENDATIONS passed at our last convention. It must be well understood that what is acted upon by these conventions, sanctioned and approved by the Department of Indian education at Ottawa, should become workable by all our teachers; otherwise our time would be lost and such meetings be but a huge failure. You will, therefore, provide
yourselves with the required note books and pencils, that you might make your own notes on what this Convention may be able to impart to you. These NOTES should be retained at school, so that I may be able, from time to time, look over same on my semi-annual visits to the Reserves. I can assure you nothing can be more discouraging to me and harmful to yourselves, as teachers in our Indian schools, when on such visits I find that the very principles adopted at our Conventions, were simply ignored. We are told that success lies in seeing our little faults and in being "BIG ENOUGH" to admit and overcome same. I feel sure of your good will and co-operation in this matter.

PROGRESS.—The success of our Indian schools remained in a balance for years. It seemed as though there was an impregnable wall that challenged further advancement. After careful research into every detail, it was found that what seemed, at first, to be unity of purpose contained the wildest divergencies, which left our Indian schools, (so unlike the white schools) without proper methods of advancement. Such difficulties could only be solved and a workable base of unity of principles and methods adopted, in a free and full discussion of same by our teachers, called in convention. Therefore, it was not until after our first Convention of September 1927, that our Indian schools solidly advanced in phalanx formation, wherever the teachers faithfully adhered to the principles initiated at that Meeting. Still, as we go on, we certainly feel a deeper need for such meetings, if progress must be maintained, and rightly so; for how in conscience could the days pass without bringing such assured success in our work as to enable us to feel that we have accomplished, in good measure, the grave responsibilities entrusted to our care, in the uplifting of a belated race to the full participation in our CITIZENSHIP.

With this end in view, let us bend every energy to promote higher education, as well as a deeper, broader efficiency
in every MORAL that must spell "A CONTINUED PROGRESS". Now,
as a guarantee for such efficiency, I carefully laid before
you, in June last, certain subjects on which you faithfully

lighten us and undoubtedly serve to remove many grave obstacles
that, heretofore, confronted us in the advancement of our work.
It will be our duty, therefore, during these days to listen
with marked attention to all papers and absorb such material
that, through the process of discussion, may be found essential
for the progress of our Indian schools.

RECOMMENDATIONS

(1) For the better advancement of pupils in many ways, I would suggest that our teachers supervise the play grounds, and do all in their power to provide and encourage such games as would afford child, the most efficient pleasure & exercise, and during such periods of recreation to induce the Ind. child to speak the English language.

(2) For your own health, as well as that of the children, may I call your attention to the grave necessity of keeping the school room scrupulously clean and well ventilated. Please make it attractive by drawings on blackboards, & flowers, &c., &c. Kindly see that all children are clean & neatly dressed, provided with handkerchiefs, and instructed how to use same, that this constant sneezing may be prevented. All sores to be promptly treated, sore eyes or any disorders requiring medical treatment, please notify the Doctor in attendance.

(3) I would kindly ask all teachers of Domestic science, — and this includes all teachers in our Ind. schools, — to instruct Ind. boys as well as the girls how to sew, knit, repair, cook, and all such practical work.

I am pleased to state that already a number of our Ind. boys have proved themselves most efficient in this line of work. They have knit a number of sweaters for themselves, & stockings, mittens, and have mastered the art of repairing old sweaters, stockings, mittens &c., by inserting needles in the stitches and knitting in all repair work, thus eliminating unsatisfactory accumulation of yarns in the very ready process of darnings, that rather reminds one of swollen glands or tumors.

(4) Finally, — let it well be remembered that upon RELIGION, as a base, must we build the whole structure of our education system. We must educate both the SOUL, as well as the HEART of those entrusted to our care.

The Soul, that precious REPOSITORY of good created by GOD for Himself — and loaned to an earthly habitation but for a little while, brings in its combination of creation, a therefore true education must be such that will develop both — the SOUL — by caring for its full intellectual and spiritual well-being in developing its whole and full capacity, by bringing out and promoting (equally) every power and everything within it, — not stifling one to strengthen the other, &c.

— (That will develop) — The Heart — the affections, the will, and all that is truly noble in the heart, for such certainly determines man's moral life! in making him good, honest, pure, obedient, just &c., &c., &c. — It is not his intellectual power and strength, — for does not our Country today possess many intellectual giants, who are everything but good CITIZENS. — Therefore, we must reach the WILL and the affections of our Ind. children — these powers must be developed, — their very souls and wills must be stamped with ONE DIVINE resemblance that has been fixed in them, thus, while we educate the heart and will on the one hand, we, at the same time, pour into their intellects every form of sound knowledge — forming both intellect and holy children.

It is self evident, therefore, that a strong religious atmosphere must pervade the schoolroom, daily strengthening within our TEACHERS deeper religious convictions well grounded upon great PURITY and SINCERITY of SOUL. Under such conditions the CHILD OF BETHLEHEM becomes the teacher, while our Ind. children daily grow in Wisdom and age, — Such an education is the sole guarantee of good and lasting citizenship to any COUNTRY.

Rev. Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of the minutes of the second convention of teachers of Indian schools in New Brunswick held at North Devon September 2nd to 4th, last, at which all teachers, with the exception of those of the Burnt Church School, were present. The various papers prepared and read by the teachers were also received. The minutes of the convention, together with your address, as well as the various papers prepared by the teachers of the schools on the different matters affecting their work, have been read with a great deal of interest. It is hoped that the convention will prove of great benefit and be productive of results both for teachers and pupils. The Department desires to thank you for the interest and trouble taken by you in making the convention a success, and also to thank the teachers for their attendance and the papers prepared and discussed by them.

Relative to the recommendation of the convention that sand tables, sewing machines and dustbans be supplied each school, I have to say, with reference to the sand tables, that the teachers should requisition through their local Indian agents for this equipment. It is thought that these tables could be made locally at less expense than purchasing same through a school supply firm. When forwarding the requisition, the cost of building the table should be given. When the requisitions are received by the Department favourable consideration will be given to authorising having the tables built.

Relative to the supplying of sewing machines for use in domestic science work, as you are, no doubt, aware machines were supplied to the Woodstock and Tobique Schools. It has been found that where equipment of this nature has been supplied to Indian schools elsewhere than in New Brunswick that they became easily damaged on account of being used when the teachers were not present to oversee the operation of same.

The Department will supply a reasonable quantity of dust-bans upon receipt of requisitions. In fact, one or two of the teachers have lately requisitioned for this material and the agents have been authorised to purchase same.

The account which you submitted covering the travelling expenses, etc., of the teachers and yourself was received, and cheques have been sent.

I have been invited by my School Inspector the Reverend Mr. Ryan to compose a report upon how quickly the interest of the Indian community in the success of my school.

For my experience among the Indians I find that in some instances it is not always an easy matter to interest them in the work and success of their children. Nevertheless I have outlined a few suggestions and remarks that may in some instances prove effective.

The interest of the Indians may be quickened by pointing out to them how of this age of advanced education so many are making rapid strides in the acquisition of knowledge, as well as showing them why the flame of their zeal should not be allowed to flicker and soon become a bygone.

Tell them what educated people have done and are doing, not only among the whites, but also among the Indians of the west. Plan friendly talks with the parents of your pupils either at their homes or when any opportunity presents itself. Let them see that you are not working merely to earn a salary, but that you are deeply interested both in the spiritual and temporal welfare of their children. If their attendance at school has been very regular show that you are pleased, and hope that this may continue.
Remark to them how well their children are progressing, due to their regular attendance.

On the other hand, the attendance has been somewhat irregular—express your regret that such has been the case, and point out that even a day from school now and again retards the progress of child.

Lucy may be missing her catechism lesson and morning prayer because she had to wash the breakfast dishes. Barney may miss a morning session, because he was sent to the country store some little distance away. Suggest that the children arise a little earlier, that they may be punctual for lessons, and present at each session.

Although the Indian people do not always seem deeply religious, still I think that down deep in the Indian heart there is a great love for the faith. So you may be able to appeal to them from a religious viewpoint. Tell them how much better the educated child understands his or her religion, and when assisting at Mass for instance is provided with a prayer book can follow the parts of the Holy Sacrifice as the priest continues, and as a result will doubtless assist with greater devotion; also in many cases the child will be able to explain many important things to the parents.

How the Teachers Can Cultivate the Indian Child's Love of Drawing

As a teacher of Indian children I have found that drawing is one of their most attractive subjects and the children derive much pleasure and gratification from it. Of course the little child who has not tested his powers to reproduce objects goes instinctively at his first attempt to make a pretty picture. At first he fails and this is so discouraging that he is apt to give up drawing entirely with a frown; so to get the young child interested in drawing I give him a simple object to draw, for instance a cat. I draw it on the black board keeping as closely to the ordinary appearance as possible with a few straight lines. Then even though the child goes pretty wide of the mark strangely enough he still gets something resembling a cat which pleases and encourages him so I have noticed that after drawing a few of these objects the child begins to take an interest in seeing things more clearly, to draw them better and to soon enjoy drawing more.

In its larger sense drawing means the graphic
expression of an idea, so when we come to a lesson in which the child lacks interest for instance a history lesson or a way if the child draws a map of the place he has seen and markers marking the features he will find it more interesting and this will always help him to remember the lesson. In geography if a child draws a map of a country he has seen a sketching and making in the rivers lakes cities, towns and imports etc., he is certainly more likely to remember them than if the map has not been drawn. Even in arithmetic in which the Indian child is so often trailing will again come in useful for example questions in the calculation the places more interesting if the figures are drawn and the pictures placed on them. In the lower grades if arithmetic is taught by means pictures on the black board it will be more easily remembered. Therefore I think that in almost any subject if drawing is introduced the child will be more willing to study.
