Reverend Fathers, Reverend Sisters, Fellow Teachers,

I have been requested by our School Inspector Reverend Father Ryan to write a short paper on "The Best Method of Starting the Indian children to read English."

In the majority of cases the Indian children have acquired little or no English before entering the school, and are to be introduced to a language to which they are, one might say, complete strangers. When the little ones begin school, the teacher should show them by her kindness and sympathy, that they can count on her as their friend. When this friendship is established, the work of the teacher is made...
much easier.

As simplicity is a marked characteristic of the Indian children, the teacher should endeavor as far as possible to use this feature in presenting all subjects.

Formal lessons in English Reading should not be begun with Indian speaking pupils until they have acquired a little vocabulary of English words.

I take my Bible class and talk to them about their pets, show them pictures of dogs and cats and other things, teach them the names of the parts of the body—hair, ears, eyes, teeth, fingers, toes, etc., also the names of the different articles of clothing such
as dresses, buttons on dresses and pockets on dresses, shoes, stockings. The teacher points to the objects, gives their names and has them repeated by the pupils until they are quite familiar with them. The children soon become interested and this is most important. Test the children by asking them questions about what they have learned. I asked one of my little girls "where are the buttons on your dress?" after I had taught the names so reviewing it very carefully carefully she looked up with a little smile and said "No Buttons". Another was asked to show her pocket. She looked at her dress and finding none said "No pocket". No every Indian school is provided
with an altar, the children's attention should be called to it. Ask them what they see. Some will point to the crucifix, others to the statue and others again to the flowers. Tell them the names of what they see. Speak to them about God, that He is in Heaven that He loves them etc., show them how to kneel and join their hands in prayer. Now and again difficulties may arise in making the children grasp the meaning of what is being said. Some of the older pupils might be called upon to give a little explanation in the mother tongue, but I think this should be the exception and not the rule.

By the time the little ones have
become acquainted with their new surroundings so they may be started on a simple reading lesson. Great care should be exercised by the teacher in bringing the children to class to see that all slovenly habits in walking and standing are avoided as these are apt to cause carelessness in reading.

Here is a plan for first reading lesson. After the pupils are assembled in class they are told to close their eyes, the teacher indicating what they should do by closing her eyes. The picture of a ball is presented, and the children are told to open their eyes and tell what they see. Then one child tells that he sees a ball, and the
of what he said is printed on the blackboard. Touch each child saying "see." The children read it from the board, and the teacher shows them the same sentence on the chart and asks them to read it, placing the pointer under the sentence.

Next day review the sentence that was taught the previous day and present other objects or pictures such as a picture of a kitty and a dog. When these are shown have a child tell the teacher what he sees and then use the blackboard printing "I see a kitty" and "I see a dog." Then have a little talk with the children about their own dogs, their names etc., tell them that we are going to
call this dog "Lover" and then print "See Lover." Drill the class on "See" which begins each sentence and show them that the endings are different. Like plants may be used for the following lessons.

Phonetics which are a great aid in word getting should be introduced as soon as possible to the Indian children. The teacher's aim in the teaching of phonetics is the training of the ear and the voice before the training of the eye, and the telling of a simple story is helpful in presenting a phonograph. But as we are dealing with Indian children who are unfamiliar with the English language, it might be deemed advisable...
to teach phonetics as well as unphonetic words as sight words for a while, probably for first and second months, according to the capability and intelligence of the class; the teacher should use her own judgment in this matter. When the lessons in phonetics are introduced they are to be given apart from the reading lessons.

Individual work is necessary.

As previously stated a story is helpful in teaching phonetics as it is intended to excite interest, and to serve as a background to aid the memory. From the sheets of flash cards cut along the dotted lines, the cards containing the nine consonants "g," "j," "r," etc., and the one vowel "a." Master the story on the reverse side of the card containing the
symbol "s" so that you can tell it well. The following story may be used to teach the sound of the letter "s."

Once upon a time there was a little boy called Tom. When playing in the yard one day he felt hungry so he ran into the house for a lunch. His mother was in the house getting dinner. "Dinner will soon be ready," said mother. Listen to the tea kettle. It says "s-s-s." This is a picture of what the kettle said. Then teach the vowel "a" as in "fan."

The next step is teaching the blend of the two sounds. Teaching the blend of the consonant and the following vowel is an essential feature of this method.
These blends, -"ea", "fa"-etc may be called helpers, since they help the pupil toward the pronunciation of words which are now to be formed. Drill the individual pupils until each child can pronounce all of them instantly.

The sound of vowel "a" is to be taught as "fan".

Do not be discouraged by the apparent inability of the pupils to blend the sounds. Keep at it until each pupil can blend the two sounds of the first helper "ea", so they are pronounced in "sat," "sand" and "sad." Then see if the children can unite each of the helpers with the consonants sounds already taught.
Flash cards are of great assistance in the teaching of reading. Provide the children with cards having the words they have already learned, and ask them to arrange these words in sentences.

In teaching all lessons from the chart the blackboard should be used freely. Insist upon good expression and discourage all parrot-like reading.

When the Primer is completed the First Reader should be begun, continuing daily drill on phonetics. A few simple suggestions which apply to all reading:

Insist upon clear enunciation and correct pronunciation.

Proper inflection and attention to all punctuation marks.
Never allow a child to read anything he does not understand. Therefore before giving a child a lesson all unfamiliar words should be written on the blackboard and clearly explained.

All head movements are to be avoided also the use of the finger as a pointer. To handle the book properly and to stand correctly.
Reverend Fathers, Reverend Sisters, Mr. Chairman and Fellow Teachers,

My opinions have been consulted regarding the "Teaching of Domestic Science as the help maid to the advancement of Indian Schools."

Domestic Science is not so applicable for lower grade pupils as in the higher grades, and it cannot be carried out on a large scale because (1) The allotted time does not permit extensive work where there are a large number of pupils. (2) The usual home training does not furnish a basis on which to enlarge on this subject.

Owing to the fact that the time-table allows only a few hours a week for Domestic Science very little work can be accomplished.
however Domestic Science is taught under the following headings: Sewing, Knitting, Patching, Cooking, Lectures, Quilting, Making mats, and Miscellaneous Subjects.

In Sewing we teach the cutout patterns of handkerchiefs, towels, pillow cases, aprons, dresses, and shirts; the making of these articles by plain hand stitching.

In Knitting, we first teach the pupil the plain stitch used in knitting scarfs, while the pupils in the higher grades knit sweaters, stockings, mittens, and gloves. During May and June as the pupils complete their allotted work they are obliged to wash, and return their last year stockings and mittens. Then, they are shown how to knit in new knees, heels, toes or feet as the article
requires; in the case of mittens
the wrists are saved for new
mittens.

Patching is important because it
teaches the child to be neat and
tidy; and it makes their clothes
wear longer. When a hole occurs
in a pupil's dress, trousers or stock-
ings we teach them how to mend
it immediately.

In Cooking we teach the pupils
the methods of preparing simple, nut-
ritious dishes, such as: The making
of breads, biscuit, muffins, oatmeal
porridge etc. Owing to depression the
government did not supply any
material for cooking during the past
year, therefore, all that could be
done was to give lectures on the
subject, and no demonstrations could
be given.
Lectures are given occasionally on foods, and their values, health, and miscellaneous subjects.

When what I considered the more necessary work was finished I found that I didn't have time for the making of quilts and mats, but I intend in the near future to take up this work with my advanced pupils.

Miscellaneous subjects might include any conditions that may arise, aside from the regular Domestic Science program.

The object in teaching the different branches in Domestic Science to an Indian child is to (1) Cultivate cleanliness (2) To give them a working knowledge of housekeeping, and the making and mending of their own clothing etc. (3) It also forms
a relation between the school and
the home. (4) The making of articles
of clothing enables the child to
attend school with suitable cloth-
ing.

As I have outlined my views
on this subject, I am now prepa-
red to receive, and will appreciate
any criticism that may arise.

I thank you.
Reverend Fathers, Reverend Sisters, Fellow Teachers:

The subject of my paper is "The Teaching of Domestic Science in my school."

The teaching of Domestic Science in our Indian schools has for its main object the training of the Indian children in the habit of thrift, and never in the history of our school has it been more needed than at the present time. If this habit is fostered through the school life of the children it will no doubt be practiced to a certain extent at least in the years to follow.

The hour set apart for this work is hailed with delight by my pupils. The little ones love to have a pair of bright knitting needles and a ball of colored yarn put into their hands.

I start my beginners knitting with two needles. They are told they must learn the plain and rib stitches, and then they
may begin to knit something they can wear. Every effort is put forth to do their work well. Many mistakes are made but they are always willing to try again. Before long they are able to set up a scarf or a pair of mittens for themselves. I do not think it advisable to continue the same kind of work daily so I change from knitting to sewing every now and then. I ask the children to save their salt bags and little pieces of soft cotton materials that they may bring them to school and hem them for handkerchiefs. Pretty soon they began to bring in their salt bags, nicely washed and ironed, also little pieces of cotton which are hemmed in a short time.

The older pupils knit their own mitts, stockings and sweaters. They repair the old stockings by knitting in new knees, heels or toes as required. The wrists of mittens which are much worn are saved, and new parts are knit on.

When the time for wearing
these garments is over, the children are told to have them all washed, mended and put away so that they may be ready for use when the cold weather begins again. If we have not sufficient yarn for mending all the garments, they are brought to school and mended at the beginning of the September term. When the last year's garments were not cared for in this way, the children were given to understand that they might not have the privilege of getting the yarn the following year. I had some difficulty about this at first. The pupils would say, "My mudder washed my stockings felt no good; knees all break, no toes or heel." But I insisted on having the garments brought to the school. The pupils were shown how to insert the needles, and knit a new piece where it was needed. When the work was completed, some of the children would say "Just like new." Of course in some instances the old part may not wear out.
the new but the children have learned a lesson in economy.

I told the older pupils to watch their mothers sewing baskets; they might find there some pieces with which they could start quilt patching. They were delighted with this proposal, and began to bring in pieces of every shape and hue. It was surprising the patience the children exercised in putting these pieces together. I must admit the work was rather crude, but as all seemed to be doing their very best, I gave them much encouragement. The children brought flour bags; some made slips upon and waists. I have been suggesting that they dye their flour bags some pretty colors, and then they could make dresses. Remnants of dress goods were used for making tams.

Another very important part of the Domestic Science work, is the making over of old garments into new ones. This work should
be particularly stressed both at home and in
the class room. Now the question might arise,
"In what Indian home could material be found
for such work?" We are aware that the average
home has little or none; but as some of our
Indian people from time to time work in ex-
change for worn clothing, it might be secure
in this way. I have in the class room two
coats which were made over in schools which
are not provided with sewing machines; the
work may be begun at home, as many Indian
homes have sewing machines. The children
may be provided with patterns, have them
rip up the old garments, eliminating worn-out
parts, the new garments cut out, and basted.

Apart from this work, the pupils are instruct-
ed to watch the buttons on their clothing and
when any are missing, to find others to take
their places. When a patch is needed to bring
a piece of material as near as possible like
the garment and have one put on. If they
have new dresses, to keep them for Sunday,
they are not to be worn to school unless it is absolutely necessary. The same rule applies to other articles of clothing, as coats, shoes and stockings etc.

From time to time the children are given practical hints on bread making and the preparation of simple nutritious foods. They are frequently reminded that economy should always be practised, economy in the home, economy in the school.

This is a summary of the actual work which is being carried on in my school, and it should be the earnest endeavor of every Domestic Science teacher to make this work a great success, for next to their religion, I think it will play the most important part in the lives of the children in the years to come. At times we may feel discouraged when our efforts are now crowned with the success we expected, but by our untiring
Perseverance, always seeking the cooperation of both parents and pupils, let us go steadily on with a fixed determination to succeed. I shall be pleased to receive any suggestions from my fellow teachers along this line of work.
Nature and Health.

It would seem presumptuous for me to try to tell you how to teach Nature and Health. In this paper I shall simply try to demonstrate a few of the methods I use, after which I shall listen attentively to your criticism, which will point out, I hope, some of the weaknesses that I could not see.

Any subject which we attempt to teach may be divided into three phases: motivation, development, and expression. Motivation is simply an article or story, a practical application or some other device used to arouse interest in the child. In fact, it is a concrete bridge connecting the known and the related and known. I very often use blackboard drawings, or make flash cards from pictures found in advertisements in magazines. Another very effective motivation is a practical demonstration before the class of some good health habit. The daily morning exercise of brushing the teeth is a good example. Frequently, too, I teach a bookless lesson. My motives here are...
to get action, to teach something to do rather than the something to learn, for the sake of variety; to show by their absence how useful books are, and to develop the power of self-reliant thinking. The vital point about this particular lesson which I have taught so often is not the fact information it contains, but the actions and habits it induces the boys and girls to do and to continue to do. Knowledge about health is important but it is the health habits that count.

Keeping this idea uppermost, my first step is to give the boys and girls a five minutes talk on bodily cleanliness among other points. Stress these: Many germ diseases may be carried by the hands, backs, footwear, the fur of pets, the knobs on doors, retain germs, most colds are caught by germs reaching the mouth by means of the hands.

Second step: I write on the blackboard this health pledge: Cleanliness is the first law of health. I owe it to myself, my family, my school, my country to keep my body clean, strong and healthy. Free from dirt and germs. I'll try. Then the children...
memorize the pledge.

Third Step: Next, I teach the children some useful health habits; for instance, how to wash their hands. Few children make a good job of it. I have a pupil demonstrate the proper way before the class. About washing the hands remind the children what should be done: roll up their sleeves, rub soap on the backs of the hands also, not to wipe dirt off on the towel.

Fourth Step: Here enters the "do" part. For one month hence (not only one month I hope) the children put into practice what I have been teaching and preaching to them. For one month, they wash their hands regularly under my supervision. After that, they wash their hands regularly without supervision. Every Monday morning they bring to school a record showing the number of times, the days, dates and occasions on which they have washed their hands. Golden colored stars are awarded. At the end of the month the winner in the competition is announced and lauded. If the interest justifies it and in my case it did, we continue the contest.
for another month. Lewis Bros. Ltd. of Toronto, will supply any teacher with Wash-up Sacred Shields. Gold Stars Ltd. This is an example of only one lesson that has been worked out on this plan.

Lessons from the text on Respiration, Digestion, the circulation of the blood etc., may be outlined under different headings and taught step by step using drawings and pictures for demonstrations.

Hand in hand with health goes Nature, and the teacher may be called upon at any time to decide some problem that had been observed or found on the way to school perhaps. Then, very often the carefully planned lesson of the day is set aside for a future date, and immediate notice is taken of the visitor. For instance, one day a big green caterpillar was discovered making its way along the classroom floor. I defined our guest as a cabbage caterpillar and told the children how the egg had been laid by the butterfly and hatched out into their caterpillar. It had now attained its full size and was seeking some place to sleep. The children
placed him in a box and watched with interest during the winter months to see what was going to happen, for they understood that life history was not yet complete. Needless to tell, it was an enthusiastic class which, one extra warm day in May, observed our guest endeavoring to spread his wings. Carefully we removed him from his close quarters and placed him in the sun. Soon he spread his wings and poised for flight. Having as it were harbored him, we were loath to kill him, as perhaps we should have done to the interest of next year's cabbage crop, but the children wanted him set free, so we opened a window and out he flew. I feel certain that particular nature lesson will never be forgotten by my pupils.

Topics for this study are so numerous that I can but touch on them. The autumn presents to us for study and observation, the harvesting of crops, turning and falling of leaves, the southward flight of the birds and nature's way in general of preparation for winter. Although nature is in most
cases, dormant during the winter months, what better time is there to study our evergreen trees. Our forest and lumbering operations, too, are a never failing source of interest because they supply, no doubt, a home occupation for the fathers and elder brothers, so though Nature be sleeping, our lessons need never be dull.

Specimens one may say, may be hard to procure in winter. Not so, if cloud collections are gathered and differences in different clouds noticed and noted, again the fungus often found clinging to the furnace sticks, is a splendid specimen for an interesting lesson.

Thus we arrive at spring when all Nature is awake and birds animals, plants and trees vie with each other to be noticed. What boy or girl is there who doesn't delight in telling us of seeing the first robin, or so far with other birds common to our locality. What better time then to have a lesson on those birds. Again I am sure, we have each had the pleasure of receiving our first spring bouquet from the children, perhaps only a mixture of lady's slipper, but
a fountain of wealth for nature study. Thus the children themselves are supplying the subjects for their nature classes.

I find that in connection with this spring work a great source of interest is the bird and wild flower studies. These are very simply made by ruling a sheet of Bristol board under the headings: Common name, Date, Family, Description, and a space for the name of the pupil who found the particular specimen. These calendars or charts can be made very attractive classroom decorations, by pasting on pictures of wild flowers and birds and hanging them on the classroom walls.

As spring advances birds and flowers give place to seeding and gardening; when again the practical work is the best way of imparting knowledge to the school child. The school garden where it can be effectively carried out, teaches the child how to prepare seed and cultivate growing crops. If school gardening cannot be carried out, encourage the child to have a home plot.

Arbor day is a day special
day, when nature work may be made most interesting. The word "work" refers to trees; it is an old day, we plant a tree, but let us not stop at that. On Labor day, we can prepare and seed flower beds, which help to beautify our school grounds. Thus we see how the nature project works itself into our school routine and added to that, the three weekly periods allotted to it, I find my pupils have a fair knowledge of nature, and in time they will hope learn to appreciate how great nature is, and that it truly is living proof of the existence and omnipotence of the Almighty Creator who in his wisdom and kindness fashioned Mother Earth for our special use and benefit.
Domestic Science.

This subject I think appeals strongly to the Indian children, especially to the girls and naturally so for it is generally to the housewife folk, that the making and mending of the household is configned. It is not unusual, however, for boys to be able to mend their own clothes or even to knit their own mittens socks and sweaters and while they may never be called upon to do these things for themselves afterwards it certainly can not harm them to know how, if the emergency ever should arise.

It really is not any harder to start a boys knitting or sewing class than it is to start the same class with girls. True, for a time it is more discouraging, for the boys cannot be expected to show the same enthusiasm for this work as the girls but in time the Indian boy begins to show a real interest in the work, especially if it is something he can use for
his own weaving apparel; a pair of mittens, a cap, sweater, or stockings, for then he begins to realize what he has done something really worth while. He is anxious to show the girls in his class that he is just as capable of looking after his own personal appearance as they are.

The girls in most cases are energetic workers along this line of study. One cannot realize how useful this period is to the Indian children until one sees the improvement it has made in their lives and homes. For a number of years, the Department of Indian Affairs has supplied material both for sewing and knitting, for the use of the school children, and practically all the clothing for both boys and girls is made from this material, the work being done either in school by the pupils or at home by their parents.

The children themselves, from the age of eleven up are able to make and keep in repair all their own clothes. This is considered no mean
accomplishment and it certainly is a credit to any child; most so to the Indian child, who not only has the knowledge and capability of such work but also brings that knowledge to the home where it has proved its influence with the parents.

For the smaller pupils who are not old enough to make their own clothes, the garments can be cut out in school basted and sent or brought to the parents, some of whom do surprisingly neat and accurate work on the garments, many times trimming them according to their own tastes showing their originality and their pride and interest in the work. This I find is a good object for our monthly visits to the homes of the children, for while the parents usually enjoy these visits of the teacher & think they like it better when the teacher brings something for them to do for their children and on the next visit they will proudly display the work they have completed. Not only does the children profit by these hours of domestic
work, but the parents also show that they are taking advantage of the opportunities these lessons afford. Besides the articles of clothing made, many comfortable quilts have been made, using up all the left over scraps of material.

The children, too, take great pride in keeping their clothes, especially when they make themselves neat and tidy, and different times I have had pupils come and ask if they could mend some article of clothing before beginning the regular work they have on hand. This shows that the children are making good use of what they have been taught. The warm garments made in school act to, as a preventative from cold. Thus this work indirectly influences the other work carried on, for if the children are not warmly clad in winter, the almost sure result is sickness, and sickness means absence from school and a falling back in the classes. I might say here, too, that I find the daily use of Cod Liver Oil
and milk which the department supplies, to have made a wonderful improvement in the health and appearances of my pupils, so that whatever ugly line look at it, the domestic work should receive the earnest and interested attention of the teacher, as it has a marked effect on the pupils, not only while they are attending school, but takes in their lives afterwards, for it is a work that can always be put to practical use.
Teaching English Grammar and Composition to Indian Children.

Reverend Fathers, Reverend Sisters, Mr Chairman and Fellow Teachers,

I have been asked to write a paper on Teaching English Grammar and Composition to Indian Children:

Out of the twelve subjects on the curriculum for Indian schools, I find that Grammar is the most difficult subject to be taught with any success to Indian children.

Since the entire study of Grammar is based on language, the teacher, therefore, has a very weak foundation to work upon, because the majority of Indian pupils know very little English and have no desire to learn it.

In the lower grades even when
the child enters in Grade I, the teacher should begin instructions in English language by teaching what is correct, and correcting what is wrong without teaching a system of rules, as the minds of little children are as yet too undeveloped to grasp scientific principles.

As the child passes into a higher grade, the language study is continued by degrees until the fifth grade, when the term Grammar should be introduced, and then in a very limited sense.

It is not until the sixth grade is reached that it is profitable to introduce the study of the text book. Up to this time the pupil has been taught to use certain expressions and to avoid others without always knowing exactly why, but when he comes
to the study of the text-book the teacher explains the logical reasons for these things, and no longer must the pupil choose between right and wrong forms on the basis of memorization instead he applies his knowledge of fundamental rules.

Both language work and Grammar are closely related to Composition since the pupil must from the beginning build sentences to illustrate the principles he has been learning.

The following underlying principles are applicable to all language teaching:

1. The child learns language by listening to his teachers.
2. The child learns language from his reading book.
3. The child learns language from by coming in contact with English-speaking persons.

The pupil must be encouraged to use the English tongue in conversation.
to pronounce words correctly, to use correct language forms and to cooperate with the teacher in mastering the correct forms of English.

I offer two suggestions which would be found helpful. The teacher must be careful to use correct language as the pupil imitates your speech as well as your actions. (2) Call attention to correct forms in such a way as not to embarrass the pupil, and do not call attention to incorrect forms for instance, when a pupil makes an error it is in conversation it is better to let him finish rather than interrupt him, as it is most difficult to encourage an Indian child to repeat.

Since the phases of Grammar are not taught to pupils under Grade V, I shall outline the work to be taken up by these lower grades. Namely, Letters—
to pronounce words correctly, to use correct language forms and to cooperate with the teacher in mastering the correct forms of English.

I offer two suggestions which would be found helpful. The teacher must be careful to use correct language as the pupil imitates your speech as well as your actions. (2) Call attention to correct forms in such a way as not to embarrass the pupil, and do not call attention to incorrect forms for instance, when a pupil makes an error. In conversation it is better to let him finish rather than interrupt him, as it is most difficult to encourage an Indian child to repeat.

Since the phases of Grammar are not taught to pupils under Grade V, I shall outline the work to be taken up by these lower grades. Namely, "Little..."
Writing (2) Story-telling (3) The writing of simple compositions. In letter-writing the pupil is taught the parts of a letter, the use of capitals, and simple punctuation.

In story-telling the story is told by the teacher and repeated by the pupil. In simple composition the teacher suggests a title and the pupil enlarges it into a composition.

Now in Grade V we begin the simple phases of grammar, namely, the parts of speech and the elements of a sentence.

In Grade VI we continue and enlarge upon the work of Grade V and introduce the Classification of Sentences according to construction and use, the classical analysis and simple detailed analysis of sentences.

Grade VII is a continuation
and review of Grade VI with the classification of nouns and pronouns, and the inflections of nouns.

Grade VII comprises the completion of the remaining phases of grammar which includes the inflection of pronouns, the classification and inflection of the remaining parts of speech, the parsing of each, the rules of syntax, the rules of punctuation and then the review of the complete text.

In teaching grammar the use of the text book should be practically eliminated even in the advanced grades. To obtain results each individual grammar lesson must be taught from the blackboard, and the grades must work exercises on grammar days so that the teacher may determine if they understand the work accomplished.

The great difficulty in teaching
Grammar to Indian children is, that their knowledge of English does not enable them to enlarge on definitions, and after accomplishing a certain section they cannot connect it with the previous lesson.

The important factor in successful grammar teaching is the constant reviewing of work done in previous grades.

There are many phases of grammar teaching which the teacher should like to cover more thoroughly, but the allotted time for grammar on the time table does not permit extensive work.

This is my personal opinion in teaching this subject, but other teachers may vary in their ideas according to the ability of their pupils.

Now I should be glad to receive any suggestions from your inspectors.
and my fellow teachers and my composition is open for criticism.

Thank you.
Supervision of the Play ground
and
Group Games.

When asked to write a paper for this teachers' convention, I was delighted to learn that the subject of my paper was "Supervision of the Play ground and Group Games," for on the play-ground I first knew my pupils as they really are, there where we became real friends and there where I obtained knowledge regarding their real tempers, dispositions and manners which has helped me to encourage what is right and discourage what is wrong or, in other words, in the moulding of moral character. This has been one of my greatest problems and one that required and still requires a great amount of study and work to make a success of. We teachers who are familiar with the Indians know it is a very easy matter to get the Indian child to play because it is their nature to be more at home in the open and up until the time they begin school restraint is unknown to them.

We have from thirty to forty minutes per day devoted to recreation and this time should be spent in recreation by both
both teacher and pupils not in neglected homework, duly prepared lessons and seat work. This time although short is restful and needed to safeguard the health of the pupils.

The Indian children very seldom leave the Reserve or have opportunity of learning new games, therefore they require more teaching and supervision than the white children; for this reason it is expedient that the teacher be present in the play-ground with the pupils during recreation and that he or she takes part in the games. This also eliminates arguing, quarreling etc., which, at times, takes place on the unsupervised play-ground.

The grouping of pupils for the different games is an easy matter in a large school but a difficult one in the smaller school where the individual teacher has to select a game which will be suitable to pupils of all ages, as most games require a certain number of pupils of the same or nearly about the same age, so it becomes necessary for the teacher to comprise a number of games to suit her school. The wider knowledge the teacher has of these games and the better she adopts
them to the conditions which obtain,
the more valuable will be the effects
of the games.

Our Syllabus of Physical Training
suggests that when choosing a game
the age, ability and physique of the
players should be considered. Children
may be divided into three age-groups,
namely, those from 5-7, those from 8-10
and those of 11 years of age and upward.
First we will consider out-of-door
games. In the first group from 5-7, the
games should be very simple. Easy
games such as running, jumping and
chasing are advised. In the running
games we are familiar with, Hide and
Seek, Fox and Geese, Fill the Gap,
Drop the Handkerchief and Races. In
the chasing games we have Cat and
Mouse, Sheep, Sheep, Come Home, Chasing
the Squirrel, etc. The jumping games
for this group must be very simple
such as imitating the nursery rhymes,
for example, the little rhyme which con-
tains the words, "The cow jumped over the
moon."
Many little song games are very much appreciated. The little rhymes being learned on Friday afternoons. Included in these games are, Little Sally Walker, London Bridge is Falling Down and Huts in May.

In the second group we use games of a more advanced and difficult form than the first. Among these games we have, Hop Scotch, Tag, Dodge, Blind Mans Buff, Jack-in-the-Dark and Catch.

In the third group the games we play are Soft Ball, Football Kicking, Leap Frog, Squat, Tug-o-War, Follow My Leader, etc. The favorite game is Soft Ball and for this the Indian team on the Reserve permits us the use of their bat, ball, gloves etc. We have also a football which is used in the kicking games.

The favorite winter games are skiing and coasting and to this end we have obtained permission to use the hill adjacent to the school grounds. On these occasions the teacher is
always present.

When weather conditions will not permit play on the playground, there are many games which can be played in the school-room and which the children like to play almost as well as the outdoor games. Some of these are, Guessing Games, Kite, Jacks, Hide the Butter, Marbles etc. There are also Jigsaw Letters and Maps which can be obtained by the teacher at a very slight cost and are educative as well as amusing. The ever popular cross-word puzzle, if not too difficult is enjoyed by the Indian child. This tends to widen the pupil's knowledge of the English language and promotes the use of the dictionary.

In the lower grades physical exercises must be very simple and exercise games are easily taught. This one I have found very interesting and instructive in forming correct walking and standing positions also in teaching the pupil alertness. The pupils are
standing in four rows. Each pupil in each row is numbered from the front back, beginning with number one to the last pupil. The rows are numbered 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th. Each pupil standing in front is given a piece of chalk. Assume that the pupils have come to the proper standing position, the teacher commands that row No. 2 lead in the walking game, followed by row No. 1, then No. 3 and lastly No. 4. When the command is given, the first child in row No. 2 comes forward to the board in proper walking position, performs the required exercise (which may be one such as the writing of a simple word) turns properly, walks back to his place, turns again so that he will be facing the front, passes his chalk backward over his right shoulder to No. 2 in his line, who repeats the exercise and so on to the end. Any pupil who does not keep his position is out of the game and takes his seat. Another exercise I like very much is "Kelley says."
One point that should be stressed is the speaking of the English language on the playground, as the pupils tend to use their own language. Some slight punishment such as suspension from the game for a short period or silence for a few minutes will help to overcome this.

I have found the educational magazines very helpful in this work, especially The Canadian Teacher, Toronto and Educational Review, Moncton. Much desired information can be obtained in the Syllabus of Physical Training which is in the hands of every teacher.

Following along these lines and also by soliciting the opinions of teachers who have wider experience in schoolwork than myself, I have rarely had extreme difficulty in controlling my playground or in having the pupils consider play a monotony.

Estelle M. O'Brien
Kingsclear Indian Day School
Kingsclear
N.B.
Ways and Means of Obtaining the Cooperation of the Indian Parents.

Domestic Science is home-made knowledge arranged or classified with reference to general truths or laws and shown to be correct by accurate observation and thinking. This kind of work to the Indians is a pleasure and really their natural kind of work.

I shall briefly give some ways and means of getting the cooperation of the Indian Parents in my work.

1. By making friends with the Indians. They being of a very sensitive nature are easily hurt; therefore, we must be watchful lest we do or say something which will hurt their feelings. We should never be so rushed that we have not time to speak to them when we meet them. Other than our monthly visit we should visit them frequently especially in cases of illness, death or in fact whenever requested for any reason. Treat them fairly; show no favoritism; give
praise where praise is due; encourage every effort, however small. We must be always ready to help them showing an interest in anything they are doing. In this way we not only make friends with the Indians, but gain their goodwill, confidence, love and respect.

2. Working up some competition among them. Some of the Indian parents take great pride in sending their children to school both neat and clean. Others do not. To the latter I remark that such a family of children look so neat and clean. This usually results in an improvement in the appearance of these families.

3. Example. Some of the boys were fortunate enough to be able to buy white knickers for the ball team. Others were not. To one Indian woman I suggested making them from bleached flour bags. Very soon I noticed several pairs of these knickers on the Reserve.

4. Through the pupils. For example
the Indian parent allows the child to do very much as he wishes. Therefore the child can convince the parent where it would be impossible for the outsider to do so. On the other hand the child more readily absorbs new ideas which he will carry to his parent and makes it easier for the teacher to convince in cases where it is necessary to do so as in case of inoculation.

I have not meant to imply that these are the only methods by which we may gain the cooperation of the Indians but I have found these ways and means useful in obtaining the end which I strive for.

Estelle M. O'Brien
Inspector Day School,
Kingsclear
N.B.
Rev. Father, Reverend Sisters,
Mr. Chapman and fellow teachers,

The topic on which I have been asked to write is "Domestic Science where the teacher is also Field Matron."

The title Domestic Science is the name given to the study of Home Economics or Home-Making.

This is the oldest and best-known profession the world has ever known.

One of the greatest resources of the teacher and Field Matron is the ability to meet all the conditions and emergencies which will confront her in the Indian home, gracefully and efficiently.

The duties of the teacher as an assistant house-maker comprise:

First, aiding the house-wife in home economics, especially the branches of cooking and sewing;

Second, the home-life and the study of each individual pupil;

Third, the developing of better habits of living; and fourth,

First aid.

Her business is to serve the Indian people safely and well.

Domestic Science in the average Indian home is neglected and over-looked, and the teacher must endeavor by visiting the individual homes at least once each month.
to carry out her miscellaneous duties, to the best of her ability.

The teacher's success depends on the circumstances and conditions of the home.

The home, the school, and the business world are important educational factors; one cannot exist without the help of the other.

The higher the standard of the home, the greater will be the efficiency of the pupils in the school.

Since the home and school are so closely related, I shall outline briefly the Domestic Science Course as conducted in the school.

The period of time allotted for this course is so brief that only a limited amount of work can be accomplished.

Domestic Science is not applicable to lower grade pupils and in the higher grades its application is limited because the home training of the pupils does not furnish a basis for this work.

In the school Domestic Science is conducted under the following headings, namely:

1. Sewing
2. Patching
3. Stitching
4. Cutting Lessons
5. Lectures
6. Quilting
7. Making Mats
8. Miscellaneous Work
The principal arts of the home are cooking and sewing. Sewing is connected with the furnishing of the home and the clothing of the children. Hand sewing should be taken up first, and the student should become familiar with all the stitches used in plain sewing, for basting, hemming, etc.

A suggested list for the sewing course includes the making of towels, holders, aprons, underwear, pillow cases, handkerchiefs, shirts and dresses.

Thin materials should be used. The pupils should also be taught the use of the sewing machine, if one has been provided for the school.

Knitting is also an essential factor in the course, and each pupil should be able to make stockings, mittens, scarfs and sweaters.

Lectures are essential from the view point of health. Cooking classes teach the child how to prepare nourishing foods, but few schools are equipped with the necessary cooking apparatus. Knitting and knitting mats are not very practical.
For Indian children, however,
this work may be carried on
on a small scale, by using
pieces of left-over material
from sewing, etc.

The work which I have
always considered the most
important in the Domestic
Science Course is Patching;
every child from its earliest
school days should be taught
the value and care of their
clothing, and how to repair
worn-out materials properly;
the teacher should remember
that this is one of the factors
which helps the child to attend
school regularly, by having
necessary clothing.

The most important points
occupy the whole of the allotted
period for Domestic Science,
and if the teacher has a
few minutes at her disposal,
at the close of the period,
she usually takes time for
miscellaneous items, which
arise from time to time.

The subject of Home
Economics, as taught in
the school to Indian pupils,
and the duties of the
teacher, as Chief Matron,
are subjects which afford a
great field for enlargement.
but would take up too much time, if gone into detail.

Therefore I have touched briefly on these general points which I have experimented with and which I consider important.

I shall now terminate with a little advice, which I have learned from actual experience, which is, when assuming your position as Field Master, do not criticize the existing conditions in any home; if you do a second visit will not be welcomed, or any further advice appreciated. Rather endeavor to alter habits, and make corrections by example and friendly advice; do not use harshness.

I should now apprise the new points of these facts.

I thank you.

Irene Fitzgerald. (Teacher)
Eel Ground Indian Day School.
I.

Reverend Fathers, Reverend Sisters,
My Chairman and Fellow Teachers,

I have been requested to compose
a paper on "Making a Workable
Time-Table for an Indian School."

In the preparation of a practical
Indian school time-table, the teacher
should comply with the same basic
principles, which are used in making
English school time-tables, as the
curricula are similar.

There are four definite points to
be carefully considered before beginning
the outlining of a time-table,
which are, the following: first, the
number and names of the title
subjects to be taught; secondly, the
division of these subjects according
to the five school days; thirdly,
the amount of time to be allotted
to each subject and fourthly, the
division of that specified time
among the eight grades.

Regarding these points just
mentioned, the first one, namely, the
number and names of the title
subjects to be taught, is applicable
to all Indian schools, while the
second, third and fourth, namely,
the division of those subjects according
to the five school days, the amount
of time to be allotted to each subject,
and the division of that specified
time among the eight grades, respectively,
will each vary according to the prevailing conditions of each particular school.

I shall now enlarge on each point individually.

First, the number and names of the title subjects to be taught; concerning the curriculum, there are twelve subjects; namely, Religion, Mathematics, Reading, Geography, Grammar, Hygiene, History, Latin, Nature Study, Writing, Drawing and Domestic Science.

Second, the division of these subjects according to the five school days either of two methods may be used in arranging this heading; for example, some teachers prefer the system of teaching daily all the subjects on the curriculum, whereas others prefer teaching a certain number of subjects on particular days and the remaining ones on alternate days.

Personally, I have experimented with both systems, and have found that it is practically impossible for one instructor to teach twelve subjects daily to eight grades; in the first place, time will not permit and in the second place, the average Indian child has not the ability to grasp such an amount of material each day.

Consequently, I have used the second system of grouping the subjects,
for certain days, and therefore the
timetable time-table, which I am
presenting to you is made according
to my practical experience.

I feel that all Indian school
teachers must agree with me that,
the work outlined on a time-table,
of twelve subjects daily, with all
the grammar grades, could not
possibly be accomplished.

The only way by which this
system could be worked successfully,
would be in a school with more
than one teacher, or where a single
teacher did not have all the right tools.
But since I am to make a whole
time table for Grades I-III inclusive,
the latter system of combining certain
subjects must be used.

Third, the amount of time to
be allotted to each subject.
The school day is divided into
seven hours, from which one and
one-half hours are deducted for
Recess periods and twenty-five
minutes are deducted for
necessary exercises, aside from
the curriculum; thus leaving
approximately five hours for
the school subjects on the curriculum.

It is not necessary that any
subject should have a definite
position on the time-table; although
educators state "that Mathematics
should be taught in the early morning session while the child's reasoning abilities are fresh.

However, the teacher may arrange the subjects according to his judgment.

The most important point on a time table is the division of the actual teaching hours among the subjects, while the teacher desires to take up daily, so that from experience she may determine the number of minutes necessary to cover the work of a certain subject with the grades which are taking that subject.

Fourth, the division of the specified time among the eight grades. There can be no special time allotted to a particular grade, as the time necessary for any lesson varies each day, according to the number of pupils in the class, their ability and the nature of the lesson. The ability of these pupils compels the teacher to use the time to best advantage, and to take opportunity of any short-notice lesson in almost every period of the day; a few minutes of the allotted time must be used in assisting the pupils with their seat-work, black-board illustration, discipline, etc.
Following is my outline of a workable time-table for an Indian School, Grades I-VIII, scientifically which from actual experience has proved successful.

**Morning Session: 9 A.M. - 12 A.M.**

| Time | Activity                          | Notes       |
|------|----------------------------------|-------------|
| 9-9.10 | Morning Exercises and Roll Call | Daily       |
| 9.10-10.10 | Religious Instruction            | Daily       |
| 10.10-10.45 | Physical Drill                  | Daily       |
| 10.45-11   | Mathematics                      | Daily       |
| 11-12 A.M. | Games and Ventilation            | Daily       |
| 12-1 P.M. | Noon recess (1 hour)             |             |

**Afternoon Session: 1 P.M. - 4 P.M.**

| Time | Activity                          | Notes       |
|------|----------------------------------|-------------|
| 1-1.05 | Roll Call                        | Daily       |
| 1.05-1.25 | Reading                          | Daily       |
| 1.25-1.30 | Physical Drill                   | Daily       |
| 1.30-2   | Geography                         | Mon., Tues., and Thurs. |
| 2-2.25   | British History                   | Mon., Tues., and Thurs. |
|         | Canadian History                  |             |
| 2.25-2.45 | Latin                            | Mon. and Tues. |
| 2.45-3   | Physiology                        | Tues. and Thurs. |
|         | Water Study                       | Friday      |
|         | Games and Ventilation             | Daily       |
| 3-3.30   | Writing                           | Mon. and Tues. |
|         | Drawing                           | Tues. and Thurs. |
| 3.30-4   | Domestic Science                  | Daily, with 60 min. Friday |
| 4-4.05   | Evening Prayer                    | Daily       |
After the teacher has practiced the workable time-table, she must strictly adhere to its every detail, by having all the lesson assignments, exercises etc., completed before the end of the allotted time, so that no period will overrun another.

In terminating, I may state that I have no further suggestions to offer pertaining to this topic; but I trust that my statements will meet with your approval.

I should also appreciate the receiving of any remarks which those present would like to offer.

I thank you.

Irene Fitzgerald,
Eel Ground Indian Day School.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th instant, regarding the summer vacation allowed pupils attending the boarding schools.

In reply I beg to say that one month (31 days) summer holidays are allowed with grant to the pupils in all residential schools. These holidays should be taken between the first day of July and the first day of October in each year, unless some other course is expressly sanctioned by the Department. During vacation the pupils may, in the discretion of the principal, be permitted to visit their homes but the Department will not pay any part of the cost of transportation, either going or returning. The grant will not be allowed for any days leave of absence in excess of 31 days, unless authority is granted for special reasons. The principals of the residential schools should be thoroughly aware of the Department's requirements regarding the granting of holidays.

Sir:

This acknowledges the receipt of your letter of February the 16th in which you state that Dr. Westgate, acting General Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, requests that the holiday period for the Alert Bay Residential Schools be extended from four weeks to six weeks each year.

It will be just as well to recognize that if the request is granted in this case it will, of necessity, lead to a change of policy in this matter by the Indian Department. For I feel certain that similar requests will come from many of our Residential Schools.

It would be well, too, to remember that according to Indian Day School Regulations, the pupils of Day Schools have two months' holidays. I think that the arguments in favour of two months' holidays for our day school are equally cogent when applied to Residential Schools.

There is a tendency in educational circles to increase the holiday time. July and August are holidays in all the public schools of British Columbia. From a health point of view it is generally recognized that pupils are better out of the
class-room during the period of extremely hot weather.

The objective of all our schools is to develop the moral, mental, and physical powers of the child. Therefore I am prepared to sanction any change that will help the schools to attain that objective.

There is also another phase of the question. At the present time many pupils do not return promptly and the result is that the quarter ending September 30th generally shows a marked decrease in the financial results. This leads to difficulty in financing the schools.

On the whole, I am in favour of the holiday period being extended to six weeks with full grant. Practically, it takes two weeks to get the pupils back to school and organized for work. If the policy of six weeks' holidays were adopted then punctuality on the part of the pupils should be insisted upon.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, with reference to the holiday period at Indian residential schools. I have noted the reasons advanced by you why it might be desirable to arrange for a 6 weeks' period.

In reply I beg to state that the Department cannot change its regulations in this connection, at the present time. Some schools in certain parts of Canada are so situated that it is impracticable to allow the children to go home in the summer time. At these schools, arrangements are made for summer camps and other outings, always under the supervision of members of the staff. Further, I am of the opinion that there will always be delinquent pupils who fail to return promptly at the expiration of a holiday period, and a lengthening of the vacation would result in a general disorganizing of institutional routine, for a period every summer of at least two months. Most of our institutions are crowded to the limit of their capacity, and no opportunity must be lost to educate and prepare for Christian citizenship the youth of the present generation.

If it is found, at any school, that the general health and stamina of the children are not what they should be, special arrangements can be made upon application to the Department for outdoor activities, as a substitution for classroom work for those weeks in the summer that are not in the vacation period. The Department believes that the children enrolled at Indian residential schools should be, for 11 months of the year, under the discipline, care and civilizing influence of the staff of workers.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:

At different times, representations have been made to the Department that it would be advisable to increase the annual vacation at Indian residential schools to six weeks. Of late years, Mr. Inspector Cairns has urged a longer holiday and Rev. Father Guy, on behalf of R.C. principals, has made a similar request.

The reasons advanced are as follows:

1. In extremely warm weather it is better for the health of the pupils if they are without classroom activity and without the restraint which is so irksome to the Indian child. (there is a general tendency to increase the duration of the summer vacation at educational institutions).

2. A certain number of the staff have to be on duty at Indian residential schools at all times. If the vacation of the pupils is limited to one month, some of the officers do not receive any more than two weeks' holiday.

3. One or two exceptions have been made and a holiday longer than 31 days is taken. Father Guy points out that some principals allow six weeks or more, without the permission of the Department, and have been doing it for many years.

With your approval I will draft a circular letter to the Church and Department workers interested. I propose to send a copy to two or three representative principals and to Commissioner Graham and Inspector Cairns, with the request that they make suggestions. Then a circular would be directed to all principals and agents, after having been approved by yourself.

To Church Authorities, Principals and Department Representatives:

The Department has decided to allow 45-60 days' annual leave with grant for pupils at Indian residential schools. This holiday may be taken at the discretion of the principal, some time during the September quarter. Other dates may be fixed only when specifically approved by the Department. The practice of giving pupils leave from Indian residential schools at Christmas is considered unwise and in future grant will not be allowed if holidays at this season are given without permission.

Orphans and children of destitute parents should not be allowed summer holidays, unless satisfactory arrangements can be made for their care when away from school. Principals should not allow annual leave to children who have had to be brought in under escort upon the expiration of summer vacations and may refuse holidays to those pupils who have truanted during the academic year. Extreme care should be exercised in the case of pupils whose homes are distant from the school. Unless special safeguards concerning their return can be taken, holidays should not be granted.

When the September quarter return is being prepared, the dates of the annual leave should be clearly indicated and grant for the full quarter may be requested for all pupils who have been away from the school no longer than 43 days.

To Church Authorities, Principals and Department Representatives:

The Department has decided to allow pupils at Indian residential schools annual leave with grant for any period up to 43 days. Holidays should be taken consecutively, at the discretion of the principal, during the September quarter. Other dates may be fixed only when specifically approved by the Department. The practice of giving pupils leave from Indian residential schools at Christmas is considered unwise; and, in future, grant will not be allowed if holidays at this season are given without permission. At no school should week-end holidays be granted.

Requests for special or emergency leave for pupils, who are urgently needed at home, should be made to the Indian agent, who will give approval only when he considers such leave absolutely necessary and after he has the concurrence of the principal, who should understand that grant will be discontinued. Special leave in the case of any pupil should be reported to the Department by the Indian agent. If the medical officer advises that a pupil be sent home for a period because of illness, the Indian agent should be informed and the principal, when preparing the quarterly return, should not apply for grant for those days the pupil was out of school.

Orphans and children of destitute parents should not be allowed summer holidays, unless satisfactory arrangements can be made for their care when away from school. Principals should not allow annual leave to children who have had to be brought in under escort upon the expiration of former vacations and may refuse holidays to those pupils who have truanted during the academic year. Extreme care should be exercised in the case of pupils whose homes are distant from the school. Unless special safeguards concerning their return can be taken, holidays should not be granted.

When the September quarter return is being prepared, the dates of the annual leave should be clearly indicated and grant for the full quarter may be requested for all pupils who have been away from the school no longer than 43 days.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

I have read over carefully your personal letter to Principals of school, dated 20th inst., No. 150-37, and fear it is going to cause us endless trouble if enforced to the letter.

The parents of the great majority of our pupils are very anxious to have their help at home during the greater part of July and August. Many of them really need the help. We could not get our teachers to continue after July 1st, or begin before September 1st, the regular school year. If pupils were forced to return here the middle of August the parents would believe we wanted them to work on our farm instead of theirs, and it would make a tempest.

Our practice is to give some latitude covering these two months. Pupils who are needed at home are allowed the full time. Those who have no homes, or are not needed at home are paid a reasonable wage for time here. It is working splendidly, and the school about breaks even in the matter.

I sincerely hope you will give us a little latitude as heretofore, and thus keep peace in the family.

I am, Dear Sir,

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir,

We are in receipt of a letter from the Indian agent referring to the Christmas holidays being denied our children attending school. We just wonder why has the Department taken such a move. We, poor Indians, think it is a crime to deprive us and our children of such joy and consolation. As we all know Christmas Day and New Year's day are above all home festivals, days of unity and charity in our Christian families. It is customary for all institutions such as Universities, Colleges, Academies and convents to grant holidays to their students at this season. Why should the Indians be denied the same privilege and happiness? Moreover, we understand that all such institutions as named above are not denied with the government grant during the Christmas holidays, why should our Residential School be deprived of the same favour?

It is not our intention to challenge the Department upon the enactment of such regulations, but we feel sorry not to be treated at par with the white people in this connection. We feel molested in our rights over our children and trust that our appeal will not go unanswered. May it please the Indian Department to adjust this matter for the good of all.

Re...Rhoda Cook, pupil #076, Alert Bay Girls' Home.

Sir:

In view of the fact that I am holding this pupil's place in this School open for her, and bearing in mind that we are losing grants by keeping this place vacant, might I enquire, please, as to the possibility of bringing this pupil back to school. Should the Dept. not see its way clear at this time to enforce the return of this pupil to school, I will at once, on receipt of the notification, fill the vacancy with a new pupil.

I am well aware of the contentious points that this subject must bring to the fore, and realise that it is a question that cannot be settled in a minute, although I would much like to get this particular child returned to school, as I am afraid for her sake what too long a delay might do. Her sister returned from Quatsino the other day, and I am afraid her influence will be for the bad.

This whole question of raising the age limit is a very serious one, and although I do not wish to be intrusive, I would like to put forward a suggestion. There is no denying the fact that we of the Schools are apt to lose sight of the fact that the Indians themselves have rights that must be guarded. Principal among these is that of having their children for the fishing season, chiefly the boys, who, in this age of keen competition and poor seasons due to overcrowding of the waters with gear, must be invaluable to their parents in the annual harvesting of the fish. It is only just and fair that these youngsters should have the opportunity of going out and learning what the schools cannot teach them, their future living as a fisherman. Yet under Departmental regulations, we can only grant them 43 days holiday, which for years here, with the attendant loss of per capita grant, has been stretched to 50 days, owing to the impossibility of getting them back before the end of the sockeye run. Yet for the past two or three years here, over 80% of the children have been back in school right on time. This is a splendid tribute to the desire of the Indians for education, and why should that be worthy of encouragement? Let us do they take them out at 15 years of age? Because they must have the elder boys for at least two months fishing, and sooner than not have them, they take them out of school, and then the youngsters hang around and do nothing all the winter. With the girls, it is different. They are needed principally in the canneries for the sockeye run, most of the other varieties being machines canned, thereby not requiring the same large number of hands.

Now is there not some way of reaching a compromise with the Indians on this matter. Could we not say that if the age limit is raised, to 17, that all boys of 14, or 15, could have two months vacation, to enable them to earn money, learn a trade, and fit themselves for an honourable life of usefulness to themselves and their people. Then, when the long winter comes, and they would otherwise become pool room habitues, they would be back in school, where education, both technical and academic, would be carrying on the work. Of course there are many questions in a matter like this, and I suppose one of the first would be that of the loss of grant. Why not put it up to the Indians themselves to pay the per capita grant for the period of extra time granted the pupil in question? One here off...
ed to pay if I would let his boy stay out for an extra month, and when I turned him down on the ground of unfairness to others, he took the boy out of school.

In summing up, it can be quite easily seen that the Indians themselves have some just and very valid reasons why they should oppose the raising of the age limit. Their story that the children come out of the school, able to read, to talk, to dress well, and in possession of many other white man's ways, but unable to fish, is pathetic, but true, as far as the boys are concerned, although I think that it is principally tribal customs relating to early marriage, etc., that create the opposition to the going back of the girls. The crying need seems to be for an extended vacation for all the elder boys, to enable them to learn their own business of life; domestic science in the schools for the girls; and advanced and intensive technical training for the boys, taking in carpentering, gas and diesel engineering, housebuilding, sanitation and drainage and other useful subjects. With these in force, I think it might be quite on the cards that the Indians themselves would welcome a raised age limit, say to the 17th year.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Very faithfully yours,

[Signature]

Principal.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th ultimo having reference to the complaint of the Principal of the Alert Bay Residential School that it is difficult to get parents to return their children to the school at the expiration of the summer vacation, which is for a period of forty-three days, due to the fact that boys are useful to their parents during the fishing season.

In reply to your request for information as to whether the fishing season is longer than forty-three days, I beg to say that it is.

In District No.1, which takes in the Fraser River and Howe Sound territory (Howe Sound is about fifteen miles North of Vancouver), the fishing season is from the 1st July to the 10th November, a period of one hundred and thirty-three days.

District No.2 covers the territory from the Nass River South to the North end of Vancouver Island, and in this district the fishing season begins on the 20th June and ends any time up to the end of September according to how the fall fish are running. This would be a period of approximately one hundred and ten days.

District No.3—Vancouver Island and Mainland South to Howe Sound. The fishing season begins on the 1st June and ends generally about the first week in November which is one hundred and forty-three days. This year, however, some of the canneries are operating until the 19th of the present month.

At the Alert Bay School, the pupils are gathered from the Kwawkewlth Agency, which is in Number 3 District, and also from the Bella Coola Agency in Number 2 District. Therefore to extend the vacation to take in the fishing season in both these districts, the period would be fully one hundred and fifty days, as of course, it would be impossible to get a boy back to the school within a few days after the fishing season is closed. It would not be in the interest of our educational system that the vacation period should cover such a long period for the reason that there is a great percentage of the pupils who do return to school at the expiration of the summer vacation.

The residential

The residential schools of British Columbia at which any of the pupils would be engaged in the fishing industry are Ahousaht, Alberni, Alert Bay, Christie, Coqualeetza, Kitimat, Kuper Island, Sechelt and also possibly the Squamish School at North Vancouver.

In British Columbia the annual vacation in the public schools begins on the 1st of July and extends to the first Tuesday in September.

I do not see how it would be possible for the vacation period to fit in very well with the fishing seasons, for the simple reason that a very great bulk of the Indian fishermen only take part in the fishing season for the sock-eye salmon, which is the early run. This is followed later by various species of what are known as the fall fish and not nearly as many Indians participate in this as do in the sock-eye fishing. Those who do not stay fishing after the sock-eye run is over generally go South with their families for the hop-picking at Chilliwack and Agassiz, some going to the hop-yards in the State of Washington during the month of September and do not reach their homes until about the second week of October. Consequently as long as pupils are allowed to take part in the fishing and hop-picking business, there naturally will be some of them who do not return after the summer vacation is over.

It might be a good idea for the Department to favourably consider the matter of giving the Indian pupils a full two months' vacation in the summer time the same as the white children have and to allow the principals of these schools to determine just when the holidays should begin and end so as to get the best results by way of return of all their pupils.

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK., December 20th, 1927.

Dear Mr. Scott,

For the last two weeks I have been besieged with Indians coming in from the reserves to see me as to whether the Department would not re-consider its ruling regarding the non-granting of Christmas holidays to their children attending the various Boarding Schools. The ruling has caused a great deal of dissatisfaction amongst the Indians and about a month before Christmas they start making appeals to have their children sent home.

Personally, I think it is perhaps unfair to a great many of our advanced Indians who are quite willing and anxious to carry out the regulations of the Department, and who have homes equally as good as some of the prosperous farmers in this country; (in fact their home conditions could not be much better), to deprive them of the privilege that the white man has, and it is hard to explain it to them. I perhaps see the discontent caused by this ruling a great deal more than do many of the Principals, because the Indians know the ruling is made by the Government and they naturally come to me. They see hundreds of children from all over the country coming home from Boarding Schools for the Christmas holidays, and they look on it as an injustice to them when their children are not given the same consideration. This certainly has the effect of making them sulky and discontented. I have always impressed upon the Indians that the Department's aim is to put them on the basis of White people as soon as it is possible to do so, and in situations of this kind it becomes rather difficult to explain to them the Department's attitude. The Indians who are right next door to the school and who are doing well in every way should not be made to suffer on account of the laxity of those at a distance who do not send their children back to school promptly and who do not keep them as cleanly as they should when they are at home.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I fully appreciate the difficulty in getting children back to school where they have to travel great distances, and in cases where the parents are indifferent, but I am now placing this matter before you more particularly on behalf of those Indians who have good homes within a reasonable distance, and who will carry out their promises to see that their children are returned to school promptly.

I believe there have been twenty people come to Regina by train to speak to me about this matter, and I hope that my writing to you will not be looked upon as being too persistent, as I think it only right that you should have the whole matter laid before you, and be advised as to just what the feeling is, and the difficulties it makes in connection with recruiting, as most of this work is done by the Department's officials and not by the Principals of schools.

Yours very truly,

I have given considerable thought to the question of Christmas holidays at Indian residential schools and to your 100-LB of the 20th ultimo. I think I should inform you that principals and others interested are, in the main, satisfied that such holidays should be discouraged.

The Department allows pupils at Indian residential schools annual leave with grant for any period up to 43 days. Generally, holidays should be taken consecutively, at the discretion of the principal, during the September quarter. Other dates may be fixed only when specifically approved by the Department. The practice of giving pupils leave from Indian residential schools at Christmas is considered unwise; and grant is not allowed if holidays are taken at this season. The Department wishes to discourage Christmas holidays; but there is no regulation prohibiting them. In the first place, the season of the year is not suitable for travelling. Further, there are occasional difficulties in the matter of the return of pupils. I consider that schools on, or contiguous to, reserves should have a Christmas tree or concert, to which all friends should be invited.

At no school should week-end holidays be granted. Far too often, returning pupils bring body vermin into the institution. Again, the breaking of the routine itself often outweighs the value of the change for the pupil. There is no objection to pupils going to their homes for Christmas Day or on Sunday, if such a short visit is possible, but they should be returned to the school before nightfall.

Children have occasionally been returned to school insufficiently clad. Lastly, the breaking of the routine itself outweighs the value of the change for the pupil.
