Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Right Reverend Joe Guy and Reverend J. O. Fleurde intimated to us that they would return to Ottawa toward the end of the present week and they were hopeful that, at that time, we would be in a position to make known to them our decision in respect to a number of proposals submitted by them for our consideration. May I submit to you, for your consideration, the following proposals:

1. That the present holiday period at residential schools be extended from six weeks to two months (July and August) and that this new regulation come into force at the end of the present academic year. This regulation, if adopted, will bring the holiday period at residential schools into conformity with the present regulation governing day schools and will be in conformity also, with the practice followed by provincial authorities in respect to public schools. If this regulation is adopted, it would result in certain economies to the church authorities. It should mean less expenditure in the purchase of supplies, etc.

2. That we grant the sum of Five Dollars ($5.00) per pupil per annum in the case of church-owned schools, on the understanding that the church authorities would become responsible for the repair and upkeep of these institutions. This additional sum may appear small, but, in view of the substantial grants made to these schools during the last five year period, I consider it reasonable.

3. That you consider the advisability of discussing with Bishop Guy the rebuilding of a wing at the Grouard School recently destroyed by fire and that this building be erected at his expense. If he is prepared to assume this obligation, the Department might agree to increase the per capita grant from $175.00 to $185.00. To Church Authorities, Principals and Department Representatives:

The Department has decided to allow pupils at Indian residential schools annual leave with grant for any period up to two (2) months. These holidays should be taken during the months of July and August. Other dates for the annual leave may be fixed only when specifically approved by the Department.

This extended holiday should obviate the necessity of granting week-end holidays or holidays at Christmastime, for which no authorization can be given.

Orphans and children of destitute parents should not be allowed summer holidays unless arrangements can be made for their care when away from the school. This provision has special application to girls from twelve to sixteen years of age. Extreme care should be exercised in the case of pupils whose homes are distant from the school. Unless special safeguards concerning their return can be taken, holidays should not be granted.

Requests for special or emergency leave for pupils who are urgently needed at home should be made to the Indian Agent, who will give approval only when he considers such leave absolutely necessary and after he has the concurrence of the Principal, who should understand that grant will be discontinued during such absence of a pupil. All such cases of special leave should immediately be reported to the Department by the Indian Agent.

If the medical officer advises that a pupil be sent home for a period because of illness, the Indian Agent should be informed and the Principal, when preparing the quarterly return, should not apply for grant for those days the pupil was not in residence. Definite information regarding all such pupils should be supplied on the quarterly return.

When the September quarter return is being prepared, the dates of the annual leave should be clearly indicated and grant for the full quarter may be requested for all pupils who have been away from the school not longer than sixty-two (62) days.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Sir:

Mr. John E. Pugh, Indian Agent at the Blood Agency, has forwarded me a copy of his No. 402-4C dated the 13th instant, re petition forwarded by the members of the Blood Band to the Department, re circular letter No. 150-37 dated March 30th last, which refers to school holidays.

When on the reserve on the 21st ultimo, Chief Owns-Many-Horses mentioned the matter to me. He claimed the new regulations were very drastic, insomuch as there would be no monthly or Christmas holidays in future. I asked him what his objections were, and what he wished, pointing out that the children would be given two months holidays each summer. His reply was, "Ten months is a very long time without having our children in our homes, after being accustomed to having them home each month. Would the Department allow them a week at Christmas and month-end holidays for the months of March, April and May?" I informed him I could not change the Department's regulations, and that I understood the new ones had been made because, in several cases pupils who were allowed to go home Friday evenings and should return to the school on Sunday, did not return until Monday or Tuesday. This upset the class-room work and other regulations in the schools, as well as the pupils themselves. I also informed him that the Blood Reserve was the only one I knew of where monthly leave of absence had been granted. He then informed me that a petition was being circulated for signing, which would be forwarded to the Department. I have not seen this petition.

The Secretary,

In conversation with the Principals of St. Paul's and St. Mary's Schools, they stated that they would carry out the Department's instructions. However, I gathered from their conversation that they would not make the suggestion: If it was made by the Indians and the Department granted same, well and good.

In my opinion, these Indians -- a number of whom have impressed me as being haughty and exacting -- have no reason for complaint. They are allowed to visit their children at the schools and are informed when they are sick, and on Sundays they have the privilege of being with them for several hours.

I am in receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, enclosing copy of a communication received from the Principal of the Kamloops Residential School, with reference to the holiday leave.

Before increasing the holiday leave from 45 days to 62 days, the proposal was discussed with all church officials, and they expressed the opinion that, if the holiday leave was extended to 62 days, there would be considerably less difficulty in having the pupils returned on time. They also promised that all church officials and school principals would cooperate with the Department in having pupils returned promptly upon the expiry of their leave.

In the case of each pupil who was in the Kamloops School on June 30th - the probable date of closing for summer holidays - and who was allowed home on holidays, the Principal may request grant at the end of September for the actual number of days such pupil was in residence during the September quarter, plus the holiday leave. For instance, for a pupil allowed out on holidays on July first and who returned on September fifth, grant may be requested for the full quarter, or 62 days. If a pupil did not return to the school until September 15th, grant should only be requested for 78 days (62 days holidays plus 16 days for the period September 16th to September 30th). For a pupil allowed out on holidays on July first and who does not return to the school by September 30th, grant should only be requested for 62 days.

Reverend Father Chatelain O.M.I., principal of

would be extended. Although Fr. Chatelain caused this
information to be made known to the parents of the child-
ren, number of them nevertheless sent their children back
at the time that the fall term heretofore opened. He was
obliged to send them home and some of the disaffected
parents started a rumour about that the circular letter
from your Department was not genuine. Then when school
opened they made a complaint—to the Indian agent, I
believe, that the school was infected with typhoid and that
the food was not good. As a result, I understand that
the Indian Agent had the Medical Officer, Dr. Craig of Broadview
make an investigation—-at least, if that is not so, Dr.
Craig after making an investigation delivered a report to the
Agent. I am enclosing a copy of this report from which you
will note that the charges were entirely unfounded, and
were obviously propounded through dissatisfaction because
of your Department's decision in regard to changing the
school holiday.

Fr. Chatelain fears that unless the Department

Dear Mr. Pugh:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter wherein the suggestion is made that a holiday (without grant) be recommended during the Christmas season. My reaction to the suggestion is definitely negative. The sooner the question of holidays is settled on a mutually accepted and satisfactory basis, the better it will be for all concerned.

You know, I know, that the Indian parents have a strong and parental desire to have their children home for a few days during the Christmas festivities. Such a feeling is quite natural and to be highly commended.

Under the domestic administration of the Agency you are also cognizant of the fact, that whereas some of the students will remain in school while a certain number will go home during that period. I know that you are further convinced that all will return in time for the New Years Celebrations.

While 'st I heartily and sympathetically agree to a few days holiday being granted during the Christmas season, yet academically, ecclesiastically, officially and personally, I most emphatically disagree to giving a holiday under such conditions, minus payment of the official and authorised Grant. Obviously, provision has already been made and anticipated, for the continued residence of the students during the period of say, two, three, or four days, as the case may be. Yet it is impossible and unadvisable to discharge the members of the School Staff and close the School for that period, owing to the fact that many of the students would still be in residence and the School routine must continue to function in the normal and accepted manner. The aggregate expenditure would therefore be lessened by the cost of only a few meals not partaken by the absentees, while the income intimated by the suggestion made, would reduce the official Grant and Revenue by several hundred dollars.
As such a high state of efficiency is and rightly demanded by the Department, the proficiency cannot be maintained by the curtailment of the anticipated per capita Grant.

In view of the local and domestic principles involved, I am sending a copy of this letter to the Reverend Principal of the St. Mary's Roman School, with the hope that we may mutually and respectfully ask for the sustained and regular payment of the Grant, while at the same time acquiescing to the wishes of the parents and allow the brief holiday as requested.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Sir:

On my return to this office today from a visit to Lesser Slave Lake Agency, I found a letter from Agent J. E. Pugh, addressed to the Secretary, attached to which are letters addressed to him by the Rev. Canon S. Middleton and Rev. P. A. Charbon, Principals of St. Paul's and St. Mary's Indian Residential Schools, which are self-explanatory.

When at the Blood Agency on the 18th ultimo, Head-Chief, Shot on Both Sides and Minor Chiefs, Own Different Horses and John Cotton, made the request to Agent Pugh and myself that the pupils of the two residential schools on the reserve be allowed to return to their homes on the reserve for Christmas vacations: I informed them that authority would have to be obtained from the Department, as was done last year. I then asked Agent Pugh to write both Principals, informing them of the request, and mentioning that it would likely affect the per capita grant. The following day, Agent Pugh and I visited both schools, when I mentioned the matter to the Principals, who, while agreeing that the Indians' request was a natural one, emphatically expressed themselves as opposed to a reduction of the per capita grant, for the period of the holidays. I then asked them to reply, in writing, to Mr. Pugh's letter, which they had received that day.

Last year, the month-end holidays, which had been customary for years past, were discontinued: This aroused the Indians somewhat. However, our point was won, and the Band pacified by allowing them Christmas holidays. This year no mention has been made regarding the month-end holidays. What effect the refusing of Christmas holidays will have upon the Indian parents, and whether it will cause dissatisfaction and desertion amongst the pupils, I cannot say.

Both Principals agree that the pecuniary saving made to the schools during the absence of the pupils who go home at Christmas, is negligible, and does not begin to offset the amount deducted from the per capita grant.

I note in his letter No. 150-37 of December 18th, 1937, second paragraph, the Superintendent of Welfare and Training states:

"...under present regulations, no grant can be allowed for the period pupils are absent for Christmas holidays."

In view of this, and the Principals' objections to losing part of the grant, it seems to me that the proper thing for the Department to do is to refuse the Indians' request for holidays, and thereby relieve the Principals of the unpleasant task of doing so.

To: The Inspector, Indian Agents and Principals of Indian Residential Schools in the Province of Alberta.

I desire to direct your attention to the fact that provincial regulations regarding additional or extended summer holidays do not apply to Indian children attending Indian residential schools in Alberta, or to the Indian children attending the Sarcee Indian Day School.

The regulations outlined in Departmental circular No. 1862 of March 30, 1943, also circular letters Nos. 502-643 and 502-645, should be adhered to strictly.

Indian Agents should visit each residential school under their supervision twice during the months of September, October and November. I suggest the first and third Mondays of each of these months. While at the residential school the Indian Agent should prepare a list of all pupils who have not returned to school upon the expiry of their leave. Following this visit the Indian Agent will be expected to make every effort to have the delinquent pupils returned to the residential school concerned at the earliest possible date. It is unnecessary for me to point out the importance of having pupils return promptly at the start of the new academic year.

In issuing the above instructions to Indian Agents, it is not our idea that the Principals of residential schools should be relieved of all responsibility. In the case of pupils who do not return on the expiry of the summer holiday period, the Rev. Principal should make a personal attempt to have such delinquents returned promptly.

Complete co-operation between the Principal of the residential school and the Indian Agent and other Government officials should have a beneficial result.

Acting Director.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of letter #103-1-6 of the 19th June last relative to Inspector Evenson's report on the two Schools of this Agency, namely the Blood R.C. and St. Paul's Anglican Residential Schools.

On receipt of the Department's letter, I wrote both Principals quoting the excerpt as given by Inspector Evenson, and I attach herewith, a letter received from the Principal of the St. Paul's Anglican School in reply, and the Rev. Father Charron advises that he is writing, but to-date this Office has not received a reply, and it is possible that this may have been sent direct to the Department.

Both Principals advise me that they discussed the matter with Inspector Evenson, asking that their comment be embodied in his report, and this apparently has been carried out.

In the opinion of the writer, it would appear that Truancy is the only answer, brought about through varying causes, which are undoubtedly affected through non-return at the end of Summer Holidays, monthly week-end Holidays, and Xmas Holidays. All of the latter have been the subject of correspondence over a period of years, and it is found that such are being given.

The matter of the return of the Pupils to Schools at the close of the Summer Holidays has been a problem, and prior to the outbreak of War, Section 10 of the Indian Act was applied quite often, notices being served by R.C.M. Police Officers, who were oftentimes conveyed in Agency vehicles for this purpose, but during the War I am given to understand that this has largely devolved largely upon the School authorities, who have spent a lot of time and gasoline in covering the country endeavouring to obtain the children's return to School, and this has been aggravated by the Indian parents who were working out off the Reserve for high wages and in widely separated areas, and a long way removed from the Schools.

It was noted that last Fall, the above was the general atmosphere, and it was also found that Holidays were a regular monthly affair, and that Xmas Holidays were included.

In perusal of the Files I find that Agents and Principals were requested not to lean on the R.C.M. Police for the return of Pupils due to War emergencies, but I did interview the local Detachment in this respect, and request that the matter be placed before the Officer Commanding, R.C.M. Police, LETHERIDGE, which I reported to the Department under cover our 402-11 CE-1 of October 23rd, 1944.

At that time I adopted the procedure of making up the Truancy Notices and the Schools delivering same. This method met with the indifference of the parents concerned, no prosecutions were made.

In reviewing the problem with a view to finding a solution, the writer is of the opinion, that the Agent is in the main the one who is held responsible, if a child is either not returned from Summer Holidays or other Holidays, I am therefore (over).................
of the opinion that, (to eradicate the criticisms offered by the Principals', which apparently was done in this connection), the Principals of both Schools should be notified that no Holidays, either monthly or other Holidays, will be allowed, and it is further suggested that this be in the form of a letter from the Branch, which could be posted on the School "NOTICE" boards, and also at the Agency, this is requested inasmuch as there is a tendency on the part of the Indians to presume that the matter of Holidays is a local affair.

It is anticipated that the Indians will protest strongly any action to curtail Holidays, and a review of correspondence entered into from this Agency prior to the War will support this prediction.

I do not concur in the suggestion of the Principal of St. Paul's School, that the matter be discussed before the Council, I however do concur in the appointment of a Truant Officer, or that the services of the R.C.M. Police be used in the matter of Truancy, and the facilities of the Schools could be used to transport R.C.M. Police Officers to serve Truancy Notices when required, but when a prosecution is to be made, it is thought that this should be carried out by the R.C.M. Police acting as Truant Officer. Should this latter method be approved, may we ask if a supply of "Notice to Parents, Guardian or other Person by Truant Officer" be sent forward prior to the opening of the Schools.

It is intended that a check-up of the School Rolls be made on the 4th September, and a report made to the Department for two purposes, that of attendance at Schools, and to the Family Allowance Directorate at EDMONTON.

May we be advised of any suggestion in this matter.

I am in receipt of your letter of the 17th ultimo, with reference to the Blood and St. Paul's Residential Schools, regarding truancy and absences at both of these schools during the past academic year.

I am also in receipt of your telegram of the 6th instant, reporting the small enrolment at both schools for the academic year 1945-46. Both of these communications refer to the same subject and consequently are being answered in one letter.

As you will remember, we have had correspondence for many years regarding the practice followed at the two schools in question, where holidays have been allowed at week-ends and on other occasions, contrary to departmental instructions and the general practice at other residential schools throughout the Dominion.

In order that the matter may again be placed before the Principals, I am forwarding two extra copies of this letter, one of which should be handed to each Principal. In connection with this letter I wish to direct attention to the contents of circular letter of June 11, 1945, and of March 30, 1937.

The Department feels that holidays on week-ends and other special occasions should be discontinued immediately, and if the Principals persist in ignoring our instructions in this regard, they should be informed...
that a note should be made on the quarterly return of every day any pupil is absent and grant will not be allowed. While it may place additional work on your office, I feel certain that you will co-operate with us in this regard, by checking the returns before forwarding them to us, in order to make certain that the Principals have not asked grant for pupils who have been allowed out on unauthorized holiday leave.

The payment of family allowances may enter into the matter this year, and it should be kept in mind that Family Allowance officials are satisfied to have Section 10 of the Indian Act apply instead of Section 29 of their Regulations. This being the case, children of 6 years of age, and who have not yet reached 7, may be granted family allowance. Children of 7 years of age and over are obliged to attend school, and if parents are holding at home children who are of school age according to Section 10 of the Indian Act, it is your duty as Indian Agent to immediately notify the Regional Director of Family Allowances of the names of such children, and the family allowance payments for them will be discontinued.

If the condition mentioned in your telegram of the 4th instant shows no sign of improvement, you may take the necessary action, under Section 10 of the Indian Act (subsections 3, 4, 5 and 6). In the latter subsection you will notice that every member of the R.C.M.P. is considered a truant officer. Under separate cover you are being forwarded a supply of the notice that is required to be given to parent, guardian or other person by the truant officer.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, File No. 150-37, with reference to the granting of monthly holidays to the pupils of the St Paul's Anglican and Blood Residential School of this agency, and enclosing a Petition from the Blood Indians.

In reply thereto, I wish to state that this matter has had considerable attention from time to time, and the writer is of the opinion that the granting of a holiday at the end of each month to the pupils of both schools, would it is thought create a better feeling towards our educational system on this Agency.

If such is granted there are certain rules that should be laid down as hard and fast regulations, these suggest should be as follows:

That such holiday be granted at the end of each month, falling on the last Sunday.
That such holiday be from 10 AM on the Saturday Morning, and under no circumstances, should pupils be allowed out on the Friday evening.
That all pupils should be returned to the respective schools on Sunday evening at 4 PM.
That in the event of parents not returning their children at the stated time, the following month's holiday should be curtailed.
That on the opening of Schools in September, any child or children not reporting back to school on the given opening date, should not be granted the privilege of monthly holidays prior to the Xmas term.

The Principals have not been consulted prior to writing this letter, as their thoughts are known on the subject, and subject to the rules outlined above I do not think that they would object to the granting of the monthly holiday.

It is understood that the habit of many of the parents not bringing their children back promptly after a holiday, does disrupt their management.

I note that Mr. Allan suggests 9 PM for return, this is considered late for the school management, entailing the settling down of the pupils just prior to bedtime.

It is also suggested that at Xmas the holiday be from Saturday the 22nd until Wednesday the 26th at 4 PM, with no further holiday until the last Sunday of January.

It is felt that if the foregoing rules were put into effect by the respective schools, and all breaches of discipline in respect to the holiday treated as suggested, the cooperation of the Indians would be readily given.

The petition and Mr. Allan's note are herewith returned.

Respectfully submitted and recommended.

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

We, the undersigned Indians of the Blood Indian Reservation near Cardston, Alberta having been advised of the new rule that children attending school on our reservation will not in future be permitted to come home except during the summer vacation wish to protest this ruling.

We ask if the reason for this, is that a number of the parents do not abide by the rules and regulations of the school. We ask that this rule be used against them and an exception be made for those that abide by the rules.

Our children are taken away from us at the age of seven and do not leave school till sixteen (16) years of age. This is the time child needs a mother's care. In a boarding school they are taught to do things in a routine way therefore they have no idea of home life and they lose the respect for the parents, past experience has proven this.

We ask that we have them home once a month and on all holidays to which a Canadian child is entitled. In this way we hope to do our duty by our children as mothers and fathers, and further more we are human beings and would like justice done to us like any other free people. An Indian is a more attached parent than a white parent. We go through thick and thin even under the poor circumstances in which we are living.

We ask again that a rule be made to permit that those who do not keep the school rules be punished and that the others have an exception to this rule.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I received your letter regarding Christmas Holidays for Residential Schools. I understand the Minister's attitude in referring this question to the Joint Committee. However, I feel justified in asking authorization to send home, for Christmas Holidays, the children whose parents are willing to take home, for the following reasons:

1... We have in our district, a group of Indians who are influenced by some politicians and who are trying to find all kinds of grievances against the present Indian Administration and our system of education.

It is a general feeling among our good Indians that the granting of Christmas Holidays would appease many bad feelings towards the School and would bring more sympathy towards the Indian Affairs Branch. (Can we really blame the parents to want their children home, at least a few times during the year. Is this not a natural desire?).

2... The Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School used to grant Christmas Holidays some twenty years ago. It became a financial problem. Many children did not return promptly and others came back suffering from some sickness etc.

It is evident that the conditions of the Indians in our district have changed. I am confident that nowadays the Christmas Holidays would have many advantages.

3... When the Joint Committee will consider this matter, how will it be able to determine that the time has come or not for the Indian children in Residential Schools, to be allowed with success, Christmas Holidays, if there is no experiment made? Since we have here, children coming from twelve different reserves, would not our School be an ideal one to make the experiment? I would be glad to send you an extensive report of the success or lack of success obtained; the reactions of the parents, the feelings of the children etc.
Indian Residential School

Lebret, Saskatchewan

4... It would be understood that the parents would take the responsibility of the transportation of their children. They would come for them or have them sent on the train at their own expenses. The highest fare (return ticket) to be paid would be $1.60 for children over 12 and $0.90 for those under 12.

5... There would be a great disappointment among the majority of our Indians if the children are not going home this year for Christmas Holidays, because for the last three years especially, the parents have been pressing us strongly with their demand to have their children home at Christmas. These demands have always been deferred until the following year.

6... We would be in a better position this year, to exact from the parents, good care of their children and a prompt return. Thus, a precedent would be created which would be a guide in our future policy.

Memorandum: Mr. Hoey

I desire to refer to letter of Dec. 5th from the Principal of the Qu'Appelle Residential School with regard to allowing the children to go home for a 12 day holiday at Christmas.

In view of our recent discussion of the contents of this letter and other similar communications that we have received during the past few weeks, I submit the following for your approval:

1. During the past few years, we have received requests from a number of the Indian Residential Schools especially in the Prairie Provinces, to allow children to go home for Christmas leave. We have been informed that the parents are very anxious to have them do so. We have never officially approved or granting such leave but due to changing conditions, I feel that it might be advisable to make an experiment this year with certain of our residential schools.

2. With the above in mind, I recommend that the Principals of the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, File Hills Residential School, and Gordon's Indian Residential School be authorized to allow home for holidays those children whose home conditions are suitable. This permission to be granted on the following terms:

(a) The children may be allowed home on Dec. 23rd and return to the school on Jan. 2, 1947.

(b) Transportation of children both ways to be paid by the parents, neither the Department or the school management being expected to incur this expenditure.
3. In order to have complete information regarding this experiment, it is suggested that the attached questionnaire be forwarded to the Principals of each of the residential schools previously mentioned.

4. A circular letter should be forwarded to all residential schools advising them of the action we are taking and pointing out that the results will be carefully studied and submitted to the Minister with a view to definitely determining if Christmas leave at all residential schools would be advisable for the future.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

RE CHRISTMAS AND NEW YEARS HOLIDAYS.

The Indians have been informed that the authorities at Ottawa are not in favor and oppose the granting of school holidays to Indian children during the yuletide season.

No one knows the real reason why the Indian Department at Ottawa takes that attitude towards the granting of those holidays.

The churches and their missionaries who have custody of the Indian children have repeatedly told the Indians that they are in favor of giving the holidays to the children, as one missionary put it, "in the spirit of peace on earth and goodwill towards all men."

In the past, some schools have granted the holidays to the pupils of their schools, and as far as we can ascertain, no ill effects on the children was noticed as a result of the holidays.

As far as we can ascertain, the authorities at Ottawa oppose the granting of those holidays because of sickness and epidemics.

We quite agree that if epidemics are in progress, isolation is the best means of preventing the disease from spreading.

But to believe and be of the opinion that the holidays in themselves are the cause of epidemics is something hard to understand.

We must remember, on some reserves the standard of living is remarkably high.

Another possible reason why the Indian Officials at Ottawa oppose the holidays may be, because in some districts a school may not be on an Indian Reserve. Some Indian schools serve several reserves, those reserves may be widely separated and many miles apart.

The school in these cases is located at as near a central point as is possible.

In those cases there may be some virtue in keeping the children at school because of transportation difficulties.

In Alberta nearly all schools are located on an Indian reserve; hence, there is practically no transportation problems.

There are no real difficulties in getting the children back to school.

When the school is located on an Indian reserve there is no reason why the children should not be granted the school holidays.

The point we wish to raise is this, why make a regulation general in its effect when that regulation is necessary only because it serves the purpose in one or two cases, or why break the legs of all the Indians because one or two Indians broke their legs.

When making regulations one must never forget the possible effects which a regulation may have on the Indians in general.

The Indians have been led to believe that the Christmas holidays are a great cause for happiness and rejoicing, an event to look forward to for family reunions in a spirit of thankfulness that God has been kind and has preserved our health and our lives for the occasion.

(Cont next page.)
The Indian has been told, on Christmas Day a Savior was born as a manifestation of the tolerance and goodness of God.

A large number of the Indians actually believe that the Indian department at Ottawa oppose the granting of Christmas holidays because, originally, the holidays were a white man's affair and that the Indian children do not deserve the holidays merely because they are Indians.

All white children in the neighborhood of this reserve will be at home, away from the formalities and restricting of school life.

The poor Indian child, because of an inhumane regulation will be kept behind high walls and closed doors as it were.

When those men who are in favor of and support such a regulation sit down at their Christmas table with their own children will they think of the misery they have caused others.

HISERY

TEDDY YELLOWFLY.
Blackfoot Indian Agency,
Gleichen, Dec. 10, 1946.

March 21st 1947.

Mr. R. Hoey,
Director, Indian Affairs Branch
OTTAWA, Ont.

Re: Home leave for Pupils during Term.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I am taking the liberty of addressing you personally on a matter important to the conduct of this school, that is, the granting of leave to local children to visit their homes once or twice a week during the school term, and at Christmas and Easter.

Perhaps you may be aware that, at the time of my appointment here, there were two major problems..... apart from finance. They were, first, discipline and conduct within the school, and secondly, the relationship between the school and the local Indians.

The two problems, I decided, had some bearing on each other. The local pupils were allowed to go home at times during the week and the parents were permitted to take them out of school to make purchases for them in the Town. Many complaints had been received about pupil conduct outside of the school, and, naturally, any and all misdemeanours occurring on the reserves or in the neighbourhood were blamed on the school pupils.

Another circumstance that had an acute bearing on school discipline was the fact that the local Indian people had, when this school catered mainly to the local Agency, looked upon the school as pertaining to them particularly. On the enlargement of the school ressentiment arose and strong hostility was met by the "non-Indians" pupils from distant Agencies, who had been transferred here from the old Coqualeetza school. Local parents insulated this resentment in their children attending the school. Further, because of this condition, local parents were constant in their demand for special privileges for their children.

Mr. Scott, my predecessor, has told me that he also recognised the leave for local children as being subversive of order and discipline and tried to institute a prohibitory rule, but was unsuccessful against the demands of the local parents. As a new Principal, I instituted the rule and have adhered to it rigidly. The reasons for it, as noted here, and also in regard to possibly the more important matter of general school health, has been fully explained to the local Indian parents, both individually and collectively. Some six months after I took over the school, on the first visit of Major MacKay, the local parents met with him here and made a request for the discarding of the "no home leave" regulation. At that meeting the whole matter was gone into, emphasizing the matter of Health, the local Indians having explained to them fully the very excellent system of detecting and eliminating T.B. among the pupils by X-ray and Tuberculin Test Clinics which is conducted at the school, among all pupils, as soon after the summer vacation as possible, during which summer vacation the disease could be and all too frequently is contracted by pupils by contagion at the Canneries. It was explained that two or three such Clinics are conducted at the school after the summer vacation, and that, after three months of such test and detection, it is safe to assume that the exonerated pupils are free from contraction of the disease during the rest of the term........ so long as they do not have further opportunities from outside. Frequent leave, such as was demanded by the parents, during the term, would provide such means of contagion, and would neutralise the usefulness of the Clinics. There are a number of active T.B. cases on the local reserves.
Further, on my first visit to parents, on distant reserves, during my first summer here, complaints were received that pupils had returned home in June with scabies and headlice, where they had been sent to school clean the previous September. I investigated, and in one house on the local reserve I found severe cases of scabies and impetigo among the pre-school age children and, in this house also, an advanced case of T.B., in a boy nine years old, since dead. This was a home that some of the school children visited when permitted leave. Headlice was even more prevalent on the reserves. Many of the Indian homes were very clean and well cared for, but there are the exceptions that provide the infection.

After prohibiting home leave, I instructed my staff that head-lice, scabies and impetigo, which are fairly prevalent when the pupils return to school in September, must be eliminated by intensive treatment within one month after the pupils return. This, I may say, is entirely possible when the pupils have been removed from outside contagion, and it has been done. However great an effort is made in the school to control these conditions, however, we occasionally get infection of this nature from children coming with their parents to visit pupils in the school, visiting which is permitted on Wednesday, Saturday and Sunday Afternoons each week. As must be obvious the regular and the great majority of visitors are from the local reserves.

All this, as I say, was explained to the local Indian people, and they readily admitted the facts and that conditions had much improved since the "no leave" rule had been instituted. But, with the notorious insistence of the Indian on the preservation of his rights (or what, in this instance, had been permitted as a privilege) and finally considered by them as a "right" they still insisted that they wanted their children home. The relationship of the school with the Indian people has been quite harmonious, with the exception of this matter of home leave, and even this has been dormant until just before last Christmas.

I am enclosing a letter just published in the local paper, signed by one George Clute, who is an intelligent man, at least up to the point where logic and reason meets up with racial stubbornness in the protection of so-called "rights." He is possibly the most vociferous in the present demand. I may say that George has two small children in the school, placed here since the rule in question went into effect. This rule was specifically agreed to by him as a condition of his placing his children in the school.

A few of the local parents work in the lumber mills here and are members of the I.W.A. Union. This Union, whose reputation, I am sure, is nation wide, is rather notorious for taking up any matter that might embarrass the Government or Government institutions. Just before last Christmas, the officials of this Union petitioned the City Councils of Port Alberni and of Alberni, the Provincial Member of Parliament, appealing for their intervention in the matter of home leave for the local Indian pupils. The Mayors of the two towns and the local Member immediately phoned me acquainting me with the complaint, and saying that there should have been obvious to the Union officials even after discounting their irrationality of thought and procedure wherever they think they can stir up trouble) that the matter was no business of theirs. I phoned the Secretary of the Union and explained the situation to him again. I invited him to come and look over the school so that he could become acquainted with the situation they were interested in. He promised to come the following day, but has not been here yet. In spite of the information and invitation I had given him, he still later appeared before the Councils and as a result the matter was aired in the local newspapers, with some totally erroneous statements such as that the parents were only allowed to visit one hour a week. To correct Public Opinion I wrote to the Councils explaining the reason for the leave prohibition. I particularly asked for no newspaper controversy, but the Councils thought that the public should be informed and the rebuttal was published in the papers and the matter dropped.
Mr. Hoey, (3)

I may say also that, while this controversy was in progress, I received your circular letter on this very matter, in reference to the experiment being made on three Reserves in Saskatchewan, and stating that the result of this experiment would govern Department policy regarding inter-term pupil leave in the future. Also, the circular stated that leave permitted last Christmas only applied to the three schools in question. Other schools would continue with the long-established policy of the Department in extending no leave.

As the case for the establishment of the "no leave" rule had been placed directly on myself (the thing the Indian people cannot understand is that other schools, including the Islamic residential school at Kakawis, permit frequent home leave for their pupils... I must confess I cannot understand this situation either) I mentioned to the Councils, and this subsequently appeared in the newspaper, that the prohibition was a Department ruling.

One would have thought that here the matter could have been entirely dropped, but recently Clutecl was invited to speak at an A.O.T.S. Club meeting in the United Church. He voluntarily took Indians "wrong" as his subject and read the enclosed letter at the meeting. Dr. Dorsey was expected on a visit the following week and it was decided to place the matter before him. (I was not present at the A.O.T.S. meeting) Dr. Dorsey was here last week and an Indian delegation of three met him and the letter written by Clutecl was read again. I was present and went over the argument again (a procedure which I knew from experience would be futile) and clinched the matter with reference to the recent epidemic of a rather bad type of measles, and also mumps, on the local reserves. We did not have a single case in the school, but could not possibly have avoided it had the children been granted the leave the parents are asking for.... as, of course, the contagious period of measles is before the parents, and especially Indian parents, could have detected symptoms of the disease. As expected, however, no argument could convince the Indian delegates that their rights were not being infringed, hence Dr. Dorsey can wholly in accord with the present rules put it to him that I had a choice of two evils... keep to the rule and incur the continued ill-feeling (on this point alone) of the local Indians, or abandon the rule and run the risk of infection among the 230 pupils in residence. One cannot question as to which choice is the wise one.

I am writing this, not because of any wish for Department assistance in the local situation, but in regard to the effect of possible future Department policy on the situation at this school. In view of the announcement of future policy as mentioned in your circular letter previously referred to, I told the delegation that I would conform to the Department policy regarding home leave as soon as such policy was announced. Referring to the practice at other residential schools, specifically the Kakawis School, the delegation still insisted that the matter of home leave rested with me as the Principal. May I, therefore, outline future possible policy as it might apply to conditions at this school.

1st. The Saskatchewan schools at which the Christmas experiment was conducted, cater, I believe, to mainly local pupils. All, or practically all, would conveniently go home on occasional weekly leave, or at Christmas and Easter. The Alberni school draws a large proportion of its pupilage from distant Agencies, Alert Bay, Queen Charlottes, Naam-Skema (Prince Rupert), Behime (Hastleton) Bella Coola, etc., as well as from the West Coast Agency. It would be obviously impossible for home leave to be taken advantage of by any but a small percentage of the pupils.
Local pupils at this school number approximately 30 out of a total pupilage of 230. About 70 pupils (exclusive of the local Alberni pupils) are from the West Coast Agency, and could conceivably be permitted leave within the periods of the Christmas and Easter holidays. However, it would appear that the parents of many of these West Coast Agency pupils do not desire such leave. The Alberni people, in order to press and gain their demand for home leave, have, on a number of occasions, sought to enlist the support of other native Bands along the Alberni Canal. These bands have consistently refused to ask for a change in the present rules. Many have expressed their approval of the present system verbally, and I have voluntary letters on file from them. One of these dated Nov. 5th 1948, from Fort Albion (Ucluelet). I will quote from—

"Dear Mr. Caldwell, I'm sure glad that you are keeping up with rules in the school. I sure would be disappointed if you had the kids running around free. Keep it up, Mr. Caldwell. Your doing splendid work. All the people from here that has children there are all satisfied with the kids for being kept in the school grounds, otherwise, had they been free, anything happens in the reserve the school boys would get the blame. Remember, Mr. Caldwell, good word is good against one whole Indian Reserve........... We have a few Alberni Indian women here at this cannery that told us about the school, but remember, we are not against you at all. Keep up the good work all Ucluelets are quite satisfied with your good work at that school."

Signed. (Philip Mack.)

I quote this to indicate that the demand for leave is purely a local one and is not only not supported, but is actually opposed by other Bands within the same Agency.

Permitting the 30 local children to frequent their own, and other's homes on the local reserves, coming in contact with, not only "outside," but "contagious" cases of T.B., would neutralize the whole excellent T.B. control programme (as outlined herein), now in practice, and would endanger the whole 230 pupils in the school. This would also apply to epidemics of measles, mumps, etc., and to conditions of impetigo, scabies and headlice which are common in some of the less progressive homes on the reserves. In other words, it would scarcely be possible for the Principal to accept responsibility for health conditions in the school, emanating from sources over which he has no control.

Permitting the 30 local pupils "home leave" has been, and would again be, upsetting to the 200 children who could not visit their homes because of the distance involved, and this condition would have a detrimental effect on school discipline.

The circular letter above referred to in connection with the experiment conducted last Christmas in the three Saskatchewan residential schools, indicated that from the result of this experiment a Department policy would be formed. It is fairly obvious such policy would apply to all Indian residential schools as the impracticability of granting special privileges to individual Indian cases is well known. It should be obvious also, however, that a policy applicable to a school catering mainly to local pupils might not apply to conditions as a school such as this, where the pupils come from widely distant homes. It might be possible, without too greatly disturbing the whole residential school system, for such a policy of "home leave" to be applied regionally, leaving the schools of British Columbia, for instance, where, in nearly all cases, the pupils are gathered from distant Agencies, out of the "home leave" regulation, if such should be found to be feasible as a result of the Saskatchewan experiment.
In conclusion, may I suggest a solution to the condition here at Alberni, one that would do away with all friction between the residential school and the local Indian people, and would meet with the approval of these people.

The approximately 30 pupils from local homes attending this school could all be accommodated in a day-school situated centrally on the Sheshatshai Reserve, on the River Road, adjacent to the town of Alberni. There is a site for a school, with space for playgrounds. This school could also accommodate some ten children, in addition to the 30 already in this school, for whom accommodation is not at present available in this school. I believe an appropriation has already been requested for such a school, by the United Church, and more recently by the West Coast Indian Agency. It might be suggested that these local pupils could attend the Public Schools in the Alberni Valley, and there would, I think, be no objection to this by the Public school authorities, but the fact is that the school population of the Alberni Valley has increased enormously during the past two years and there is no prospect of accommodation for elementary Indian pupils for some time to come. May I therefore request that the matter of the providing of the day-school be given immediate consideration.

I would not have the Department think that there is too much confinement of pupils in this school. My policy has been to provide as much opportunity of the Indian pupils mixing with the "whites" as possible. To that end, football, baseball and boxing is encouraged with the "whites" in competition. Our pupils visit the sports grounds of the two Cities and teams from the Cities come to the school. This experiment, carried out during the past two years, has been essentially successful, both in establishing normal companionship between the Indian and "white" pupils, and in engendering an affection of the Indian pupils among white residents generally. Our football team is so well known that usually, when a British freighter is loading at Port Alberni, the Sailor's Institute arranges a game between the crew and our senior boys.

Further, we have four pupils attending grade 10 in the Public High School, where they are greatly appreciated, are themselves very happy, and are doing well in their studies.

The local Indian parents, I may say, are given every opportunity of visiting the school, even beyond the hours and days specified as for visiting. Parents wishing to make purchases in Town for their children are always permitted to do so in company with their children, except that, in order not to break the rule established, and to make sure that the children are not taken to the homes, the pupils are taken to town by school car or truck, left with the parents for the required period and then conveyed back to school again.

I trust that you will pardon the length of this explanation. My desire is to acquaint you with the conditions at this school applicable to the matter of "home leave," now under your consideration. I am sure that Dr. Dorey will substantiate the information I have given you.

Yours very truly,

In reading over the attached letter I am impressed with the fact that such a letter would have a tremendous sympathetic influence on an uninformed public. I fancy much of the trouble caused the Department in Indian affairs comes through the channels of a romantically inclined, but factually ignorant public.

I have been exclusively in Indian work, of practically all phases, for over twenty years, and the fact that I am still in the work is evidence that I am not unsympathetically disposed towards Indians and their problems and conditions. The attached letter would indicate a deep emotional sensitivity as an Indian trait. I am afraid that my experience has yet to find such in the Indian race. There is emotional sensitivity; it is true, but it is essentially superficial.

The writer of the letter has become "inebriated with the exuberance of his own verbosity"..... and that is a decided Indian trait. His overwhelming desire for contact with his children is not particularly apparent in that he does not take very regular advantage of the opportunity afforded him to visit them in the school.

To one who understands Indian nature the letter provides a typical example of Indian psychology. I would say, advisedly, that the Indian, generally, is as yet incapable of any depth of sensibility, and this applies to domestic affection. Undoubtedly, they are not yet far enough removed from savage custom and tradition. In many cases still, and among the more advanced communities, the wife is a chattel and marriages are arranged without the consent of the two contractants. Indian girls, mainly through the teaching of the schools, are just emerging from the condition where they accept such "arranged" marriages docilely, and are looking for something more in a husband than just a good "provider".

I do not say that they have no form of affection for their children. The affection they display is something of the nature of the affection of a child for her doll. This applies only while the children are quite young.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I have your letter of April 11th in reply to my letter of March 21st, regarding the matter of home leave. I have no objection whatever to you placing the correspondence before the Joint Parliamentary Committee. The matter referred to is only a local one, but the situation must be duplicated in other instances, and it is an indication of the many complexities of Indian Administration.

I have had Mr. Davis, the School Inspector, here recently on his first visit and we discussed the matter of school leaves and the effect of the present conditions on the local Indian people. I agree with him that the better solution would be to arrange for the local Indian pupils to attend the Public School in Alberni. A school bus service would make such attendance very convenient. This bus service is now in operation for the public school pupils, including the High School pupils attending from this school. However, Mr. Davis felt that, due to the lack of accommodation at the Public Schools, with no prospect of improvement for some years, the only present solution would be the establishment of a day school on the Reserve. No doubt he will be reporting on this matter.

In an effort to cope with the dissatisfaction which arises out of the present situation, I requested the Supervisor of the Alberni District Schools to take up the matter of the entry of Indian children in the public schools with the School Board. This he did at a meeting last Monday and he reports back to me that, while the Board would have no objection to Indian pupils attending the Public Schools, there is no prospect of accommodation being available for them for a long time. The situation in the local Public Schools is perhaps unique. This is a fast growing community. A year ago the local High School accommodated 120 pupils. There are now 600 pupils and the High School is being accommodated in temporary buildings of an Army Camp. The elementary school population is now 2800; with crowded accommodation. Further, on the present population alone, it is estimated that the pupilage of both the High and the Elementary Schools will double in the next six years.
I give the foregoing information to indicate that the Public Schools cannot very well be considered as a solution to our local educational problem.

I am enclosing a cutting from the local paper of this week, making mention of a resolution passed by the Native Brotherhood at their Convention at Nanaimo recently. It is worthy of note that this resolution was presented by the representative from the Alberni Reserve. I do not suppose there was any presentation made of reasons for the weekly leave restrictions. It is likely the Rev. Peter Kelly will be a Brotherhood delegate to the Joint Committee. It might be productive of good if this whole matter of inter-term leave, with all the facts pro and con to hand, were discussed with him.

I scarcely think it is fair to expect responsibility on the part of a Principal for school health should this home leave be allowed. The visiting of relatives, and especially pre-school-age children (which is permitted here on three afternoons each week) provides in itself a considerable health risk. Our experience this year goes far to prove this. During the winter there was a severe epidemic of measles outside the school and on the reserves. I quarantined the visitors during the epidemic and we did not have one case in the school. Just now there is an epidemic of "flu" in the district. This got into the school last Sunday and we have had over seventy cases during the week. With such a non-registered nurse in charge, this is a period of strain that could have been avoided if we did not have the local public situation. I certainly would not suggest any such drastic step as to prohibit visiting at the school, but, in our case, our main corridors are full of parents and children during the whole afternoons of Sunday, Wednesday and Saturday, and, if there is any cause of infection, the opportunity thus afforded is ample.

In view of the condition at the Public Schools in this district, I would be glad if the Department would give serious consideration to the prospect of giving the local Indians a day school on the Reserve.

TO PRINCIPALS OF INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS.

This letter will deal with two main points in the administration of Indian Residential Schools.

(a) Christmas Holidays
(b) Qualifications of Teachers.

(a) Christmas Holidays:

As you are aware, it has not been the practice of the Department to allow holidays at Christmas. For physical and other reasons, we have always felt that it was in the best interests of the children to remain in the residential schools during the Christmas holiday period and from reports received, we were under the impression that all our schools provided special food and entertainment for the children at this period of the year.

However, in recent years we have had increased requests from some Principals and from some Indian parents to allow Christmas holidays and due to changing conditions we decided last year to conduct an experiment with certain of our residential schools.

It was decided to allow Christmas holidays to pupils attending the Qu'Appelle, the File Hills and the Gordon's Residential Schools. A survey form was completed by each principal after the holidays. Of 447 pupils granted leave, 430 (96%) returned on the proper date. The number of returnees would have been higher but for a severe storm (-40 degrees below zero) at the time. The reaction of the principals was varied -- with two being decidedly in favour of the plan and one opposed. In all instances the physical condition of the children on their return was good. The reaction of the parents and children was decidedly favourable.

Therefore, the Department has decided on the following policy with regard to Christmas Holidays for Residential Schools:

(a) Due to the widely varying conditions existing in our residential schools, the decision as to the permitting of children to return to their homes at Christmas will be left in the hands of the principal of the school. In some schools it is a relatively easy matter to send the children home, in others it is very difficult. Taking this factor and others into account, it is felt that the principal of the school concerned is the one who should make this decision. It is suggested that before making his decision known, each principal should consult his local Indian Agent and also the principals of other residential schools in the area (if any).

(b) Those children whose home conditions are suitable may be allowed to go home on December 20 on the distinct understanding that they will return to the school by January 4, 1948.

(c) It must be clearly understood by all concerned that the transportation of the children both ways will be paid by the parents. Neither the Department nor the school management is expected to incur this expenditure.
(d) No claim can be made for Family Allowances for the 14 days the children are at home.

(e) Each child should take home his progress record card for signature by his parents or guardians.

(f) The Department will make a full per capita grant for the children who are on Christmas holidays.

It is suggested that a mimeographed letter be sent to the parents of these children outlining the above facts which immediately concern them. In certain instances, principals may wish to point out to parents the fact that future Christmas holidays for their children depend on their compliance with the above regulations.

(b) Qualifications of Teachers:

In order to present an accurate picture of the qualifications of our teachers to the parliamentary committee we wish to have the attached forms completed by each classroom teacher. Would all principals please have their teachers complete these forms and have them forwarded to the Department within five days after the arrival of this letter.

Director.

BULLETIN No. I.  SEPTEMBER 1st, 1920

The Red Cross as a Peace-time Organization

"The members of the League agree to encourage and promote the establishment and co-operation of duly authorized, voluntary, National Red Cross organizations, having as purposes the improvement of health, the prevention of disease, and the mitigation of suffering throughout the world."

(Covenant of the League of Nations, Article 25.)
The Red Cross as a Peace-Time Organization

This issue of THE BULLETIN is devoted entirely to a brief sketch of the relations between the various elements in the Red Cross Peace-Time Organization.—League of Red Cross Societies,—Canadian Red Cross Society,—Ontario Division and Local Branches.

In War Time

Formerly a War Organization

Prior to May 5th, 1919, the Red Cross was in constitution and purpose a War-time organization. Its function was to act as a voluntary auxiliary to the Army Medical Service in time of war. Such an auxiliary organization is necessary in order that the Medical Service may quickly mobilize in sufficient strength those voluntary forces which are needed to enable it to meet the necessities of the sick and wounded in time of war. This statement is borne out by the fact that ever since the League has given its permission to its National Red Cross Societies as the official channel for voluntary medical aid to the sick and wounded soldiers in time of war.

The Transition to Peace Time Work

Work for War Prisoners and Refugees

But during the Great War, the Red Cross Societies of Allied and neutral countries found it impossible to limit their work of mercy to the armies. Our soldiers who were held as prisoners of war in enemy countries had to be cared for. They were inhumanely treated, in violation of international usage, and deprived even of necessaries of life, and it became imperative to send to them regular supplies of food and clothing. The Red Cross, as the internationally recognized means of communication with prisoners of war, became an official channel through which supplies were sent. While this meant to our unfortunate men languishing in prison camps, will never be fully realized, except by the men themselves.

Refugees from the invaded and devastated regions of France, Flanders, Italy and Serbia, and broken and diseased civilians repatriated through neutral countries constituted a problem in health, sanitation and relief which the Red Cross could not ignore.

Relief Work After the Armistice

After the Armistice, as the demands of the armies rapidly diminished, the demands for civilian relief as rapidly increased. This was due to the freeing of invaded areas, the repatriation and demobilization of enlisted men, the disorganization of civil life due to the War, under-feeding of civilian population and the terrible aftermath of disease and poverty which always follows war. The Red Cross Societies did not slow responding to these needs. As their supplies and organization were released from the demands of the armies, their energies were directed towards providing civilian relief in Belgium, France, Italy, Serbia, Roumania, Siberia and Czecho-Slovakia.

These features of Red Cross activity,—the aid to war prisoners, the aid to refugees from devastated districts, and the post-Armistice relief work in war-stricken countries—represent three stages in the transition of the Red Cross from a war-time to a peace-time organization.

The League of Red Cross Societies: How it was Formed

Committee of Red Cross Societies to Discuss Peace Work

The organization of the League of Red Cross Societies came about in the following way.—In December, 1918, one month after the Armistice, with the approval and indorsement of the Governments of the five great powers, Great Britain, France, Italy, Japan and the United States, a Committee of their Red Cross Societies was convened "to formulate and propose to the Red Cross Societies of the world an extended programme of Red Cross activities in the interest of humanity."

Conference of Medical Experts to Suggest Plans

This Committee called a Conference of the leading medical experts of the world which was held at Cannes in the early part of April, 1919. The Conference outlined a programme of Peace-time work of the Red Cross Societies of the world. To carry out this programme the League of Red Cross Societies was formed at Paris on May 5th, 1919, with headquarters at Geneva.

The League Formed, Paris May 5th, 1919

The League was formed in Paris on May 5th, 1919, with the approval of the five great powers. It is mentioned in Article 25 of the Covenant of the League of Nations which reads: "Members of the League agree to encourage and promote the establishment and co-operation of duly-authorized, voluntary, national Red Cross organizations, having as purposes the improvement of health, the prevention of disease and the mitigation of suffering throughout the world."

Membership of League

The National Red Cross Societies of the five great powers,—Great Britain, France, Italy, Japan and the United States, became founder members of the
The Work of the League

The League is purely voluntary organization. It is non-political, non-governmental and non-sectarian and therefore has no statutory connections with the League of Nations or any government. The objects of the League are:

1. To encourage and promote in every country of the world the establishment and development of duly-authorized, voluntary, national Red Cross organizations, having as purposes the improvement of health, the prevention of disease, and the mitigation of suffering throughout the world, and to secure the co-operation of such organizations for these purposes.

2. To promote the welfare of mankind by furnishing a medium for bringing within the reach of all peoples the benefits to be derived from present known facts and new contributions to science and medical knowledge, and their application.

3. To furnish a medium for coordinating relief work in case of great national or international calamities.

The Canadian Red Cross Society

The Canadian Red Cross Society has become a member of the League, and is planning to carry out its objects by a programme of Peace Work organized Nationally, Provincially and Locally.

At a Conference held in Winnipeg, September 9th and 10th, 1919, the Charter of the Canadian Society was altered to include Article 25 of the League of Nations' Covenant, as above quoted.

The functions of the Canadian Society will be—

1. To continue to act as a voluntary auxiliary to the Militia Department.

2. To act as a voluntary auxiliary to the Federal Department of Health;

3. To furnish the connecting link between Provincial Divisions and Local Branches and the League of Red Cross Societies;

4. To conduct such health and organization propaganda as can best be done nationally;

5. To co-operate with all nationally-organized, official and voluntary health organizations;

6. To transmit to Provincial Divisions all approved appeals which may come from other countries, directly or through the League of Red Cross Societies;

7. In case of need to give grants of money and supplies and to send relief units to other countries and to aid nationally-organized or controlled institutions in Canada;

8. To pass on to Provincial Divisions information received from the League of Red Cross Societies as to the progress of health work in other countries, and to keep each Province informed as to what the other Provinces are doing.

The Ontario Division—Canadian Red Cross Society

The functions of the Ontario Division will be—

1. To act as a voluntary auxiliary to the Provincial Department of Health;

2. To organize Local Branches;

3. To promote Junior Red Cross work;

4. To co-operate with all Provincially-organized, official and voluntary Health bodies;

5. To aid Provincially-organized or controlled Health institutions;

6. To furnish supplies and medical and nursing aid to remote parts of the Province not sufficiently organized or not financially able to take care of themselves;

7. To co-operate with the National Red Cross body in all nationally-organized appeals for relief or medical aid, either for foreign countries or for our own;

8. To recommend the granting of Charters to Local Branches within the Province;

9. To pass on to Local Branches literature issued by the National body, and information which may be considered helpful as to local organization or Health measures;

10. To create and maintain a reserve supply of garments and medical supplies likely to be required in emergencies.

Local Branches Canadian Red Cross Society

The functions of the Local Branches will be—

1. To co-operate with all local, official and voluntary Health organizations;

2. To furnish aid to local Health institutions;

3. To promote co-operation in all local Health work and in Provincial and national Health work as outlined by the Provincial and National bodies;

4. To adopt and be responsible for some one especially outstanding piece of Health work in the community, particularly in cases where a Health measure has to be demonstrated by a voluntary organization before it can be taken over by the municipality or by some other official body;

5. To encourage and support the Junior Red Cross.

6. To stand ready to co-operate at all times with whichever active organization in the community is best equipped to deal with the emergency of the moment;

7. To report as required to the Provincial Division.
The above outline is not intended to be exhaustive or final; nor is it to be understood as an official pronouncement on policy. Its purpose is to show briefly the kind of relations which should exist between the various factions of the Red Cross organizations, from the Local Branch to the League of Red Cross Societies, and to show every member of the Red Cross how his or her effort is vitally related to a great world-wide movement of neighborliness, humanity and mercy. Each individual member should feel that he or she is a vital part of this movement and see clearly that the power of this good and merciful work depends ultimately upon the devotion and service of the individual.
