THE JUNIOR RED CROSS

No. 1 REGINA SASKATCHEWAN April, 1920

Junior Red Cross Work in Saskatchewan

Early in the year 1918, when after nearly four years of struggle with a powerful enemy it was realised that the most extreme efforts must be made to cope with the critical situations that had developed, the Red Cross Society turned to organise more actively the assistance that could be given by the children. In Saskatchewan, on account of the organisation of the schools earlier in the war for other patriotic purposes, the request for the formation of Junior Red Cross Societies readily met with response. In 1915, an appeal had been made to the children on behalf of the Canadian Patriotic Fund, and a large sum of money which was contributed to the Schools Patriotic Fund and turned over by the Department of Education to the Canadian Patriotic Fund. In 1916 upwards of $67,000 was collected by the children of the province for the relief of Belgian children. This fund also was organised by the department through the schools.

The campaign for Junior Red Cross Societies began in April, 1918, when Sir Richard Lake, President of the Saskatchewan Branch, sent through the teachers a letter to the school children urging the need for funds and material for the Red Cross, and requesting that the assistance that could be given be sent through their respective Red Cross Societies.

In May, this appeal was followed by Mr. Martin Frances, and Minister of Education, by a letter to teachers, trustees and pupils, recalling the good work that had already been done, and requesting assistance by way of funds for the Red Cross. In turn a letter to teachers and trustees from the Department was sent, establishing the Schools Red Cross Fund and recommended the formation of a Junior Red Cross Society in every school district. Efforts were also made to interest the Inspectors of Schools in the scheme, and many of them, besides holding meetings, made personal appeals by means of circular letters to the teachers and trustees in their jurisdictions. A diploma was presented to each school in whose jurisdiction that raised the largest amount for the Schools Red Cross Fund by December 31—and 40 of these diplomas have been presented at public meetings. At that date there had been subscribed a total of $15,195. Undoubtedly many times this sum would have been collected, but the epidemic of influenza prevented most of the schools just at the time the preparations were being made for the campaign to collect funds. When the fund was closed on September 30, 1919, the total amount turned in to the Red Cross Society by the school children, through the Schools Red Cross Fund, was $19,203.47. The signing of the Armistice, of course, caused most of such efforts to cease altogether.
The Junior Red Cross

Under all the circumstances this result testifies to the splendid assistance our school children, when effectively organised, can give to patriotic and humanitarian schemes. But this is not the whole story. There were organised in 1917 by the senior branches in the province 127 junior branches—in 1918, 285 were formed a total of—412. The amount raised by these and sent direct to Red Cross Headquarters, was at September 30, 1918, $1,600, and from October 1st to September 30th, 1919, $7,500, a total of $9,100. Not to weary you with figures, let it be added that the grand total raised for the Red Cross by the children was $38,700, and besides this they made innumerable articles for the comfort of our soldiers. These figures are eloquent. They speak of all the big and little sacrifices made and gifts given by teachers all over the province. They tell of splendid impulse actualising in good deeds, realised as for noble ends. Only those who love children may measure the deep and wide human interest implied in such results.

When subsequent to the Armistice, consideration was being given to the nature of Red Cross work in peace times, the Executive Committee at its meeting discussed the share that should be taken by the Junior Red Cross Societies. A committee of two was appointed, and the following report when presented to the full meeting of the Executive was unanimously adopted:

(1) That the Junior Red Cross Societies already organised be encouraged fully to resume their activities.

(2) That the organisation of Junior Red Cross Societies in connection with schools or other institutions throughout the province be encouraged.

(3) That Junior Red Cross Societies be recommended to hold regular meetings at least monthly, study among other things, certain details of domestic hygiene and public hygiene as related to municipal and rural conditions.

(4) That the Junior Red Cross Societies be encouraged to make contributions to a fund known as the Junior Red Cross Fund instituted for the care of crippled children.

(5) That the amount now at the credit of the Schools Red Cross Fund approximating $1,660 be used as a foundation of such fund.

(6) That a leaflet to be the organ of the Saskatchewan Junior Red Cross Society be issued monthly, the editorial and managing committee to be appointed by the Executive Committee, and that this leaflet be sent to every society, its contents to form the nucleus of study at the regular meetings.

In furtherance of the scheme outlined the president nominated a committee consisting of a doctor, the editor of one of the Regina dailies, the Director of School Hygiene for the province and the two members of the original committee. This committee has already investigated several cases reported to require orthopedic treatment, and is setting in motion schemes for discovering necessitous cases of the kind throughout the province.

The appeal of the crippled children of the province, we believe, will readily awaken the sympathies of children who are sound and well. The studies in personal, domestic and public hygiene will awaken an interest (Continued on page 14)

File Hills Indian Junior Red Cross

The boarding school on the File Hills Indian Reserve contains about seventy-five Indian children. When the Junior Red Cross was organised in 1916 every pupil became an enthusiastic member. Some already had money to pay the membership fee; the others immediately set to work and got it. There were many other children on the reserve, little tots not old enough to go to school or earn money to pay their membership fee by working on farms or elsewhere made them members. It came about that the Junior Red Cross at File Hills had the youngest member in the world—the baby Kowayaytin aged only seven weeks. The oldest member of the Red Cross Society also lived on the File Hills reserve, the aged and venerable Chiposotatum who had reached the advanced age of 109.

The Red Cross was not a new thing to the Indian children as they had done much to help the senior members from the beginning of the war, but they went to work with more energy when they had their own society. They volunteered to spend two evenings a week for the Red Cross making bead chains, torn gauze, magazine covers and knitting and crocheting many useful articles. One little Indian girl made a good deal of money for the Red Cross by knitting mittens for the hills. They sold at ten cents a pair.

During the harvest of 1918 the boys and girls raised money by stoking sheaves. All the older ones who were able to lift a sheaf went out into the harvest fields while the younger ones worked extra hard at the housework and chores. By this splendid co-operation they together helped to make money for the Red Cross. They received a certain amount for their work and gave it all. So the Junior Red Cross at File Hills has earned about three hundred dollars for the good work and now that they know the service the Junior Red Cross is giving to crippled children they are going to work with renewed energy and plan to make their society one of the best in the province.

For the Relief of Crippled Children

To the Teachers of the Schools of Saskatchewan:

The Saskatchewan Division of the Canadian Red Cross Society in an effort to perpetuate the work of the Junior Red Cross branches throughout the province has created the above committee to take charge of the general organization of Junior Red Cross work with a view to the maintenance of a fund for the relief of crippled children. Such unfortunate cases are not uncommon and are more frequent than generally known. They evoke our deepest sympathy and will doubtless inspire us all to assist in providing the medical and surgical attention required, and in supplying hospitals with the necessary apparatus and other items.

A crippled child is naturally the object of much sympathy and kindly feeling in other children and it is a phase of education with definite value to the training of children for good citizenship. It is a natural sentiment demanding for its proper expression. What could be more fitting than that the children who have been blessed with sound, healthy limbs should be called upon to assist a plan which aims at as sound and healthy as possible those who are crippled? The committee feel convinced that the idea will appeal to children all over the province.

We urge that the Junior Red Cross be organised. If there is a Junior Red Cross Society in your neighbourhood see that the pupils of your school join it and work for it. If there is no such organisation, make an effort to establish one in connection with your school. The committee will be glad to receive any funds for the purpose indicated above either by small regular contributions or by means of a special contribution provided by public entertainments or similar methods. You will be kept informed from time to time of any dispositions made for the collection of contributions. Every dollar raised shall be expended for relief work among the children of the province and not one cent for organisation or expenses.

The committee trust that every teacher will take a lively interest in the scheme. It will take time and energy to organise your school or class efficiently and keep up interest but what a noble cause!

The committee urges you to deal with the matter immediately in your district. You will be glad to know that the Junior Red Cross Club already amounts to several thousand members throughout the province by the end of last year. The relief of crippled children has begun. Teachers are asked to report to the Secretary of the Committee, Mr. W. F. Kerr, 217 Macdonald Street. Report any cases in their locality requiring treatment. Investigations will be made by the committee and assistance given where needed.

The scheme has the fullest approval of His Honour Sir Richard Lake and the Honourable W. M. Maclean, Premier and Minister of Education.

All contributions should be sent to Saskatchewan Headquarters, Canadian Red Cross Society, Regina, and marked "Junior Red Cross Fund for Crippled Children."

THE PRINCE OF WALES

"The Friend of the Children of the Empire"
The Lady With The Lamp

On England's annals through the long
Her name is written in the song,
That light its rays shall cast
From portals of the past.

"A lady with a lamp shall stand
In the dark hours of the land,
A noble type of good
Heroic womanhood."

When thinking of the origin of the Red Cross one naturally recalls Florence Nightingale. She was the first to do for the soldier what the Red Cross has done for him in the Great War. Setting the example herself she organised in 1854 a band of thirty-eight nurses to bring comfort and health to sick and wounded soldiers in the Crimea.

She saw that good wholesome food was essential for them and started proper kitchens in the hospitals. She had medical stores sent from England and bought with all speed to the seat of war. She wrote to friends in England to send out books and papers so that the patients in hospitals might have something to read. She had recreation huts built where the convalescent could write letters, play games or have entertainments. She provided paper and stamps for their letters. She persuaded as many as possible to send money to their families and even organised a Money Order Office to make this as easy as possible. She looked after the health and comfort of any of the families who had come out with the army and even arranged for invalids to be sent back to England. She did more than her share of the nursing of those who particularly needed her care.

With a mind of exceptional ability to originate plans and reform abuses she combined a heart so tender and a love for others so great that we have almost forgotten all the wonderful work of organising which she did and remember her only as "The Lady with the Lamp" walking down the cold dark corridors of the hospital at Scutari after all others were in bed. But to me it seemed that all was not well as far as the poor soldiers were concerned. The incident mentioned of the soldier turning "to kiss her shadow as she passed" was really true of at least one man. He was a Highlander whose arm had been so badly wounded that the doctors said it would have to be taken off, but Florence Nightingale begged to be allowed to see the patient and worked hard to see if special care could not save it. She was allowed to do this and worked so hard she well that it healed and the soldier naturally was most grateful. He always liked to lie awake at night to see her pass by and kiss the shadow of the woman who had done so much for him. In fact all the soldiers loved dearly this noble loving young lady who had given up all the comfort of a home in England to come out to the Crimea to make things more comfortable for the wounded of our army.

And it was a far different thing to do this in 1854 than it was in 1914. In 1854 there were no women nurses in the army. No women nurses had ever been with our armies so it was a hard task to find women who knew something of the care of the sick and at the same time had a ability to meet and overcome all the difficulties that would be sure to arise in such new work. Some idea of what they had to do may be imagined when we read that when they arrived at Scutari there were in the hospital no vessels for carrying water, no towels of any kind, no soap, towels no clothes. No washing was done so there was no clean linen. There were no bandages or hospital supplies. No hospital clothes had been provided for the men who were lying mostly on the floors, their uniforms stiff with blood and their bodies covered with the vermin that infested

FLORENCE NIGHTINGALE

the dreadful den of dirt and pestilence and death to which they were consigned.

There was no proper cooking apparatus and what food could be got was cold and unappetising, for it had to be carried long distances to many of the patients as they lay in the open air on the hospital grounds of a mile long. Before Florence Nightingale arrived the cooking for the sick was done in large kettles into which the meat and potatoes were thrown together and the resulting greasy soup was all the poor invalids
had. But a few days after her arrival chicken broth, beef tea and jellies made their appearance to tempt the appetite and cheer the spirits of the poor suffering men. The swiftness with which she was able to create order and comfort in this terrible place might well be called one of the wonders of the age.

The secret of her ability to do all this lay largely in the fact that all her life had been an offering and a preparation. Her work in the Crimea was not the outcome of a mere generous impulse. It was the fruit of years of steady preparation. The war gave her an opportunity of which others, less wisely desiring to volunteer, could not take advantage. She had always liked to help others, particularly the sick, and to do that well she soon found out that she must learn all she could on the subject of nursing. So she visited hospitals in England and Scotland and learned whatever she could of their management and care of the sick—and this was considered by many a most unlikely thing for a woman to do. Then she went abroad to study. On her return to England she was placed in charge of a hospital for sick governesses which had just been opened in London. This gave her a training in the management of an institution as well as training in nursing.

So, having armed herself by hard work and hard study she was ready when the call came to do a great and wonderful work. Not only by doing so much for the poor unfortunate soldier, but also because of her fine character and training she was able to lift a despised occupation into being one of the most noblest and dignified—into a woman's engagement.

On her return from the Crimea she was presented with a gift of $250,000 to which people of all classes and in all parts of the Empire had contributed and this sum she gave to establish and maintain an institution for the training of nurses and hospital attendance and for some years she presided over this institution.

When in 1860 her health gave way and she became a bedridden invalid for the rest of her long life she still worked hard at her life work of ameliorating human suffering. She still kept in touch with all movements of social and hygienic reform and indeed was able by her writings to organise and direct the welfare of boys in Great Britain and India. So to the end of her long life she worked from morning to night and sometimes from night to morning as well at her Master's work—caring for others with no thought of reward or rest for herself.

Saskatchewan Juniors at Work

Since the organization of the Saskatchewan Junior Red Cross Committee a few months ago, and the approval by the Provincial Red Cross Executive of its plan of work, the main feature of which is to encourage the formation of Junior Red Cross Societies throughout the Province and thereby enlist the sympathising and active assistance of the boys and girls of Saskatchewan in providing medical and surgical attention for crippled children whose parents are too poor to obtain proper relief for them—the committee has had no less than eleven cases reported to it, all of which have been investigated and definite action taken to relieve the sufferings of these little patients.

The following brief outline of these cases will serve to indicate the nature of the work the Junior Red Cross is undertaking in Saskatchewan and in support of which the boys and girls in the schools of the province are urged to organise their own Junior Red Cross Societies and contribute towards the relief of their suffering brothers and sisters in less fortunate positions in life.

REPORT OF CASES

Case of Eye Trouble.

Case No. 1. E. M. Cadillac—in August last the secretary of Bedford S.D., No. 3195, forwarded to the Department of Education a letter received by him from Miss Morton, who stated she was unable to attend school on account of eye trouble. The secretary of the school district wrote back saying that there was no case deserving one but that the father, owing to successive total crop failures for the last three years, was unable to send the boy treated. Upon the organisation of the Junior Red Cross committee this case was referred to it. Through the director of school hygiene, Miss Morton was sent to Broadview and examined this boy and advised that he was a suspect of trachoma and should be immediately seen by the local board of health and to the provincial bureau of public health. So far as the Junior Red Cross committee is concerned it was thus relieved of responsibility.

Tubercular Spine.

Case No. 2.—(A. F. Broadview) This is the case of a deformed girl, a humpback, aged 10 years, daughter of a man of foreign birth, and was reported by her school teacher. She was last seen by the director of school hygiene. The resident doctor examined the case and reported the deformity as due to a tubercular condition of the spine. He took the child to a specialist in Winnipeg with the understanding that she be left there until such time as treatment had been completed. The child's parents were informed that with proper treatment there is hope for the child's cure. After the organisation of the Junior Red Cross committee this case was entrusted to it. Unfortunately, during the interval of time which elapsed, the family moved from Broadview and only recently a report was received that the child and parents were living near Colonay. An effort is now being made through the school inspector of that inspectional to locate this girl.

A Case that is Hopeless.

Case No. 3.—(E. L. North Regina) Through the cooperation of the Regina Branch of the Red Cross Society this case of a little girl of 7 years was brought to the attention of the Junior Red Cross committee. The child has never walked, cannot speak, and has to be spoonfed, cannot eat solid food. The parents and other facts relating to this girl and her case were reported by Miss Morton, school nurse, and recently a visit was made at the request of the Junior Red Cross committee. Miss Morton stated that
The Junior Red Cross

the mother was anxious to have the child examined by a physician, but could not afford to do so. The Junior Red Cross arranged with the mother to take her daughter to a local physician and have her examined at Junior Red Cross expense. This was done. The physician reported that the case was hopeless, that there was lack of brain development, as well as physical deformities, and that a massage might serve to straighten her limbs somewhat, nothing really effective in the case. It was decided that the mother of the child has written the Junior Red Cross expressing appreciation of the help she had found in their belief. The physician declined to accept any fee for a Red Cross case.

To Have Adenoids Removed.

Case No. 7—A. M., Cadillac—This is the case of a boy of 12 years who had spinal meningitis when he was six years old. He is one of a family of nine children, whose father earns $20 per week. Miss Cooper of the Junior Red Cross has been working on the case. The most urgent need was for braces properly adjusted by an orthopedist. The boy was placed in a wheelchair, as the surgeon so advised. The Junior Red Cross has had this little girl attending school, and she is now able to walk with the aid of a cane.

Helping a Widow's Child.

Case No. 5—A. C., Rosanville—Reported to the Red Cross by Mrs. Deacon, widow of a soldier. The boy lives on a farm 18 miles from Cadillac and is suffering from advanced operation, but the parents, being in very poor circumstances, could not afford it. The Junior Red Cross has arranged with Dr. Porter to undertake the treatment of this boy at Junior Red Cross expense.

Fast Required Treatment.

Case No. 8—K. B., Weyburn—This boy of 7 years of age, the son of a woman of several children, has been under the control of the Provincial Superintendent of Neglected and Dependent Children. His mother is unable to control him. He has been working on farms, but is in such poor health that he cannot possibly go about doing work. The boy has a deformed foot. The Superintendent of Neglected and Dependent Children has asked Junior Red Cross to make arrangements for surgical treatment for this boy by Dr. Gallaway, Winnipeg, and to pay his hospital bill. He asked that the Red Cross undertake to pay his fare to Winnipeg and return. This the Junior Red Cross did.

The Junior Red Cross Committee wants to see a Junior Red Cross Society organized in connection with every school in Saskatchewan in order to give all boys and girls with sound and healthy bodies an opportunity to contribute their share, however small, towards "The Junior Red Cross Fund for Crippled Children," and thus enable the committee to give prompt and necessary attention to all further cases of crippled children in our own province who require assistance.

Is there a Junior Red Cross Society in your school? If not, will you not interest yourself in the formation of one without loss of time and thus have your school take a part in this noble work?

Deformed and Crippled.

Case No. 10—A. A., Pennant—This is the case of a boy 13 years of age, who was brought to Regina by Miss Simpson of the school hygiene staff. When quite a small child he had infantile paralysis, which caused him to be crippled. Six years ago the municipality sent him to Rochester where he had a certain number of bones given an iron splint to wear, which he has outgrown. The mother had a larger one made for him, but it was not at all satisfactory. The mother is a woman with a family of four children, who could not find anyone able to give the boy fitted with a proper splint. The Junior Red Cross has arranged with Dr. Gallaway on March 23 and he is now being fitted with proper braces at Junior Red Cross expense.

Successful Operation Performed.

Case No. 11—M.T., Francis—This young girl, years of age, is a sister of E. T. Case No. 6, and operated for removal of tonsils and adenoids was required. In company with her sister she was brought to Regina on May 2. She was operated for by the Junior Red Cross for her admittance to the Alexander Clark Hospital, Regina General Hospital. She was successfully operated on the following day, and two days later was able to return to her home.
A Letter from Our Premier

To the Teachers of Saskatchewan:

Regina, March 31, 1920.

The covenant of the League of Nations has placed before us all of its significance and duty of emphasis on a new foundation the noble work of the Red Cross. Hitherto active only in time of war it is now to continue its work in time of peace and in the words of the covenant "to encourage and promote the establishment and co-operation of the authorities and voluntary Red Cross Societies throughout the world pursuing the improvement of health, the prevention of disease and the mitigation of suffering throughout the world."

It is therefore evident that the Junior Red Cross of Saskatchewan has set before itself very definite objects—chiefly the study and practice of hygiene and the relief of crippled children. I realise that these aims will tend gradually toward humanitarian phases of education and that the former will benefit the hundreds of many children now apparently doomed to lives of suffering. In the study of health, in the practice of healthy habits, in the assistance given to crippled children, and good citizenship will be daily inculcated and our citizenship thereby strengthened towards good ends.

The Junior Red Cross therefore has my most approving sympathy and I trust that while schools are in operation, in order to assist the realisation of these objects, a portion of every Friday afternoon be given to the study of those humanitarian phases of education and citizenship for which the Junior Red Cross stands.

Yours very truly,

Naturally, Red Cross workers will realise that though the primary object of Junior Red Cross Societies in Saskatchewan has been set down as the creation and fund for the relief of crippled children, the secondary object, namely the training of the altruistic instincts of the children is possibly the most important from the long distance view of training for citizenship. The view held by Sir Arthur Currie was voiced by him in all his public addresses, that the offices of the splendid service of the late noble man can only be made effective in the life of this Dominion by a similar spirit of service and sacrifice on the part of all its citizens, will find vital expression in the lives of our children in the many little sacrifices for the Junior Red Cross and the great service for crippled children. What an appeal the Red Cross will ultimately become second only in its influence to the appeal of the White Cross the symbol of our religious goodness!

Everywhere one hears the call to service—service not of ourselves, but of our fellow citizens, the larger service of the community in which we live, and the splendid service for our country and our race. Children think in simple terms. They tend to act upon their impulses in immediate action. The Red Cross supplies another category of good impulses. Children are impatient of principles and precepts, finding the application of daily moral problems to such principles difficult, but they appreciate facts, the facts of suffering and the Red Cross provides the opportunity for training in what may be termed concrete goodness.

Hints on Organization of Junior Red Cross Societies

The Junior Red Cross Committee wants to see a Junior Red Cross Society formed in connection with every school in Saskatchewan. That is the committee's objective for 1920. You can help in this connection in once more putting Saskatchewan 'over the top.'

The organisation of a Junior Red Cross Society is very simple. All boys and girls under eighteen years of age are eligible for membership. The annual membership fee is small—only twenty-five cents. A membership button will be supplied to each member by the Junior Red Cross Committee.

A member should be enrolled on payment of the membership fee and the taking of some simple pledge like the following:

"I promise to serve the King and the flag of my country, the symbol of liberty and justice, and to work for the Red Cross, the emblem of humanity and service throughout the world."

The simple organization of a Junior Red Cross Society may be covered by the following:

1. Name—This Society shall be known as the Junior Red Cross Society of ______.

2. Objects—The objects of the Society shall be to acquaint its members with the aims and objects of the Red Cross, to enlist the sympathies and services of the members in behalf of suffering childhood and the needs of those children less fortunate situated, to instil into themselves to give instruction in hygiene and encourage healthful habits among its members, and generally to inculcate and develop kindly thought and sympathetic action by personal effort and sacrifice in behalf of others, thus providing intelligent training in good citizenship.

3. Membership and Fees—All young people under 18 years of age shall be eligible for membership. The membership fee shall be twenty-five cents per annum.

4. Meetings—Meetings of the Society shall be held at least once a month.

5. Officers—The officers shall consist of a Director (who should be the teacher in charge of the school), a President, and a Secretary Treasurer, to be chosen from among the members.

6. Committees—Committees to be named by the Director may be appointed, such as Membership, Finance, Programme or Entertainment, and such special committees as occasion may require.

Upon completion of organisation of a Junior Red Cross Society the Report Form enclosed herewith, should be completed and forwarded promptly to W.F. Kerr, Secretary Junior Red Cross Committee, 2175 Cameron Street, Regina, Sask. Upon receipt of this Report Form, a supply of Junior Red Cross membership buttons will be sent forward.

October 6th, 1924

To the Teachers of Ontario Indian Schools,

It gives me much pleasure to offer you the services of Junior Red Cross for the encouragement of the development of good health habits amongst your pupils. There is no charge for these services. They are offered free to the schools by the Red Cross as part of its peace-time service to make Canada healthier and happier.

As the enclosed leaflet explains, Junior Red Cross is an "activity" plan of teaching. The pupils enroll as junior members of the Red Cross (free) and agree as a group to "play the health game". There are pretty membership buttons, attractive merit badges, colored posters, a charter, etc. Each month the class gets our magazine (free) with interesting pictures, reading matter, etc.

If the members of the class are old enough and clever enough, they may hold occasional meetings as a Head, Heart, Hand and Health Club, but this is not essential. The important thing is that they should "play the game" daily, keep themselves clean, keep their school sanitary, etc - and so grow up healthy and strong.

I enclose an Application Form for the enrollment of your class. Upon receipt of it we will send you a full set of supplies. Dr. Scott, Deputy Superintendent General of the Department of Indian Affairs in accepting our proposal and sending us a list of Indian Schools says, "I am sure that many of our teachers in Ontario Indian Schools will be glad to utilize the "health games" which are promoted by your society". Miss Moffit's class at Cape Croker is enrolled.

During the past three years the work has grown steadily in favour in our schools. It is past the experimental stage. It is now being encouraged in the Normal Schools. You can have it for a three cent stamp!

Yours for Good Health and Good Citizenship,

Prof. J. A. Dale,
Chairman, J.R.C. Committee,
